webTitle: Derby 0 - 0 West Ham

fields.headline: Derby cheered by damp squib
fields.trailText: Derby 0 - 0 West Ham
fields.body:
Derby were hardly inclined towards singing in the rain but after four consecutive Premiership defeats a point at least brought relief for Jim Smith's beleaguered side on an inhospitable evening.

Without a win in 12 matches, Derby remain bottom of the table, a point behind now-managerless Bradford, who are their next home opponents on Saturday week. West Ham, on top for the middle part of the contest, had half a dozen chances to score but Derby finished the stronger, with Craig Burley going close in the final moments.

One who was not kept away by the weather was Colin Todd, who was making his Derby debut for the second time, almost 30 years since Brian Clough signed him as a player. Todd, who knows a thing or two about watertight defences, has arrived this time as assistant manager, in the hope that two wise heads will do better than one as Jim Smith grapples with the task of turning the relegation tide.

On the field, Derby were reinforced by the arrival of Lilian Martin, a right-sided defender signed on a free transfer from Olympique Marseille. Martin has the distinction of being the first Frenchman, who is shortly to be joined by a Nigerian, Taribo West, in a squad boasting a dozen nationalities.

They could have done with their Belgian, Branko Strupar, to counter a strong West Ham rearguard in which Ian Pearce continued his comeback alongside Rio Ferdinand and his namesake, Stuart.

Rory Delap had the first crack at goal, although it was a wild one that did not trouble Shaka Hislop. There was much endeavour from the home side, if no discernible pattern. West Ham boldly began with three up front, no doubt hoping it might curb Derby's adventure, but the absence of Joe Cole, ruled out by an ankle injury, left a missing link.

Finally, with half-time close, West Ham raised some excitement. Three times in the space of five minutes, Mart Poom, Derby's Estonian goalkeeper, came to his side's rescue, palming away stinging shots by Michael Carrick and Frederic Kanoute and leaping to his right to parry a powerful header by Ferdinand.

Poom was clearly reluctant to handle the slippery ball and he was tested again early in the second half as Carrick and then Frank Lampard delivered shots pitched awkwardly in front of him. Carrick's effort almost squirted under his body and Lampard's, which he fumbled completely, would have spelt danger had it not spun kindly to a team-mate.

Meanwhile, the first hour was completed with Hislop still waiting to be extended. Derby's front trio were largely ineffective and it was left to their midfield to pose a long-overdue threat. A long-range effort by Seth Johnson at least passed respectably close but a header by Craig Burley was easily dealt with. Another by a diving Simo Valakari, a half-time substitute for skipper Darryl Powell, sailed harmlessly over the top.

Disappointingly, the two players with the individual flair to break the deadlock had been confined to the fringes, Paolo di Canio for once unable to make more than fleeting impressions, Georgi Kinkladze too often isolated on the flanks, although he was a greater influence once Smith switched him to a more central role.

webTitle: England spin twins seeking tandem effect

fields.headline: England spin twins seeking tandem effect
fields.trailText: The Devils in Tracksuits took to the hills yesterday. Those of the England team not sufficiently philistine to want to lounge round the hotel or play golf on their day off travelled by coach away from Peshawar, into the Khyber area which is home to some of the fiercest tribes on the planet, and carried on under armed escort up the sinuous road into the Khyber Pass itself, as far as the fortress of Michni Post, beyond which, in dusty brown panorama, lay the town of Torkhan, three miles distant and several hundred metres below. Beyond that, through the haze, Afghanistan.
fields.body:
The Devils in Tracksuits took to the hills yesterday. Those of the England team not sufficiently philistine to want to lounge round the hotel or play golf on their day off travelled by coach away from Peshawar, into the Khyber area which is home to some of the fiercest tribes on the planet, and carried on under armed escort up the sinuous road into the Khyber Pass itself, as far as the fortress of Michni Post, beyond which, in dusty brown panorama, lay the town of Torkhan, three miles distant and several hundred metres below. Beyond that, through the haze, Afghanistan.

Some places just take the breath away and this was one. It was, said Ashley Giles, who admits to being into history, very special. Then it was back to the hotel and reality.

Tomorrow England begin the final warm-up match here before the first Test next week. Giles, the left-arm tweaker, and Ian Salisbury, his wrist-spinning confrere on this tour, know that come the big game in Lahore one of them almost certainly will be chosen, perhaps even both.

This four-day game against a Governor's XI, though, is their chance to impress - not only selectors but opposition as well - and to show that stories of the dire state of English spin bowling are exaggerated. It is also a chance for each to outshine the other.

Both know that they will have to excel to win over those sceptical of their selection for the tour. The last England spinner to take five wickets in a Test innings was Peter Such in Sydney two winters ago.

Public expectations of English spinners, even after the England team triumphs of last summer, are at a low ebb, with unfavourable comparisons already drawn with the world-class Pakistan duo of Saqlain Mushtaq and Mushtaq Ahmed.

"We have [read] that we are supposed to be on a hiding to nothing and our records [have been] paraded," Giles said. "Personally I'm not worried about that. If we do well, they will have to sit up and take notice. You have to put up with the criticism and live with it."

Both draw confidence from the fact that they are being brought into the game earlier in Pakistan than at home, and both sent down significant overs - Giles 34.3, Salisbury 33 - in last week's win in Rawalpindi, the former finishing with four for 63, his partner two for 83.

Giles was the steadier, Salisbury by his own admission rusty but derusting rapidly, with the googly coming out nicely. "It is important to stress the different conditions here," Salisbury said. "At home the ball retains its hardness and can still be swinging and seaming after 100 overs. It is not conducive to spin bowling any more, which is why counties are more ready to sign a trundler than take a gamble on a spinner. Here, though, the ball goes soft quickly."

Giles said: "If we played out here regularly it would give us confidence, because all too often at home we are waiting 60 overs to get into the game."

They both hope they will be allowed to play together more on tour because spinners, like pace bowlers, feed off one another. The chances of both making the Test side have to be slim, however, unless the Lahore pitch is a dust bowl. That too is unlikely, as Pakistan tend to back their spinners on relatively good surfaces knowing that on pitches that are too helpful it is also possible for the home side to be ambushed.

England will probably opt for caution early in the series, with Giles getting the nod first-up over the maverick Salisbury.

 Wasim Akram, recommended to be fined £3,000 by Pakistan's Qayyum report into match-fixing, is to be awarded a gold medal for his services to the game by the country's military ruler General Pervez Musharraf, in his capacity as head of the Pakistan Cricket Board. Medals are also to be given to Saeed Anwar and Inzamam-ul-Haq and to the fast bowler Waqar Younis. Wasim protests his innocence and is refusing to pay the fine, and now it seems his board is closing ranks around him.

webTitle: Rangers 2 - 2 Monaco

fields.headline: Rangers 2 - 2 Monaco
fields.trailText: Rangers: Christensen, Vidmar, Wilson, Amoruso, Numan, Ricksen, Ferguson, Albertz, de Boer, Miller, Mols. Subs: Brown, Kanchelskis, Wallace, Dodds, Tugay, McCann, Porrini.
fields.body:
Rangers: Christensen, Vidmar, Wilson, Amoruso, Numan, Ricksen, Ferguson, Albertz, de Boer, Miller, Mols. Subs: Brown, Kanchelskis, Wallace, Dodds, Tugay, McCann, Porrini.

Monaco: Porato, Da Costa, Christanval, Irles, Contreras, Dabo, Bonnal, Giuly, Gallardo, Simone, Nonda. Subs: Biancarelli, Riise, Gravelaine, Wagneau, Leonard, Prso, Rodriguez.

Referee: Lubos Michel (Slovakia)

1 Rangers kick off. Crunch time for Dick Advocaat and Rangers tonight as they walk the European plank and attempt to salvage their Champions League campaign with victory progression to the second phase. Ditto Monaco, which all makes for a very interesting night at Ibrox.
2 Monaco make an early break down the right flank with Simone.
3 GOAL Frantic pace as both teams seek to gain an early advantage without actually showing any cohesion in their play. Rangers take up temporary residence in the Monaco half, but the ball comes out to Albertz on the half-way line - he fires it down the left for Ferguson to cross first time. The bounce leaves Contreras flailing and Miller is on the far side of the six-yard box to fire home with a right-foot shot.
6 No let up in the pace after this dream start for Rangers.
8 Monaco look rattled and are making too many errors on the ball. Rangers start to knock it around at the back a bit and manage to calm things down.
9 Rangers taking control of the game as de Boer races on to a long ball and into yards of space on the right; he crosses for Mols who is charging towards the area, but Christanval does well to intercept and clear.
14 Rangers try to work the ball up on the left from a free-kick, to no avail.
15 Mols looks to be struggling a little and is lucky to avoid a booking when he mis-times a challenge and leaves a Monaco player for dead.
17 Despite struggling, Mols performs some fancy footwork to make use of the space that Monaco are allowing Rangers at the back.
18 Rangers come close to a second when Miller shoots from just inside the area; Mols is unlucky with the rebound.
19 Monaco corner on the right. Simone takes and Rangers clear, but Simone recovers the chance and cuts inside for a shot into the crowd.
20 Miller gets away on the left, but his cross is blocked.
24 A brief period of, well, nothing really. A few taps back to keeper by both teams and the game has slows down a bit. That's it until Monaco realise they have a game to win and fire in a couple of speculative crosses that Rangers have no trouble clearing. Rangers get caught offside a couple of times.
27 Giuly starts a move on the edge of the Rangers area that ends with Nonda missing what looked like a sitter after good work by Simone to keep a cross in play on the edge of the six-yard box.
31 Mols again manages to turn a defender in the blink of an eye, but Monaco are making most of the running - shame they can't get their attacking play sorted out.
32 Monaco free-kick 35 yards out. Simone takes towards the head of Contreras in the six-yard box but the ball goes over.
33 A long ball from just inside the Rangers half finds Mols in acres of space and not even one on one, but his right-foot shot goes wide.
37 Monaco push up and win a free-kick 30 yards out to the left. Simone taps for Dabo to fire over the bar.
38 Numan gets up on the left for Rangers and crosses from just inside the Monaco area for Miller to shoot wide.
39 GOAL Simone whips in a corner from the right and Da Costa meets the ball to head in the equaliser.
41 Rangers reeling now as Nonda turns Vidmar on the edge of the area and drags his shot just wide of the far post.
42 Monaco corner. Simone takes again and the lanky Christanval is unlucky to see his header go over.
45 De Boer glides through midfield, finds Ricksen on the right, picks up the return and wins a free-kick. Monaco break with Nonda but Vidmar gets across to cut him off. Half-time.

46 Nonda kicks off for Monaco and Simone hoofs the ball up to Christenson in the Rangers goal.
47 Monaco almost take the lead after Amoruso dwells on the ball and allows Simone to break through the back line. He runs it too far and after some fancy, but insignificant, jigging around, Rangers clear.
50 Nonda races away from Vidmar down the right, but Vidmar recovers well to chop him down under the guise of well-timed sliding tackle.
52 GOAL Mols, clean through just inside the area, waits to read the bounce of a high lob over the back line and shoots past Porato to put Rangers in the lead.
56 Substitution Tugay on for Mols.
57 Substitution Prso on for Nonda.
58 Rangers corner from the left; Porato gathers easily.
60 Da Costa feeds Giuly on the right but his cross is gathered by Christensen.
62 Monaco coming forward with determination now and it's clear Rangers are going to have to fight to get a result.
63 Rangers have a chance to wrap things up when Numan, on the left edge of the Monaco area, crosses for Ferguson to shoot high into the crowd.
55 Booking Gravelaine for chopping down Ricksen.
67 Simone finds Giuly in the Rangers area but Numan does well to hustle him out and clear.
68 Giuly now an ever-present threat, but Rangers manage to break as Albertz finds Miller in space on the left. Miller gets into the area and then fluffs his chance to get a second.
70 Booking Dabo for a challenge on Albertz, who needs to go off for some attention as a result.
72 Monaco are not giving up. Simone is charging around trying to do the job of three men, despite the fact the the three men around him are happy to do their bit. 75 Dabo shoots from 30 yards but only sees it fly into the crowd.
77 Albertz gets on the end of a Miller cross from the right but his shot from the edge of the area is saved.
78 GOAL Disaster for Rangers just seconds after Albertz's chance. Prso slides the ball through to Simone and he runs across Christensen before putting a shot past the Rangers keeper at the far post. Substitution Wallace on for De Boer.

83 Rangers continue to live dangerously as a cross and header by Monaco only just clears the bar.
84 Manic stuff now as both teams try to get the elusive winner that will see them through to the next round.
85 Substitution McCann on for Albertz. Rangers corner from the left - Gravelaine hooks it clear from the goal-line.
86 Monaco free-kick from wide on the left, but it is too deep for everyone in the area.
87 Wallace controls the ball well 30 yards out, but opts to snatch at a long-range shot instead of looking around him for other options.
90 Rangers free-kick deep on the left; handball given against Rangers. McCann gets away on the left and crosses superbly but Wallace cannot make his shot count. Rangers last chance? Monaco then come close when Bonnal drags his shot wide of the far post. Monaco's last chance? End to end of stuff.... but that's it, full-time. Both Monaco and Rangers go out of the competition, Rangers fate assured after Sturm Graz and Galatasaray potter around for the last few minutes of their 2-2 draw in Istanbul after hearing the result in Scotland.

webTitle: Boro hit out over 'illegal' Ziege move

fields.headline: Boro hit out over 'illegal' Ziege move
fields.trailText: Middlesbrough may take Liverpool to court over compensation for Christian Ziege's £5.5m move to Anfield in August.
fields.body:
Middlesbrough may take Liverpool to court if they are not paid an additional £2.5m compensation for Christian Ziege's £5.5m move to Anfield in August.

The Boro chairman Steve Gibson, awaiting a Premier League ruling on the transfer, yesterday reiterated his belief that the Merseysiders had made an illegal approach for the German international.

"The fact that Liverpool made the move two or three weeks before the start of the season inflicted maximum damage on Bryan Robson's pre-season plans," he said, adding that "the rules have clearly been broken. We haven't closed the option of taking the matter outside football. We don't rule out any possibility."

Ziege joined Boro in 1999 for £4m from Milan and played 29 Premiership games for them. Liverpool's manager Gérard Houllier tabled a bid for the 28-year-old in July and the defender, recently returned from Euro 2000, opted to use a get-out clause in his contract allowing him to leave Middlesbrough for a fee of £5.5m. Initially the Teesside club blocked Liverpool's approach until Ziege threatened to take them to the high court.

Now Boro are demanding a further £2.5m, claiming that two other clubs had made £8m bids for his services in the summer. "I would hope that the severity of the damages would be a warning to all clubs," said Gibson.

"We took great comfort from the rules of the Premier League, which state quite categorically that no club can induce a player to join them and no player can induce a club to sign him.

"Further clauses in Premier League rules say it's illegal for either the football club to disclose details of a player's contract or for the player to display details of his contract.

"We wish to explore that through the correct channels so that the matter can be concluded to the satisfaction of the Premier League rule book. It's an ongoing situation."

Liverpool have denied acting improperly. Last night the club refused to comment.

Ziege's team-mate Patrik Berger will undergo surgery in the United States this week on the injured knee that is likely to rule him out for the rest of the season. The midfielder, who suffered the injury against Leeds on Saturday, will see the knee specialist Richard Steadman in Colorado.

 Wembley's twin towers will be demolished with the rest of the stadium after a plan by Halton Council to relocate them to Widnes to form part of a rugby league museum failed because it would have been too expensive.

"Staging a demolition in such a way as to temporarily retain the towers would add in excess of £10m to the cost of the new stadium," said the stadium's chief executive Bob Stubbs. "Halton have made it clear they could not meet such a cost."

 Scotland will face Poland in a friendly on April 21 next year, when neither side is playing a World Cup qualifier.

The Boro chairman Steve Gibson, awaiting a Premier League ruling on the transfer, yesterday reiterated his belief that the Merseysiders had made an illegal approach for the German international. "The fact that Liverpool made the move two or three weeks before the start of the season inflicted maximum damage on Bryan Robson's pre-season plans," he said, adding that "the rules have clearly been broken. We haven't closed the option of taking the matter outside football. We don't rule out any possibility." Ziege joined Boro in 1999 for £4m from Milan and played 29 Premiership games for them. Liverpool's manager Gérard Houllier tabled a bid for the 28-year-old in July and the defender, recently returned from Euro 2000, opted to use a get-out clause in his contract allowing him to leave Middlesbrough for a fee of £5.5m. Initially the Teesside club blocked Liverpool's approach until Ziege threatened to take them to the high court. Now Boro are demanding a further £2.5m, claiming that two other clubs had made £8m bids for his services in the summer. "I would hope that the severity of the damages would be a warning to all clubs," said Gibson. "We took great comfort from the rules of the Premier League, which state quite categorically that no club can induce a player to join them and no player can induce a club to sign him. "Further clauses in Premier League rules say it's illegal for either the football club to disclose details of a player's contract or for the player to display details of his contract. "We wish to explore that through the correct channels so that the matter can be concluded to the satisfaction of the Premier League rule book. It's an ongoing situation." Liverpool have denied acting improperly. Last night the club refused to comment. Ziege's team-mate Patrik Berger will undergo surgery in the United States this week on the injured knee that is likely to rule him out for the rest of the season. The midfielder, who suffered the injury against Leeds on Saturday, will see the knee specialist Richard Steadman in Colorado.  Wembley's twin towers will be demolished with the rest of the stadium after a plan by Halton Council to relocate them to Widnes to form part of a rugby league museum failed because it would have been too expensive. "Staging a demolition in such a way as to temporarily retain the towers would add in excess of £10m to the cost of the new stadium," said the stadium's chief executive Bob Stubbs. "Halton have made it clear they could not meet such a cost."  Scotland will face Poland in a friendly on April 21 next year, when neither side is playing a World Cup qualifier.  You've read the piece, now have your say. webTitle: Hutchings sacked after 12 games

fields.headline: Hutchings sacked after 12 games
fields.trailText: Chris Hutchings has been sacked by Bradford City after only one win in 12 Premiership games this season. Stuart McCall takes over as caretaker manager.
fields.body:
Chris Hutchings' brief flirtation with management came to a predictable end yesterday when he was dismissed by Bradford City.

Less than a fortnight after the Bradford chairman Geoffrey Richmond warned him to produce an immediate improvement in results and team performance or face the consequences, Hutchings was informed that his tenure at Valley Parade was over after only 12 Premiership games.

The club's veteran former Scotland midfielder Stuart McCall has been placed in charge as caretaker and has already put himself forward for the full-time job.

"He is a serious candidate," Richmond said, but he will probably seek to install an experienced manager, possibly David Pleat, director of football at Spurs. "The target we've provisionally put in place is by the end of November for the appointment to be confirmed on a permanent basis."

Richmond, having left hospital, was back at Valley Parade to announce Hutchings' dismissal. The chairman had been admitted last Wednesday after suffering chest pains following his club's elimination from the Worthington Cup by Newcastle at St James' Park.

His patience ran out at the weekend after City were beaten 2-0 by Charlton, leaving the west Yorkshire club marooned in the bottom three. "The board felt the time for a change had now come to give the future manager as long as possible to change the fortunes on the field," he said.

The chairman scrawled the writing on Hutchings' wall 12 days ago by taking the unusual step of publicly confessing that he might have made a misjudgment in choosing a novice manager. Hutchings, 43, agreed to move up from No2 after Paul Jewell, who had against all odds preserved City's Premiership status last season, unexpectedly resigned.

Hutchings gambled, believing that in flooding the squad with ageing players of vast experience he would confound logic and the bookmakers by steering City to a position of comfort. Despite the introduction of Benito Carbone and Dan Petrescu, he was proved wrong.

City beat Chelsea at Valley Parade in the opening week but they still await a second league success, having managed only five league goals so far.

Hutchings' final throw of the dice came 11 days ago when he took the troublesome Stan Collymore on a free transfer from Leicester. Although Collymore scored in the 1-1 draw with their local rivals Leeds, the die was cast and, after the defeats by Newcastle and Charlton, Richmond acted, dismissing both Hutchings and his No2 Malcolm Shotton.

Hutchings, a former Chelsea and Brighton player, said: "I've had almost five years at City and still feel I've got a lot to offer football. I hope to get back in the game as quickly as possible."

webTitle: Rimless wonders change from blockheads to eggheads

fields.headline: Rimless wonders change from blockheads to eggheads
fields.trailText: Never mind the tactical nous, it's Sven-Goran Eriksson's glasses that will determine how successful he will be. Appearance is everything and spectacles are the new car coat.
fields.body:
In football a man does not have to do much to establish an image as an intellectual. Dressing rooms up and down the country are full of players nicknamed "Brains" because they once expressed the view that there might be more uses for a book than simply stabilising a wonky card-table.

Speaking of Sven-Goran Eriksson in this newspaper yesterday the football correspondent of Svenska Dagbladet commented: "When he changed his spectacles a few years ago he made himself look more like a professor." Given the suggestibility of footie folk, it is impossible to overplay the significance of this apparently offhand remark.

A few years ago Eriksson was a manager with a respectable but hardly earth-shattering reputation. Now he is hailed as one of the world's greatest football thinkers. It is hard to know if his improved standing stems from his having drunk deeply and long from the well of coaching knowledge, or simply the result of spending half an hour down at the Roman branch of Specsaver.

Admittedly since trading in his old frames for something a touch more academic-looking Eriksson has won the Italian double with Lazio. But how much that triumph owed to the Swede's finely honed tactical skills and how much to the boost his new glasses gave to his team's confidence in him we may never know. In the end it may not matter much. As Thomas Hardy observed, "Who seems most kingly is the King." If the players believe in the manager then that is half the battle won.

Footballers are by and large a superstitious breed. It cannot have escaped their notice, for example, that the World Cup has never been won by a coach with excessive facial hair. In the long term the putative German boss Christoph Daum's luxuriant moustache would surely have done far more to undermine his players' self-belief than a few trivial details about his racy private life. Likewise, subliminally at least, our nation's finest must have absorbed the fact that the majority of the managers who have recently dominated the domestic and world game - including Aimé Jacquet, Sir Alex Ferguson and Arsène Wenger - wear glasses.

This is a new development. Although the round-spectacles-and-baggy-suits "politburo look" was popular in the 30s with managers such as Herbert Chapman and the Italian team boss Vittorio Pozzo (who looked like a chubby, clean-shaven version of Trotsky) it fell out of style after the second world war. By the 70s managers had divided themselves into three distinctive schools: the bosses, the gaffers and the genial uncles. They did not look like professors, nor did they want to. Football was a visceral rather than mental activity.

Bosses such as Bertie Mee favoured sharp, shiny suits of a type that looked like they had been bought in a job lot from Gerry and the Pacemakers. Gaffers like Don Revie on the other hand wore car coats and the shifty look of illegal bookmakers, and genial uncles such as Joe Mercer loved incongruous combinations of clothing. The genial uncle look was perhaps best exemplified by West Germany's World Cup-winning manager Helmut Schoen, who wore a flat cap and an Adidas top with buttons down the front, a singular garment that might best be described as a tracksuit cardigan.

Brian Clough, meanwhile, began life in suits and ended up in tracksuit bottoms and a sweatshirt. Clough's clothing was all-important to his success. Much has been made of the Forest boss's ability to mould players to his will and get them to undertake the craziest of tasks. His appearance was the key. For whereas players might refuse to run through a field of nettles for somebody got up like an accountant, what British male could dare resist the orders of a man dressed like a games teacher?

And none of these great men wore glasses. Well, not openly anyway. But times have changed and once again the English have been slow to realise it.

Not that it is simply a question of sticking on any old pair of bifocals. As Eriksson's recent shift shows, they must also be the right type. The only England manager to flagrantly wear spectacles was Graham Taylor. Alas, all those years spent in close proximity to Elton John had not had an altogether positive influence on the Watford boss. His glasses were far too big to be credible.

Instead of saying "thinker" the expansive frames simply chuckled: "Hey, I'm a bit crazy, me."

webTitle: Champions League preview: Rangers v Monaco

fields.headline: Rangers feel heat in pressure group
fields.standfirst: Monaco visit Ibrox in shootout for a place in the second phase
fields.trailText:
Rangers v Monaco
After a promising start to their campaign, Rangers now face a bitter showdown for a place in the second phase when Monaco visit Ibrox tonight.
fields.body:
The blue half of Glasgow has always been boisterous in its passion but tonight at Ibrox Rangers and their supporters face the ultimate test of their coronary arteries. Scotland's champions take on Monaco in a Group D showdown that could not look more compelling if pistols and a cactus backdrop were supplied.

Their manager Dick Advocaat is facing one of the nights of his coaching life. A European campaign that started well for him has fallen into disarray amid chronic injuries and domestic turmoil.

Rangers, currently fourth in the Premier League, have not known such a lack of form in years. Tonight the stadium will crackle with tension as they seek to barge their way through from the tightest of the eight groups. They need to win or, if they draw, hope that Galatasaray lose at home to Sturm Graz.

Amid all of this, Advocaat has remained a beguiling figure. He managed Holland for two years and PSV after that but, like Jozef Venglos and John Barnes at Celtic, had not bargained for the hothouse of one of Britain's big football cities, where 50,000 season-ticket holders are breathing down his neck. As recent results have gone against Rangers, Advocaat can relate to the testimony of one of his predecessors. "There is no comfort zone managing Rangers," said Walter Smith. "If you win it is taken for granted, but if you lose it is a full-blown crisis."

In two years at Rangers Advocaat has won two championships, two Scottish Cups and one League Cup. It is a swag of baubles that has quickly been forgotten. From Sept 27 to Oct 30 Rangers contrived to win only once in seven matches, losing to Galatasaray and Sturm Graz, and also faltering against St Johnstone and Kilmarnock. On Saturday they recovered some of their venom with a 7-1 hammering of St Mirren but the result, in a sense, was irrelevant. Having taken the group by the jugular at first, tonight Rangers cannot help being nervous.

Not since Advocaat had a tiff with Ruud Gullit on the eve of the 1994 World Cup has the coach been in such dire straits. Gullit lost that battle, walking out of the Dutch camp in a huff, but Advocaat hardly fared better, losing his job six months later. He is, though, a gifted and scheming coach whose bullish presence and strong face give him an authority around footballers.

"I've worked with Dick a lot in Uefa circles and he's got something many coaches would love to have," says the former Scotland manager Andy Roxburgh. "It's that look in the eye which says to a player, 'I'm the boss. Don't you mess with me, pal'."

Experience and authority notwithstanding, the man they call the Little General in the Netherlands is feeling the strain. As an institution, Rangers are pining to have their huge potential fulfilled in Europe, and it has fallen to Advocaat to take the heat from the media and supporters; in Glasgow these two are not always distinguishable.

For the first time in 30 months Advocaat looked pale and drawn last week. A naturally genial, humorous and self-deprecating man, he lost his cool with reporters when asked if failure tonight might lead to his dismissal.

"I am sick of being asked this question by the media; it is absolutely out of order," he barked. "In most of my time with Rangers we have won, won, won but now in a bad period I am being asked this and I find it wrong. I have won five out of six trophies with this club and we have got better in Europe every year. If I had not won here then you could ask me this question. Right now I am sick hearing it."

It does defy reason that Advocaat can become a bad operator overnight. More likely is that he simply has not been able to live with a sequence of injuries to his players.

Stefan Klos, Craig Moore, Jorg Albertz, Claudio Reyna, Giovanni van Bronckhorst and Michael Mols - not peripheral figures - have all been indisposed. Van Bronckhorst and Mols are arguably Rangers' two most gifted players, and yesterday it emerged that Van Bronckhorst will certainly miss tonight's match and Mols remains doubtful. Wearing away at Advocaat's conviction even more was the news that Ronald de Boer, from whom Rangers require a big performance, is still troubled with a knee strain. And in defence they will be without the suspended Bert Konterman.

"We will miss Van Bronckhorst; he needs to go back to Holland for further treatment," Advocaat said. "As for Mols, he remains a doubt but I still hope he will make it. Everyone knows what he gives to Rangers. He makes other players play well and brings people into games. I hope we can have his influence."

The match should be wide open and racked with nerves. Like Rangers, Monaco are guaranteed to go through if they win tonight, even though they are currently bottom of the group.

To add to the drama, Monaco were unable to take off from Nice yesterday morning because of storms along the Cote d'Azur. Claude Puel's side thus missed their scheduled evening training session at Ibrox. That might seem a minor break amid a period of stress for one Dutchman at Ibrox. Advocaat tonight needs the intervention of the gods.

webTitle: Champions League: Shakhtar Donetsk v Arsenal preview

fields.headline: Wenger's men battling against bed bugs and big freeze
fields.trailText:
Shakhtar Donetsk v Arsenal
With nothing to play for in the group, a midweek trip to a freezing and inhospitable corner of the Ukraine is trip that Arsenal could have done without.
fields.body:
It was not without good reason that Arsenal arrived in the mining region of south-east Ukraine yesterday with more baggage than even Terry Venables is said to carry around with him.

Arsenal have hauled not just extra clothing to this freezing town near the Russian border but food, water, bed linen, towels and toilet paper. Bed bugs are said to be rife.

It is safe to assume Arsène Wenger's players will be denied such Ukrainian delicacies as oseledsi (pickled fish) and holubtsi (cabbage rolls). Donetsk, once named Stalino and twinned with Sheffield, is clearly not on Wenger's list of holiday destinations.

"It is part of Ukraine, which is not yet equipped to host people who are used to western commodities," he said. "From what we have seen the hotels are not what we are used to."

Little wonder that Arsenal's players were not keen on the 3,500-mile round trip for tonight's match with Shakhtar when they were already certain group winners. "They do it because it is their job," said Wenger. "It's not that they don't want to play. If we played the same game at Luton everyone would want to play."

No one suddenly claimed to share Dennis Bergkamp's fear of flying but Wenger said seven first-team regulars had been left behind with the Dutchman because of injury or suspension, among them Tony Adams and Patrick Vieira.

Even so the team will be stronger than many expected, which must delight the 50 or so Arsenal fans who have independently bought £5 tickets for the game. The familiar faces will be joined by the 19-year-old goalkeeper Stuart Taylor, making his second start, and Matthew Upson, on his way back from knee trouble.

"I felt we didn't play much better [at Middlesbrough] after I rested players [in the Worthington Cup]," said Wenger, who confirmed he would not discuss a new contract until the transfer regulations were settled. "Players like Wiltord, Kanu and Vivas need matches and I also feel a responsibility to Donetsk and Sparta Prague [who are fighting for third spot and a Uefa Cup place]." Sylvain Wiltord and Arsenal last night played down a French report that the £13m signing is unhappy because he has started only five games since arriving in early season.

The travelling players were certainly not gambling thousands. After the revelations that big-money betting was damagingly rife in Kevin Keegan's England squad, Wenger made his position clear.

"When cards is played for nearly nothing it is great," he said, though he stressed he felt he could not join in. "But when the purpose is big money you have to forbid it because it spoils your mind."

But he added: "People say the English problem is that the players gamble too much, but I'm really suspicious of that. The basic thing is technique."

Arsenal (probable; 4-3-1-2): Taylor; Dixon, Keown, Upson, Cole; Vivas, Parlour, Lauren; Kanu; Wiltord, Henry.

"I felt we didn't play much better [at Middlesbrough] after I rested players [in the Worthington Cup]," said Wenger, who confirmed he would not discuss a new contract until the transfer regulations were settled. "Players like Wiltord, Kanu and Vivas need matches and I also feel a responsibility to Donetsk and Sparta Prague [who are fighting for third spot and a Uefa Cup place]." Sylvain Wiltord and Arsenal last night played down a French report that the £13m signing is unhappy because he has started only five games since arriving in early season. "When cards is played for nearly nothing it is great," he said, though he stressed he felt he could not join in. "But when the purpose is big money you have to forbid it because it spoils your mind." But he added: "People say the English problem is that the players gamble too much, but I'm really suspicious of that. The basic thing is technique." webTitle: Carr pay talks are 'make or break'

fields.headline: Carr pay talks are 'make or break'
fields.trailText: Stephen Carr, Tottenham's exciting full-back, has warned the club that unless they increase his salary in line with other first-team players, he could leave.
fields.body:
Stephen Carr, Tottenham's exciting full-back, has warned the club that unless they increase his salary in line with other first-team players, he could leave.

The Republic of Ireland international, who was voted Spurs player of the year in all polls last season, will have what he describes as a "make or break" meeting with Tottenham's director of football David Pleat on Thursday. He insists that "unless there's a dramatic improvement in their offer, an agreement will be unreachable".

Spurs can ill-afford to let that happen. Their captain Sol Campbell is almost certain to quit the club when his contract runs out at the end of the season because, it is understood, he feels that Tottenham are not ambitious enough. That feeling is shared by many supporters and will only grow if Carr is allowed to leave.

Such a situation would pile even more pressure on the chairman Sir Alan Sugar, who has been accused of refusing to pay the sort of top wages that would attract the very best players to the club.

Carr has 3 years left on his contract which is worth £4,000 a week but is currently in talks over a new deal. "The facts are actually quite simple," he said. "I came to this club as a 15-year-old so they got me for nothing. All I'm asking for is financial parity with other first-teamers, but the club seem to feel that as I have another 3 years on my contract there isn't a problem.

"I love playing for Spurs and would gladly stay, but they have to show me a little respect. I know the fans appreciate me working my socks off every Saturday, but it seems that the club haven't been prepared to properly reward me for this.

"Thursday's meeting is make-or-break time. The last time we met to discuss a new contract, what they offered me was nowhere near what I'd expect from them. Unless there's a dramatic improvement, an agreement will be unreachable. The more they stick to their guns, the more it seems to me like they don't care whether I'm at the club or not, and if that's the case then why am I in the first team every week?"

Charlton yesterday revealed their successful promotion campaign lost them almost £3m compared to a net profit of more than £1m when they were relegated from the Premiership the previous season.

The 12 months to June 30 2000 produced a net loss of £2.8m before tax on turnover of £11.7m - compared to a net profit of £1.2m on turnover of £16.3m the previous financial year. The chairman Richard Murray said: "We took a carefully calculated financial risk by maintaining and then improving the first-team squad in order to gain promotion."

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Beginning of the end

fields.headline: Beginning of the end
fields.standfirst: Bill Clinton's eight years in office have been a rollercoaster ride of scandal and comeback, disaster and triumph.  Jonathan Freedland, who spent much of that time following the president, salutes a political genius with the common touch
fields.trailText: Bill Clinton's eight years in office have been a rollercoaster ride of scandal and comeback, disaster and triumph. Jonathan Freedland, who spent much of that time following the president, salutes a political genius with the common touch
fields.body:
Today America will begin to say farewell. It will be a long goodbye, one that fits the outsized character of the man. For the United States has three months to let go of a leader who has, by turns, enthralled, appalled and seduced them for eight compelling years. Bill Clinton won't officially become the ex-president till a minute past noon on January 20 2001, but by late tonight he will be yesterday's man. He will lose his throne, either to his appointed heir or to the son of the king he slayed to get there. One of them will be the president-elect and, in a heartbeat, Clinton will slip from emblem of America's present to holdover from America's past.

His fellow Americans will miss him - more, perhaps, than they realise. They'll miss the two terms of peace and record prosperity, of course, but they might even miss the psychodrama: an eight-year rollercoaster ride so turbulent that those who followed it become queasy at the recollection. They'll miss the daily triumphs and disasters of a character of Shakespearean complexity, a president who stirred in the American people passions of love and hatred unseen since the days of John F Kennedy and Richard Nixon - and almost never aroused by a single man. Above all, they will miss his signature feature, one which may well have redefined the presidency itself: an almost eerie gift for empathy.

I will miss him, too. For the years of Clinton's American journey matched my own. I first came to live and work in the country in 1992, just as he exploded on to the national scene. I watched him run for president, and stayed to see him do the job. From then on, and for several years, I either watched, read or wrote about Clinton nearly every day. Just as future TV documentary makers keen to evoke the 1990s will flash up an image of the president, I suspect that, when I look back on my late 20s or early 30s, I will do the same. And tonight that era will come to a close.

The memories come so fast that it's not easy to separate them. That 1992 election alone was so chock-full of scandal and turnarounds, such a vintage campaign, that it's hard to forget any of it - whether it was Gennifer with a G, the Vietnam draft-dodging letter, written by Clinton while a student at Oxford, or Hillary on 60 Minutes insisting she had been no Tammy Wynette standing by her man, and that if you didn't like her husband, then, "Heck, don't vote for him."

It was a crazy year, but it was that Clinton gift for empathy which saw him through. I had heard about it before - Republicans had already ridiculed the Arkansas governor's tendency to begin sentences with "I feel" rather than "I think", a habit that reached its apotheosis in the legendary "I feel your pain." But there was no substitute for seeing it in action.

Of course there were the moments widely witnessed, such as those few seconds during one of the televised debates, when the candidates were asked how the recession had affected them personally. Clinton turned the query around, asking the questioner how she had suffered. Meanwhile, his opponent, George Bush Snr, was caught on camera checking his watch.

But there were also the tiny episodes, too small to be reported in their own right, which offered a glimpse of Clinton's sheer talent for people. It's perhaps hard, after this year's lacklustre contest, to imagine the excitement Clinton generated that autumn. "The failed governor of a small southern state," the Republicans had called him. But the voters didn't see it that way. I remember two moments from a Clinton-Gore bus tour through the American heartland. It was a swing through southern Georgia and the buzz was palpable. People didn't just attend rallies, they lined the highways in crowds to catch a glimpse of the man who would be president. Some held banners urging the young governor with the gargantuan appetite (he can eat a whole apple in a single bite) to stop awhile and sample the local peaches or peanuts - and he always did.

His aides would get enraged, every stop delaying the tour by a few more crucial minutes. By the end of a campaign day, Clinton would be running four or five hours late, but it didn't matter. In the town square at Valdosta a crowd that had gathered for a 9pm rally waited till 2am. Under floodlights on that September night, they cheered themselves hoarse.

Earlier that day, we'd been in a small town called Tifton. Clinton had delivered the usual stump speech, his throat sore, when it began to pour with rain. The reporters ran for cover, inside a makeshift press room where there was the usual supply of chicken drumsticks and Diet Coke. Eventually an Israeli journalist tapped me on the shoulder. "Come outside," he said. "Look at this."

The candidate was still out there, shaking the hands of fewer than a dozen elderly voters who had stayed out in the rain. He was talking to each one - not just a "Hi, how are you," but a proper conversation - as the rain streamed down his face and theirs. His aides were urging him to hurry out, desperate to whisk him on to the bus and into a new shirt. This was not a pose to show how much he cared about ordinary people: there was not a single camera to record it. Besides me and the Israeli, no one saw it. But Clinton did it all the same.

Who knows why? Maybe the legend was right: maybe Clinton believed that so long as he met every single voter in America, they would all vote for him. Maybe his childhood (widowed mother, alcoholic stepfather) had left him with a near-addictive need for human contact, affection and adulation. Maybe he just cared.

Either way, it worked and worked. The crowds got bigger, his voice got hoarser and the empathy gift won that election. I returned to London determined to get work in America that would let me see the next chapter of the story: how Clinton the candidate would become Clinton the president.

The transition was not easy. A dozen books have recounted the political errors of those first months. Day one saw a promise to let gays into the military, a move which only confirmed the brass's worst suspicions about the new, draft-dodging commander-in-chief. Later Hillary Clinton took control of healthcare reform - a move that would bring the administration's greatest defeat. The first lady presented Congress with an almost comically complicated blueprint for a new system: expressed as a diagram, it looked like a circuit-board for the space shuttle. The fact that the plan had been hatched by a taskforce of wonks meeting with Hillary in secret added to its Soviet-era aura. By 1994 the plan was dead, and the Clinton administration badly wounded.

Things were no easier for the president himself. The Washington establishment was not sure what to make of this brash southern newcomer. They were both excited by and disdainful of him. They sniffed at the Arkansans who piled into town, supporting their beloved Razorbacks football team with the uncouth chant "Oooo pig soo-eeee!" For the Washington elite, Clinton and his friends were hicks, plain and simple.

The greybeards also disdained his way of doing business. They heard that the president would have long "bull sessions" more akin to the college seminar room than the Oval Office. They saw the pizza delivery bikes skidding up to 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue, as the young, novice staff worked through the night. While Bush had been a grown-up, Clinton's White House seemed to lack adult supervision.

The word of the hour back then was "unpresidential". The Washington snobs disliked Clinton's habit of answering reporters' questions while still out of breath, pale thighs wobbling. They winced when he answered an MTV inquiry about his taste in underwear: "Boxers or briefs?"

What the scolds did not realise was that all this "unpresidential" behaviour was connected to the president's greatest strength: his common touch. He was comfortable with people. So when a little girl, invited to the Oval Office to take part in a candle-lighting ceremony to mark the Jewish festival of Chanukah, yelped as her hair caught fire, guess who put out the flames and calmed her nerves? Not an aide, but the prez himself.

Clinton was like that Star Trek character, the empath, who can psychically read the emotions of those before him; he had a mind-reader's ability to see into the hearts of any individual or group he faced.

I saw the trick at work in Baltimore, when the president was out selling his healthcare package. He was addressing an outdoor crowd of thousands of hospital staff. I was standing among a group of nurses, who began chatting and whispering. Their minds were wandering. Somehow, from faraway, Clinton sensed it. He suddenly declared that his plan really mattered, that it would affect all of them, nurses especially - and that they all had to listen up. The women around me hushed.

The gift did not save him from the failure of the healthcare programme, a defeat that was endorsed by 1994's mid-term elections, which the Republicans won by a landslide. Overnight Newt Gingrich became the hottest politician in America, cheerily explaining that he would be prime minister to Clinton's now largely ceremonial president. Soon Clinton was forced to tell a press conference why he and his office were still "relevant".

But the mood changed. On April 19 1995 a right-wing extremist detonated a bomb at a government building in Oklahoma City, leaving 168 dead. Suddenly the anti-government bile of Gingrich's revolutionaries left a much harsher taste in the mouth: America had seen where such talk could lead.

Clinton stepped forward as the calmer voice, leading the Oklahoma families in mourning. Perhaps for the first time, he looked presidential - a father of the nation at a moment of crisis. Just then, America needed a leader who would feel their pain.

In fact, though no official would ever say it out loud, mourning worked well for Clinton: he gave good funeral. He knew how to touch just the right nerve. I remember a ceremony at Arlington National Cemetery, dedicating a memorial to those who had died in the Lockerbie bombing. He spoke well, as always, but it was afterwards that he came into his own. A huddle of relatives gathered around him. He spoke to each of them, but then he extended his big hands to reach the ones who had not pressed forward, the ones too shy to approach the president themselves. He encouraged them and beckoned them closer, his eyes finding the hesitant widow or retiring father who was holding back. Again, I looked around: no cameras. The TV crews had already got their pictures; Clinton was not doing it for appearances' sake. He stayed there a full hour over schedule, maddening his handlers and listening to the stories of bereaved loved ones - and not a word was ever written about it.

This talent or knack or psychosis - whatever it was, it secured Clinton's position as president. Groups who had once been suspicious began to like and eventually adore him.

Take black Americans. In 1992 they had big doubts about Clinton. He was a white politician from the deep south, a Democrat who had signalled his "centrist" credentials by attacking black rapper Sister Souljah and by breaking off from the campaign to return to his home state - to order the execution of a retarded black man convicted of murder.

Yet within a few years Clinton would be hailed by Toni Morrison, the African-American Nobel laureate, as "our first black president" and by the rapper Ice-T as "a brother". What had changed? Clinton had saved affirmative action from the Republican axe, but he'd also signed a welfare reform bill which hit black families hard. No, it wasn't policy which sealed the bond between Clinton and black America. It was a more subtle connection. The president displayed a comfort with black audiences that was unheard of among white politicians. He could deliver an impromptu speech-cum-sermon from the pulpit of a black church that had civil rights activists admitting they had heard nothing so inspiring since the days of Martin Luther King. The result is a white president who enjoys 95% approval ratings among African-Americans to this very day.

Jewish voters tell a similar story. They were wary of a southern baptist Democrat in 1992: they feared he might be another Jimmy Carter, too sympathetic to the Palestinians. But Clinton reassured them, using his secret weapon: emotional intelligence. It was his instinct and body language that led to that 1993 handshake on the White House lawn between the PLO's Yasser Arafat and Israel's Yitzhak Rabin. And when Rabin was assassinated two years later, it was Clinton who knew how to massage Israel's wounded spirit. He spoke to them, via TV, in their own language, addressing the dead Rabin with the words "Shalom chaver" - goodbye friend. The phrase had not existed in Hebrew before then; now it's common Israeli parlance. And so, in 1996, Jewish Americans turned out - alongside blacks and women and Hispanics and trade unions and every other group who felt understood by Clinton - to give him four more years.

I took that as my cue to head back to Britain. I reckoned we'd seen the best of Clinton. The second term would be more of the same, only less so. And for the first year, 1997, I seemed to be vindicated: the economy prospered on auto-pilot and Clinton barely had to break a sweat. But in the first weeks of 1998 the sky fell in. The allegations of a dress-staining affair with a White House intern, Monica Lewinsky, the finger-wagging denial, the talk of perjury and impeachment - it all came so fast. The Washington punditocracy predicted that the Arkansas hick would be sent back to Little Rock by the end of the week. But they forgot who they were dealing with. Clinton was not just the Comeback Kid, the Houdini who had survived a thousand scrapes. He was also the empath-in-chief, and now he got the return on his investment: the American people empathised back.

They had already forgiven or ignored the waves of scandal that had broken with every season of the first term: Whitewater, Travelgate, Filegate and all the other gates never really swung. The American people apparently felt the same way about the president as a former Arkansas state senator I once interviewed. He had worked with the then governor throughout the 1980s and had little sympathy for him politically. But he was adamant: "Bill Clinton doesn't give duck crap about money." Americans could see that for themselves: they had a president who had never owned his own house (he had lived in the Arkansas governor's mansion since he was 32, moving from there directly to the White House). He may have been a shameless hustler after votes, but few voters believed Clinton was ever in the business of lining his own pockets. That's why all the stuff about Whitewater never stuck.

Zippergate was different: Clinton may not have lusted after cash, but Americans knew he lusted after flesh. They knew, too, that he had an indisciplined, selfish, self-indulgent streak. They knew he could be reckless and self-destructive, taking a risk he must have known could have ended his presidency.

But here's where empathy became a two-way street. Despite a year-long hammering from the Republicans, and a press united in its disgust for the president's actions, the public stood by him. Americans told pollsters they hated what Clinton had done but, from the first revelations in January 1998 to the senate trial a year later, they remained consistent, approving his performance as president and insisting that he should not be removed from office.

They understood him, just as he had understood them. He had always seemed to cut them a little slack, and now they returned the compliment. In the autumn of 1998 they watched the tapes of a beleaguered president assaulted by excruciatingly personal questions from Kenneth Starr's prosecutors - grainy footage with the visual grammar of a hostage video - and they sided with him. Just like Hillary, they stood by their man.

Once, when speaking about his faith, Clinton described the God he believed in as "the God of second chances" - and he let out a little smile. That was the Clinton of early 1999: a lucky man, blessed with forgiveness.

In the end, he was less Houdini than Rasputin. The Republicans tried and tried to kill him, but they failed, destroying themselves in the attempt. Where are his enemies now? Gingrich was forced out of the Speaker's chair after the impeachment debacle, so was his successor. The rest of the president's persecutors in the House are in tight congressional races today, desperate just to hold on to their seats.

And as for Clinton, this is his last day in total command. I can look back now on the last eight years and admit that we, those of us who covered him, were spoiled. We saw a president with towering political skills and a serious intellect - a man who could rattle off the fine-print detail of any policy programme anywhere in America and discuss the domestic politics of most countries in the world, a leader who would think nothing of calling up the great academics and writers of the day, often in the small hours, for a late-night, unarranged té-te-à-téte.

And there was that gift for people. I admit it, it spoiled me - it even skewed my judgment. I came back from America to cover Britain's 1997 election, and was soon whispering to friends my anxiety that Tony Blair's success was far from assured: he got such little enthusiasm from the crowds. I'd got used to winning candidates getting a Clinton-sized response. Now I can see that I had witnessed a once-in-a-lifetime phenomenon. Like someone who heard Sinatra sing in the 1950s or watched John McEnroe play tennis in the 1980s, I had seen a maestro at the height of his powers. Clinton was the Pele of politics, and we might wait half a century to see his like again.

Today America is choosing between two half-Clintons. They can have a version of his smarts, in Al Gore, or a version of his warmth, in George W Bush. Clinton wants the voters to choose Gore, of course, to protect his legacy. But if America picks Bush, that will be a kind of compliment, too. For it will prove that an ability to connect, which Bush has and Gore does not, is now an indispensable part of the job - thanks to Clinton, the king of empathy.

Smarts or warmth, one or the other is on offer today. Voters who want both will just have to wait. Or they can take one last look at the man from Hope - and remember.

He suddenly declared that his plan really mattered, that it would affect all of them, nurses especially - and that they all had to listen up. The women around me hushed. The gift did not save him from the failure of the healthcare programme, a defeat that was endorsed by 1994's mid-term elections, which the Republicans won by a landslide. Overnight Newt Gingrich became the hottest politician in America, cheerily explaining that he would be prime minister to Clinton's now largely ceremonial president. Soon Clinton was forced to tell a press conference why he and his office were still "relevant". But the mood changed. On April 19 1995 a right-wing extremist detonated a bomb at a government building in Oklahoma City, leaving 168 dead. Suddenly the anti-government bile of Gingrich's revolutionaries left a much harsher taste in the mouth: America had seen where such talk could lead. Clinton stepped forward as the calmer voice, leading the Oklahoma families in mourning. Perhaps for the first time, he looked presidential - a father of the nation at a moment of crisis. Just then, America needed a leader who would feel their pain. In fact, though no official would ever say it out loud, mourning worked well for Clinton: he gave good funeral. He knew how to touch just the right nerve. I remember a ceremony at Arlington National Cemetery, dedicating a memorial to those who had died in the Lockerbie bombing. He spoke well, as always, but it was afterwards that he came into his own. A huddle of relatives gathered around him. He spoke to each of them, but then he extended his big hands to reach the ones who had not pressed forward, the ones too shy to approach the president themselves. He encouraged them and beckoned them closer, his eyes finding the hesitant widow or retiring father who was holding back. Again, I looked around: no cameras. The TV crews had already got their pictures; Clinton was not doing it for appearances' sake. He stayed there a full hour over schedule, maddening his handlers and listening to the stories of bereaved loved ones - and not a word was ever written about it. This talent or knack or psychosis - whatever it was, it secured Clinton's position as president. Groups who had once been suspicious began to like and eventually adore him. Take black Americans. In 1992 they had big doubts about Clinton. He was a white politician from the deep south, a Democrat who had signalled his "centrist" credentials by attacking black rapper Sister Souljah and by breaking off from the campaign to return to his home state - to order the execution of a retarded black man convicted of murder. Yet within a few years Clinton would be hailed by Toni Morrison, the African-American Nobel laureate, as "our first black president" and by the rapper Ice-T as "a brother". What had changed? Clinton had saved affirmative action from the Republican axe, but he'd also signed a welfare reform bill which hit black families hard. No, it wasn't policy which sealed the bond between Clinton and black America. It was a more subtle connection. The president displayed a comfort with black audiences that was unheard of among white politicians. He could deliver an impromptu speech-cum-sermon from the pulpit of a black church that had civil rights activists admitting they had heard nothing so inspiring since the days of Martin Luther King. The result is a white president who enjoys 95% approval ratings among African-Americans to this very day. Jewish voters tell a similar story. They were wary of a southern baptist Democrat in 1992: they feared he might be another Jimmy Carter, too sympathetic to the Palestinians. But Clinton reassured them, using his secret weapon: emotional intelligence. It was his instinct and body language that led to that 1993 handshake on the White House lawn between the PLO's Yasser Arafat and Israel's Yitzhak Rabin. And when Rabin was assassinated two years later, it was Clinton who knew how to massage Israel's wounded spirit. He spoke to them, via TV, in their own language, addressing the dead Rabin with the words "Shalom chaver" - goodbye friend. The phrase had not existed in Hebrew before then; now it's common Israeli parlance. And so, in 1996, Jewish Americans turned out - alongside blacks and women and Hispanics and trade unions and every other group who felt understood by Clinton - to give him four more years. I took that as my cue to head back to Britain. I reckoned we'd seen the best of Clinton. The second term would be more of the same, only less so. And for the first year, 1997, I seemed to be vindicated: the economy prospered on auto-pilot and Clinton barely had to break a sweat. But in the first weeks of 1998 the sky fell in. The allegations of a dress-staining affair with a White House intern, Monica Lewinsky, the finger-wagging denial, the talk of perjury and impeachment - it all came so fast. The Washington punditocracy predicted that the Arkansas hick would be sent back to Little Rock by the end of the week. But they forgot who they were dealing with. Clinton was not just the Comeback Kid, the Houdini who had survived a thousand scrapes. He was also the empath-in-chief, and now he got the return on his investment: the American people empathised back. They had already forgiven or ignored the waves of scandal that had broken with every season of the first term: Whitewater, Travelgate, Filegate and all the other gates never really swung. The American people apparently felt the same way about the president as a former Arkansas state senator I once interviewed. He had worked with the then governor throughout the 1980s and had little sympathy for him politically. But he was adamant: "Bill Clinton doesn't give duck crap about money." Americans could see that for themselves: they had a president who had never owned his own house (he had lived in the Arkansas governor's mansion since he was 32, moving from there directly to the White House). He may have been a shameless hustler after votes, but few voters believed Clinton was ever in the business of lining his own pockets. That's why all the stuff about Whitewater never stuck. Zippergate was different: Clinton may not have lusted after cash, but Americans knew he lusted after flesh. They knew, too, that he had an indisciplined, selfish, self-indulgent streak. They knew he could be reckless and self-destructive, taking a risk he must have known could have ended his presidency. But here's where empathy became a two-way street. Despite a year-long hammering from the Republicans, and a press united in its disgust for the president's actions, the public stood by him. Americans told pollsters they hated what Clinton had done but, from the first revelations in January 1998 to the senate trial a year later, they remained consistent, approving his performance as president and insisting that he should not be removed from office. They understood him, just as he had understood them. He had always seemed to cut them a little slack, and now they returned the compliment. In the autumn of 1998 they watched the tapes of a beleaguered president assaulted by excruciatingly personal questions from Kenneth Starr's prosecutors - grainy footage with the visual grammar of a hostage video - and they sided with him. Just like Hillary, they stood by their man. Once, when speaking about his faith, Clinton described the God he believed in as "the God of second chances" - and he let out a little smile. That was the Clinton of early 1999: a lucky man, blessed with forgiveness. In the end, he was less Houdini than Rasputin. The Republicans tried and tried to kill him, but they failed, destroying themselves in the attempt. Where are his enemies now? Gingrich was forced out of the Speaker's chair after the impeachment debacle, so was his successor. The rest of the president's persecutors in the House are in tight congressional races today, desperate just to hold on to their seats. And as for Clinton, this is his last day in total command. I can look back now on the last eight years and admit that we, those of us who covered him, were spoiled. We saw a president with towering political skills and a serious intellect - a man who could rattle off the fine-print detail of any policy programme anywhere in America and discuss the domestic politics of most countries in the world, a leader who would think nothing of calling up the great academics and writers of the day, often in the small hours, for a late-night, unarranged té-te-à-téte. And there was that gift for people. I admit it, it spoiled me - it even skewed my judgment. I came back from America to cover Britain's 1997 election, and was soon whispering to friends my anxiety that Tony Blair's success was far from assured: he got such little enthusiasm from the crowds. I'd got used to winning candidates getting a Clinton-sized response. Now I can see that I had witnessed a once-in-a-lifetime phenomenon. Like someone who heard Sinatra sing in the 1950s or watched John McEnroe play tennis in the 1980s, I had seen a maestro at the height of his powers. Clinton was the Pele of politics, and we might wait half a century to see his like again. Today America is choosing between two half-Clintons. They can have a version of his smarts, in Al Gore, or a version of his warmth, in George W Bush. Clinton wants the voters to choose Gore, of course, to protect his legacy. But if America picks Bush, that will be a kind of compliment, too. For it will prove that an ability to connect, which Bush has and Gore does not, is now an indispensable part of the job - thanks to Clinton, the king of empathy. Smarts or warmth, one or the other is on offer today. Voters who want both will just have to wait. Or they can take one last look at the man from Hope - and remember.
