fields.bodyText: How do you stop teenagers becoming mums and dads? One way may be to have them play a brisk game of "fruit salad". "Oranges!" shouts Andy of the drama group Theatre in Education, and half the eager year 9 pupils of Waverley School for Girls dash for chairs. The one left standing has to show off a bit of knowledge to her classmates: "A man has no rights in abortion decisions." Correct. So Andy shouts: "Lemons!" "You should be 16 before you get pregnant," says the last lemon out. An opinion rather than a fact, as Andy notes. But he underlines that 16 is the legal age of consent. "Fruit salad!" he bellows. Now the oranges and lemons scurried altogether, and the girl left chair-less offers: "If you're having sex you ought to use a protective ... thingummybob. Erm, aah, uh ... condom." Or maybe one of the dozen other kinds of thingummybob there are. Or maybe don't "have sex" in the first place. Or maybe not that kind of sex. What an awful lot there is to learn. Fruit Salad is just one of the novel devices deployed in the Great British Battle Against Teenage Pregnancy, a battle which the government has pledged to win. The December edition of Sugar magazine, already on the news stands, contains the first example of the "straight-talking" Department of Health advertising campaign designed to furnish young people with proper fax 'n' info about having a sex life: contraception, disease, peer pressure, relationships, becoming a parent too soon. Bliss and J-17 will shortly follow suit, as will a number of boys' interest magazines including Shoot, Match, and some computer titles. The ad in Sugar shows an embarrassed girl arrowed with the dread word "virgin". The ad reassures her that although her peers might be talking about sex as if they were experts, the average ages of first vaginal intercourse is 17 for girls and 16 for boys. This ad seems to have provided the excuse for recent crass misreporting of the entire exercise as some kind of nanny state jihad for virginity. In truth, it simply marks the start of a fairly progressive initiative supported by a range of sexual advice agencies catering to the young. It will carry on into February and possibly beyond. But what about the state of sex education in schools, the place where a deeper understanding may be instilled, and also the place where most parents seem to prefer their children to receive it (anywhere, rather than in their own homes)? Teachers are now absorbing the DfEE's new guidance on sex and relationships education, produced to complement the National Curriculum's Personal, Social and Health Education framework and to address the Social Exclusion Unit's findings on teenage pregnancy. Contributors to the consultation process such as Anne Weyman, chief executive of the Family Planning Association, believe the final document has retained a core of good sense, despite becoming entangled in horse-trading in the House of Lords over the government's proposed repeal of Section 28. Political fingerprints are clearly visible. Controversial areas, such as what teaching materials - books, videos, models and so - should be used are notable for the use of wishywashy words like "inappropriate", and one clause insists, impeccably non-specifically, that "there should be no direct promotion of sexual orientation." However, there is also a clear requirement that homophobic bullying should be dealt with and an explicit recognition that "stable relationships" other than married ones can be effective for the bringing-up of children. Clearer signs of progress lie in the stress on helping young people respect themselves and each other, the development of social skills, knowledge and understanding. But big worries still remain: is the guidance all it should be? Are teachers confident and skilled in the right ways to deliver what the guidance does allow? And, most importantly, does it licence schools to give young people the wisdom about sex, sexuality and sexual relations that they desperately need and so urgently desire? Weyman is afraid that a golden opportunity has in some respects been badly missed. "We're not doing anything like enough for primary children - they get nothing until they're 10 or 11. They need to learn about puberty before it starts happening to them, and these days that can be when they are nine or younger. "And it's as if we believe children aren't aware of sex. It seems so naive to carry on as if they haven't already picked up lots of information by the time they're 10 - much of it wrong." Then there are questions about the importance given to sex and relationships education in primary and secondary schools alike. "We've known for 10 years that there's a link between the quality of a child's social education and his academic progress," Weyman says. "But we don't seem to have done a great deal about it." In secondary schools sex and relationships are tackled as part of personal, social and health education, confined to just one teaching period per week. Teachers are often nervous of the topic and many are not practised at the less didactic teaching style it demands. "If the government gave it as much support to this as it has to literacy and numeracy," Weyman says, "we might be able to make real progress." This is the kind of gap that such groups as Theatre in Education may help to fill. Andy and his colleagues have been working with 15 girls at Waverley and, separately, with a smaller number of boys from Holloway school in Islington, on the opposite side of town. After warming up with Fruit Salad, the pupils role-play about boyfriends and girlfriends and are developing 30-minute scripts to perform to the other school. The aim is to get youngsters thinking more profoundly about issues surrounding sex and pregnancy, not simply improving their knowledge of the "facts of life". It obviously helps the children engage with a ticklish subject - the enthusiasm of the Waverley girls was palpable - but in the process of demonstrating the good things it can achieve, the team's work also highlighted how far there is to go. It was striking how conventional the girls were - or how grimly realistic. If one got pregnant and had a baby, what would be the responsibility of the father? "To get a job," said one. "To earn the food," said another. "Not to run away when the going gets tough," said a third. These girls were equally aware, though, that sex and relationships in real life abound with transgressions, eagerly offering anecdotes about complicated stepfamilies and how they had heard that Queen Victoria did it with her cousin. The same mixture of stout conformity and darker knowledge also informed their answers when asked why they thought people had sex in the first place. "To make babies." "To feel big: boys mostly, but also girls." "To get love - maybe they have not been loved at home." Here was "sex" seen as synonymous only with intercourse, as a regrettable expression of adolescent ego and - most affectingly - as betraying a need to be needed. These fragments show with painful clarity the fragility of adolescent identities and how closely these are bound up with - and inhibited by - themes of sex and destiny. School is the place where they struggle most painfully to make sense of those themes. It is in school that boys learn how to police and punish "deviant" masculinities with the one word "queer", in school that girls fully grasp how boys long for and yet despise them, in school that Section 28 inhibits understanding. webTitle: Ryman teams up with Bol.com

fields.headline: Ryman links up with Bol.com
fields.trailText: 3.30pm: High street stationery retailer Ryman has found its perfect online match - with Bertelsmann's shopping service Bol.com, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
High street stationery retailer Ryman has found its perfect online match - a long-term deal with Bertelsmann's shopping service Bol.com.

The partnership is part of Bol's initiative to hook into high street commerce, a move it initiated at the end of September when it tied up with book wholesalers Bertrams to take Britain's 3,000-plus independent book shops online.

The Ryman's deal will enable Bol to market itself in all the stationery retailer's 90 high street stores.

Plans under consideration include window posters and Bol shelf branding, in addition to a Bol ad being given the whole back page of Ryman's Christmas catalogue, of which 750,000 copies have been printed.

A co-branded website has been created, linking from bol.com, as part of the deal. Commission of around 7% is to be paid for any sales that are generated by referrals from either partner's site. It is thought the deal may lead to Bol helping Ryman's to upgrade its clunky website, although nothing has been decided at this stage.

Malcolm Cooke, group marketing director at Ryman said: "Ryman has been growing at over 10% like for like over the past few years and this link with Bol should help continue to keep us well ahead of our competition."

webTitle: Airey starts reshuffle at Channel 5

fields.headline: Airey kicks off Channel 5 shake-up
fields.trailText: 3.15pm: New Channel 5 chief executive Dawn Airey has made her first executive changes, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
New Channel 5 chief executive Dawn Airey has made her first executive changes promoting Michael Attwell and Chris Shaw into senior programming roles.

Ms Airey, who became chief executive 10 days ago when David Elstein was ousted by Channel 5 shareholders RTL and United News & Media, is retaining her role as director of programmes.

But Mr Attwell, controller of features and arts, and Mr Shaw, controller of news, current affairs and documentaries, will take on additional responsibilities as senior programme controllers.

Mr Attwell, who has been responsible for some of Channel 5's most controversial shows, including Sex and Shopping, will oversee programme controllers responsible for drama, entertainment, children's and religion, as well as his own area.

Mr Shaw, who was launch editor of Channel 5's acclaimed 5 News bulletin before joining the station, will now also have the controllers of sport, special events and interactivity reporting in to him.

Ashley Hill, controller of programming planning, has also been promoted, to director of broadcasting. Mr Hill will take on responsibility for the Channel 5 schedule budget, departmental administration and presentation.

Ms Airey said: "Obviously taking on the chief executive duties since David Elstein's departure has meant that some streamlining of the programming department reporting structure is necessary, though I will continue to have direct creative contact with all controllers."

webTitle: Ad guru to pocket millions in takeover windfall

fields.headline: Ad guru to pocket millions in takeover windfall
fields.standfirst: Nov 6: Leagas Delaney sold to Envoy
fields.trailText:
12pm: Advertising guru Tim Delaney could net up to £18m following the £59m takeover of Leagas Delaney by Canada's Envoy Communications, reports Jade Garrett.
Nov 6: Leagas Delaney sold to Envoy
fields.body:
Advertising guru Tim Delaney could net more than £18m following the £59m takeover of his agency by Canada's Envoy Communications.

Mr Delaney is considered one of British advertising's creative geniuses and the mastermind behind Adidas, Barclays campaigns and the recent launch of Isabella Rossellini's cosmetics range.

The chairman and creative director of Leagas Delaney owns a third of the company, according to accounts just filed at Companies House.

With 3,299,960 of the 9.6m shares, Mr Delaney stands to make more than any of the other eight directors of the agency.

On paper his stake is worth £18.3m, but the ultimate value of his shareholding will be influenced by complicated financial conditions attached to a management buyout two years ago.

Mr Delaney's eventual fortune will also be affected by future profits although one source close to the agency boss said: "£18m is conservative."

When it extricated itself from Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO, Leagas Delaney agreed a long-term profit related tie-in.

The company was valued at £4m at the time, but the nine directors paid just £100,000 cash to regain their independence.

Up to now the terms of the deal have remained confidential, but accounts filed on October 27 reveal that Leagas Delaney committed to handing over 2.5% of its gross profit every year to Abbott Mead Vickers to cover the remaining £3.9m.

This financial arrangement was due to expire in 2008.

Bruce Haines, Leagas Delaney group chief executive, told MediaGuardian.co.uk today that the link with AMV had been completely severed, with Envoy clearing the slate as part of the deal.

He refused to comment on the personal fortunes of the directors of the company but revealed that 33 staff in total would benefit financially.

Mr Haines is also looking forward to a windfall as a result of the takeover. He holds 2,400,050 shares in the group.

Accounts also reveal that Mr Delaney earns £400,000 a year. In 1999, his salary increased by nearly £80,000.

The other main shareholders include group media director Jerry Fielder, who holds 1,600,040 shares, and Eric McClean, group finance director, who has just over 900,000 shares.

The Envoy deal is worth a total of £59m. The down payment is approximately £25m, of which about £8.9m will be satisfied with the issue of Envoy shares valued at £3.60.

The balance of the purchase price is subject to meeting annual profit targets over a period of four years.

The deal is expected to finalised by the end of January 2001.

webTitle: America goes to polls

fields.headline: America goes to polls
fields.standfirst: Special report: US election race
fields.trailText: The polling stations have opened on the east coast of the US for today's presidential election that is still too close to call after the tightest race in 40 years.
fields.body:
The polling stations have opened on the east coast of the US for today's presidential election that is still too close to call after the tightest race in 40 years.

Exhausted by the effort, the candidates, Democrat Al Gore and Republican George W Bush, have now surrendered their fate to the voters.

Mr Bush, the governor of Texas and son of former president George Bush, is topping most of the polls, but the outcome is uncertain.

Mr Gore, who has been the US vice-president for eight years, put in a final push of campaigning in Florida, a key state to win.

The earliest results are already in from the two New Hampshire towns where votes are traditionally first posted.

In Dixville Notch, the result was Bush, 21, Gore 5, and the green candidate, Ralph Nader, 1. In nearby Hart's Location, it was Bush 17 and Gore 13, with one vote for a write-in candidate.

"It's not close here, but I believe it will be close in New Hampshire and across the country," said Stephen Barba, a Dixville Notch voter.

Mr Bush will cast his ballot in Austin, Texas, and has been making calls to west coast radio stations to urge voters to turn out. He also was calling voters in Michigan, Oregon, Florida, Iowa and Wisconsin.

After his pre-dawn campaigning in Florida, Mr Gore was voting in Carthage, Tennessee.

Voters were choosing between Mr Bush's promise to be a "uniter not a divider" and Mr Gore's assertion that he alone has the experience to "fight for you and win." A new Congress was also being decided at the polls.

Before that election day ritual in New Hampshire, the candidates had barnstormed the country one last time.

Mr Bush hit four states - Tennessee, Wisconsin, Iowa and Arkansas - that voted for Bill Clinton and Mr Gore in 1992 and 1996, but which polls suggest could go Republican.

"If people do what I think they're going to do, you're looking at the next president of the United States," the Texas governor told an audience of several hundred supporters after returning to Austin.

For his part, Mr Gore engaged in a marathon 30-hour campaigning flurry through crucial Iowa, Missouri, Michigan and Florida. In Florida, he said that the crowd of tens of thousands who greeted him in Miami's fashionable South Beach left him with "no doubt whatsoever" he'd finish the day as president-elect.

"Americans are coming together and making a very powerful decision that we are not going to allow ourselves to go back to the policies of the past," Mr Gore told the crowd. "We're going forward with the policies of the future - a bright future that includes all Americans."

A cast of stars - Glenn Close, Robert De Niro, Stevie Wonder, Billy Dee Williams, Ben Affleck - were there to boost his final campaigning.

From Miami, Mr Gore headed to a decidedly more sombre event, holding a pre-dawn meeting with nurses at a Tampa cancer centre, where he sat around a table and talked health care.

Mr Gore also was rallying workers on their way to "get out the vote" before heading home to cast his own vote at a small school in Carthage.

Behind Mr Gore and Mr Bush was the most expensive election in history - $3bn (£2bn) on presidential and congressional races, about $30 for every vote cast - but one that failed to stir much excitement.

President Bill Clinton predicted that Mr Gore will emerge victorious on the strength of the economy and a hoped-for large turnout among black people, Latin Americans, immigrants and the working poor.

"He's run a good campaign on his own," Mr Clinton said, before taking off from Washington bound for his new home in Chappaqua, New York, where he planned to vote. "Especially the last couple of weeks, I think he's really been in gear and you also see a lot of our people getting energised. I think he'll win."

In addition to replacing Mr Clinton, the people were deciding control of the house of representatives and senate, both narrowly held by Republicans.

Voters were picking all 435 members of the House, 34 senators and 11 governors and members of state legislatures.

For the first time in history, a president's wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton, is seeking election to the Senate. She faced Republican Rick Lazio in New York, nominated when prostate cancer caused the mayor of New York, Rudolph Giuliani, to abandon plans to run.

With peace and prosperity both at hand and not big issues, the fight was chiefly over how to divide the spoils of prosperity. Mr Bush proposes tax cuts and Mr Gore favours shoring up federal pensions, health care and education.

A new Congress was also being decided at the polls. Before that election day ritual in New Hampshire, the candidates had barnstormed the country one last time. Mr Bush hit four states - Tennessee, Wisconsin, Iowa and Arkansas - that voted for Bill Clinton and Mr Gore in 1992 and 1996, but which polls suggest could go Republican. "If people do what I think they're going to do, you're looking at the next president of the United States," the Texas governor told an audience of several hundred supporters after returning to Austin. For his part, Mr Gore engaged in a marathon 30-hour campaigning flurry through crucial Iowa, Missouri, Michigan and Florida. In Florida, he said that the crowd of tens of thousands who greeted him in Miami's fashionable South Beach left him with "no doubt whatsoever" he'd finish the day as president-elect. "Americans are coming together and making a very powerful decision that we are not going to allow ourselves to go back to the policies of the past," Mr Gore told the crowd. "We're going forward with the policies of the future - a bright future that includes all Americans." A cast of stars - Glenn Close, Robert De Niro, Stevie Wonder, Billy Dee Williams, Ben Affleck - were there to boost his final campaigning. From Miami, Mr Gore headed to a decidedly more sombre event, holding a pre-dawn meeting with nurses at a Tampa cancer centre, where he sat around a table and talked health care. Mr Gore also was rallying workers on their way to "get out the vote" before heading home to cast his own vote at a small school in Carthage. Behind Mr Gore and Mr Bush was the most expensive election in history - $3bn (£2bn) on presidential and congressional races, about $30 for every vote cast - but one that failed to stir much excitement. President Bill Clinton predicted that Mr Gore will emerge victorious on the strength of the economy and a hoped-for large turnout among black people, Latin Americans, immigrants and the working poor. "He's run a good campaign on his own," Mr Clinton said, before taking off from Washington bound for his new home in Chappaqua, New York, where he planned to vote. "Especially the last couple of weeks, I think he's really been in gear and you also see a lot of our people getting energised. I think he'll win." In addition to replacing Mr Clinton, the people were deciding control of the house of representatives and senate, both narrowly held by Republicans. Voters were picking all 435 members of the House, 34 senators and 11 governors and members of state legislatures. For the first time in history, a president's wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton, is seeking election to the Senate. She faced Republican Rick Lazio in New York, nominated when prostate cancer caused the mayor of New York, Rudolph Giuliani, to abandon plans to run. With peace and prosperity both at hand and not big issues, the fight was chiefly over how to divide the spoils of prosperity. Mr Bush proposes tax cuts and Mr Gore favours shoring up federal pensions, health care and education. webTitle: A tale of frenzy and a result no one can call

fields.headline: A tale of frenzy and a result no one can call
fields.standfirst: As Americans head for the polls, Derek Brown looks at the final exhortation from the US press to today's voters
fields.trailText: As Americans head for the polls, Derek Brown looks at the final exhortation from the US press to today's voters.
fields.body:
There are two universal threads running through the mass of election coverage: the frantic, frenzied nature of the campaign's final 24 hours, and the utter impossibility of predicting the outcome.

As the campaign dust finally settles and Americans set about choosing their new leaders, some of the papers are casting around for entertaining sidebar stories.

The Los Angeles Times, for example, is already looking ahead to how ex-president Clinton will be filling his time. Apparently he has no shortage of plans.

"... Clinton, while vowing not to tread on official toes - especially if his vice president, Democrat Al Gore, wins the presidency - is thinking on a scale that dwarfs [Jimmy] Carter, or even the elder statesman gambits of Richard Nixon.

"Clinton sounds like a man determined to raise more money, talk with more world leaders and generally plunge deeper into the public fray than any of his modern-day predecessors.

"From education and health care reform to bringing peace to Northern Ireland and the Middle East, Clinton envisions playing a high-profile role that will cheer his admirers and keep his enemies gnashing their teeth for years to come."

The Chicago Tribune delves into its Illinois hinterland to come up with a delicious little piece about the neighbouring hamlets of Bush and Goreville:

"With town names like these, Bush (pop. 351) and Goreville (pop. 872), might have provided a photo opportunity along the presidential campaign trail for Texas Gov George W Bush and vice president Al Gore.

"Trouble is, the towns'loyalties don' live up to their names. There are precious few Gore supporters in Goreville, and even fewer Bush supporters in Bush.

"Of course, in Bush - where a weed-choked, long-abandoned high school recalls better days - there aren't many people to begin with."

The San Francisco Chronicle, which backs Gore, presents the closing hours of the campaign as a last-minute dash for the winning tape, with both candidates desperately seeking last minute momentum.

"The airwaves were a blizzard of campaign advertising, with an advantage to Bush. From the start of his run through mid-October, the Texas governor had spent $138 million, including $56 million on radio and TV ads, according to the Campaign Study Group.

"Gore was at $94 million overall, including $41.5 million for broadcast ads."

The Miami Herald looks at another modern campaigning tool: the pre-recorded telephone message.

"Tens of thousands of such messages, recorded by candidates and their celebrity supporters, have hit answering machines across the nation.

"Some voters, like Jason Cottrell, are unimpressed: 'If I got a call from a real person, I would talk to them,' said Cottrell, who also received recordings from gun control advocate Sarah Brady for Gore and former presidential candidate John McCain for Bush. 'But a message doesn't seem right. My answering machine is sort of personal'."

The Charleston Gazette, in the 'swing' state of West Virginia, urges its readers to use their votes, and has no doubt where they should go: "A vote for vice president Al Gore may actually make a real difference in this tight election.

"Gore will need every popular vote and every electoral vote he can win in his battle against Texas Gov George W Bush. A Gore victory would mean a lot for West Virginians.

"Gore will keep the nation headed on the right track, continuing the unprecedented prosperity the United States has enjoyed for the last eight years."

The paper runs through its endorsements in the other elections, and finally exhorts: "As soon as you finish reading this newspaper, go vote. You have a chance to make a real difference. Don't blow it."

webTitle: November 6 ratings

fields.headline: Newsflash floods ITV with rising tide of viewers
fields.trailText: 2pm TV ratings: The News at Nine is turning out to be ITV's Noah's Ark, scooping up viewers as the waters rise, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The News at Nine is turning out to be ITV's Noah's Ark, scooping up viewers as the waters rise.

The network scored yet again with another ad hoc 9pm news special last night. The Trevor McDonald-fronted bulletin pulled in a bumper audience as people tuned in to catch up after another night of storms and flooding.

It is the fourth 9pm bulletin scheduled at the last minute by director of programmes David Liddiment. The gamble paid off, winning an audience of 11.1m and a 41% share.

And it left the BBC1's Ten O'Clock News trailing in its wake with an audience of just 5.5m and a 25% share.

But earlier in the day the BBC1 news bulletins undoubtedly benefited more than their ITV counterparts from the foul weather and continuing concern about petrol shortages.

The One O'Clock News took 4.3m - a whopping 53% of lunchtime viewers - and the Six O'Clock News averaged 7.4m and a 34% share.

The ITV 9pm news special led-off a post-9pm line-up that is growing stronger by the week against BBC1's revamped late evening schedule.

Who Wants to be a Millionaire? followed on from 9.10pm with 12.1m over 60 minutes. BBC1 opposition One Foot in the Grave and The Royle Family slipped to 8.1m and 7.2m, respectively, compared with 9.5m and 8.2m last Monday.

Then ITV's Frank Skinner Show pulled in 8m against the BBC1 10pm news.

BBC2 controller Jane Root may be fretting over her channel's fuddy-duddy image, but she appears to have unearthed two more factual hits, following hot on the heels of A History of Britain.

Adam Hart-Davis' investigation of Roman Britain and its modern day legacy, What the Romans Did for Us, debuted at 8.30pm on BBC2 last night with 3.7m and a 14% share.

New South American wildlife series Andes to Amazon, which features breathtaking aerial footage of the continent, followed up at 9pm with 3.1m and a 12% share.

On Channel 4 last night Tony Marchant drama Never Never's gritty subject matter - a council estate loan shark - took its toll on viewing figures.

The concluding instalment of the two-parter averaged 1.1m and a 4% share, after the previous night's opener had pulled in 2.1m and 9%.

webTitle: Portrait of fantasy writer Graham Joyce

fields.headline: Fantasy world
fields.standfirst: Graham Joyce grew up in a family where education was a closed book. Now a prize-winning novelist and creative writing lecturer, he tells Simon Midgley why he believes the art of fiction can be taught
fields.trailText: Graham Joyce grew up in a family where education was a closed book. Now a prize-winning novelist and creative writing lecturer, he tells Simon Midgley why he believes the art of fiction can be taught.
fields.body:
The old argument about whether writing can be taught or not is "nonsense", according to Graham Joyce, a 46-year-old senior lecturer in creative writing at Nottingham Trent University who has just won the British Fantasy Award for Best Novel for an extraordinary fourth time.

"It's the only art form where anybody would raise that question. With any other art form - ballet, music - of course there has to be teaching. It's the same with writing."

He prefers a spare prose style. In the mining village of Keresley near Coventry, where he grew up, anybody using words of more than two syllables was instantly suspected of being a homosexual. "Generally fantasy writers write long. I write short."

He adds: "You cannot teach inspiration or grace, but lots of craft elements can be taught. Dialogue, for instance, is something people find tricky, but there are all sorts of tips on how to make it work. It's all about editing down. Narrative structure, character development and sense of place can all be taught."

From a mining family - his dad, grandfather and brothers went down the pit - Joyce was brought up in a house with scarcely any books. After failing the 11-plus, he went to a comprehensive in Bedworth, Warwickshire. "Education was a closed box to my parents," he says. "But they could see it was a way out of mining. They knew that intuitively."

There was, however, an oral storytelling tradition in his family - his dad loved recounting anecdotes and several relatives on his mother's side used to tell a good tale. "You have to be able to imagine a scene," he said. "This addresses the hoary old question of the difference between telling and showing in a story. A lot of people can write stuff, but for some reason they cannot impress in their mind's eye the thing happening live and therefore cannot render a scene."

As well as talent, would-be writers also need doggedness to finish, for example, an 80,000-word novel. "I have seen loads of students with a natural flair for words," he said. "but they just do not have the persistence." Joyce is a great believer in writers spending time serving their craft before becoming fluent at pushing the words around on a page.

"What I do at the university enriches my writing because I am constantly having to break down the craft elements to communicate clearly. It's kind of exporting the knowledge from the intuitive to the rational mode. If you are claiming to be a craftsperson, you should be able to replicate these effects time and time again.

"Intellectually that is quite challenging because then you can start looking at other great writers and see how they do it. Some literary rather than genre writers seem to be terrified of breaking down the art and craft of what they do.

"It's almost like an old priesthood, who want the Latin mass so that people do not understand it. Writers have worked up an almost sacred mystery about writing and they want to preserve it. What I am doing is trying to break that down."

After making an initial mess of his O-levels, he passed seven at a second sitting. In the sixth form he started writing poetry and made his first stab at a fantasy novel. A-levels in English literature, language and history followed, before four years training to be a secondary teacher at Bishop Lonsdale teacher training college in Derby.

At college he wrote for the student magazine - getting drunk, as he puts it, on his own published words. After staying on for a fifth sabbatical year as union president, he did an MA in modern English and American literature at Leicester University, where he met his future wife Sue, who was training to be a lawyer.

After a short spell as a poet on the dole - at university he had won a poetry prize - Joyce spent eight years as a training and development officer for the National Association of Youth Clubs in Leicester. In 1988 he and Sue married and drove in a Citroën 2CV to Greece, where he spent a year testing his dream of becoming a novelist.

In Lesbos they shared a shack on the beach with no electricity or mains water and scorpions crawling up the walls. Here, and later in Crete, he completed his first novel, Dreamside. At the end of the year a shepherd came to the door saying that Joyce's London agent was on the phone to the local café saying that the novel had been placed with Pan Macmillan.

Today nine of his fantasy/supernatural thrillers have been published - and four of them, including his latest novel, Indigo, have won the British Fantasy Award. Stephen King has recommended Joyce's The Tooth Fairy, which has sold more than 200,000 copies in the US alone, as one of his favourite books. The film rights to his novel Dark Sister have also been bought by Trimark Pictures.

Four years ago he started teaching creative writing two days a week at Nottingham Trent University. With two young children - Ella, 4, and Joseph, 2 - he wanted more financial security: "I know writers who are better than I am who have suddenly been unable to find a publisher. Also I am fairly gregarious and it drives me crazy to be locked in a room with a word processor day after day.

And does he have anything in common with his great literary forebear DH Lawrence, another scion of a mining family? Not much. He does have a bit of Lawrentian routine, however. "All these spitting, snarling miners," he mimics gustily in a broad East Midlands accent. "Do you want to make a stool-arsed jack of him?"

Hobbits and hobbyists
Donald MacLeod

Fantasy and academic life have gone together happily since the Mad Hatter's tea party.

In real - or at least academic - life Lewis Carroll was the Oxford mathematician Charles Dodgson, a lecturer at Christ Church and author of various treatises on the subject including Euclid and His Modern Rivals. Alice's Adventures in Wonderland, one of the greatest and most original fantasy novels, appeared in 1865.

The story originated in a boat trip with the young Alice Liddell and her two sisters, but is full of characters who might have stepped out of a college commonroom and who argue in the impeccably logical but often daft manner of academics at their most infuriating.

The whole genre of modern fantasy was reinvented by another Oxford don, JRR Tolkien, who tapped into the Anglo-Saxon tales and Viking sagas he studied. The Merton professor of English language and literature, he published a number of philological and critical studies, including the influential Beowulf: the Monsters and the Critics.

The Hobbit (1937) and its sequel, The Lord of the Rings, built up a mythology which has proved extraordinarily popular and spawned a thousand sword and sorcery books, complete with elves and dwarves and goblins and noble warriors. Hollywood followed suit. Now there is even fantasy noir.

CS Lewis, a fellow of Magdalen College, Oxford, during Tolkien's time, was one of the first writers to reflect this influence in his Narnia stories, in which four children step into a fantasy world to find elves and dwarves and goblins. His stories come with a strongly Christian message.

webTitle: New post signals pro-business switch by BBC

fields.headline: New post signals pro-business switch by BBC
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the future of the BBC
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The BBC director general, Greg Dyke, yesterday delivered a withering attack on the corporation's track record in covering business issues, and named Sunday Business editor Jeff Randall as the man he hopes will put it right.
fields.body:
The BBC director general, Greg Dyke, yesterday delivered a withering attack on the corporation's track record in covering business issues, and named Sunday Business editor Jeff Randall as the man he hopes will put it right.

In a wide-ranging criticism of the BBC's present output, Mr Dyke said it had been wrong to entrust responsibility for business to economics editor, Peter Jay, and admitted that mainstream news and current affairs programmes had "ignored or failed to understand the real business agenda".

At the CBI annual conference in Birmingham, Mr Dyke said the corporation would soften its anti-business stance. "We need to understand what profits are for," he said. "That companies have a duty to make profits and that investment can't happen without them".

Mr Randall, 46, will take up the newly created post in February, when his contract with Sunday Business expires. His appointment signals a sharp change in attitude at the corporation. A comment made by Mr Randall in Sunday Business earlier this year said that "patronising, middle-class, guilt-ridden do-gooders dominate [the BBC's] corridors".

Under Mr Dyke, the BBC has shown an increasing willingness to look outside the corporation to fill senior posts. The most recent example was the appointment of former Independent editor, Andrew Marr, as political editor.

Mr Randall was yesterday equally damning in his judgment of the BBC's business coverage.

"There is a huge gap to fill," he said. "For many, many years at the BBC the only business story they would cover would have to be a combination of industrial relations, redundancies or fat cat salaries."

Mr Randall was first approached by BBC executives in May after what he described as a "rant" against the corporation's coverage in the Sunday Business.

The column lambasted the corporation's politically correct agenda. "Greg Dyke made a personal fortune from business. It's about time he looked at the corporation's institutionalised bias against free-enterprise wealth creators," it read.

Mr Randall, who is strongly against Britain joining the single currency, said his wish list would include a dedicated BBC business channel.

Among other measures to build the BBC's coverage, Mr Dyke announced the formation of a business features unit headed by Robert Thirkell. Other plans include a weekly programme featuring a panel of four prominent business figures, a nightly slot on News 24, and Newsnight's first dedicated business reporter.

Mr Dyke made improved business coverage a priority when he took over at the BBC earlier this year.

Mr Randall made his intention to quit Sunday Business well known and is believed to have been offered several other jobs, including one with News Corporation, and a different role within the Barclay brothers' Press Holdings. Sunday Business launched three years ago. It has built a circulation of more than 60,000.

Mr Jay sidestepped the suggestion that Mr Dyke's comments were aimed at him. He noted his own specialism was macro economics and welcomed Mr Randall's appointment. "Business is a very important area, and we are all very excited about the increase in resources and priority," he said. "I don't think it's for me to judge what the coverage has been like in the past."

Mr Randall made a name for himself on the Sunday Telegraph and went on to become City editor of the Sunday Times.

A comment made by Mr Randall in Sunday Business earlier this year said that "patronising, middle-class, guilt-ridden do-gooders dominate [the BBC's] corridors". Under Mr Dyke, the BBC has shown an increasing willingness to look outside the corporation to fill senior posts. The most recent example was the appointment of former Independent editor, Andrew Marr, as political editor. Mr Randall was yesterday equally damning in his judgment of the BBC's business coverage. "There is a huge gap to fill," he said. "For many, many years at the BBC the only business story they would cover would have to be a combination of industrial relations, redundancies or fat cat salaries." Mr Randall was first approached by BBC executives in May after what he described as a "rant" against the corporation's coverage in the Sunday Business. The column lambasted the corporation's politically correct agenda. "Greg Dyke made a personal fortune from business. It's about time he looked at the corporation's institutionalised bias against free-enterprise wealth creators," it read. Mr Randall, who is strongly against Britain joining the single currency, said his wish list would include a dedicated BBC business channel. Among other measures to build the BBC's coverage, Mr Dyke announced the formation of a business features unit headed by Robert Thirkell. Other plans include a weekly programme featuring a panel of four prominent business figures, a nightly slot on News 24, and Newsnight's first dedicated business reporter. Mr Dyke made improved business coverage a priority when he took over at the BBC earlier this year. Mr Randall made his intention to quit Sunday Business well known and is believed to have been offered several other jobs, including one with News Corporation, and a different role within the Barclay brothers' Press Holdings. Sunday Business launched three years ago. It has built a circulation of more than 60,000. Mr Jay sidestepped the suggestion that Mr Dyke's comments were aimed at him. He noted his own specialism was macro economics and welcomed Mr Randall's appointment. "Business is a very important area, and we are all very excited about the increase in resources and priority," he said. "I don't think it's for me to judge what the coverage has been like in the past." Mr Randall made a name for himself on the Sunday Telegraph and went on to become City editor of the Sunday Times.

webTitle: Britain rejects EU call to drop veto

fields.headline: Britain rejects EU call to drop veto
fields.standfirst: Special report: the European commission
fields.trailText: Britain rejected calls yesterday from the president of the European commission, Romano Prodi, to abandon its veto on key areas of tax and immigration policy in the interests of streamlining decision-making to cope with the planned enlargement of the EU.
fields.body:
Britain rejected calls yesterday from the president of the European commission, Romano Prodi, to abandon its veto on key areas of tax and immigration policy in the interests of streamlining decision-making to cope with the planned enlargement of the EU.

Mr Prodi, in his first speech in Britain as head of the commission, said in Birmingham that the system would be unable to cope if the number of EU members expanded from 15 to as many as 28 in the next decade or so.

Mr Prodi said that an extension of qualified majority voting - used only for non-contentious issues at present - would allow the government to push its own initiatives through the EU more easily. Britain had the choice, he said: play a leading part in Europe or be left lagging.

But his suggestion that the veto should be abandoned for taxation matters relating to the single market, fraud, immigration and e-commerce, met with a frosty response. Keith Vaz, the minister for Europe, who welcomed most of Mr Prodi's conciliatory speech, said the government rejected scrapping of the veto in any tax matters and any interference with immigration policy.

"We have made it clear that on tax, social security, border controls and immigration we will not consider qualified majority voting or the removal of the veto." Many other countries, he said, also had areas where they considered scrapping the veto to be off-limits.

With the Conservatives keen to make Europe a pivotal issue at the next election, ministers are taking a tough line on the veto in advance of December's EU summit in Nice, where the agenda will be headed by the issue of reforming the system through which power is exercised and decisions reached.

Mr Vaz said Britain was prepared to talk about majority voting in certain limited fields, such as the rules governing the European court of justice.

Mr Prodi said that enlargement could not be achieved without deep-seated reform of the commission and of the structures of the union itself.

"I hope that decision-taking will be made more efficient, by moving to majority voting in key areas - not in all areas; but in those which are essential to an enlarged union.

"I feel strongly that we must make it easier to modernise and simplify EU laws. I know that in Britain many believe majority voting will reduce Britain's ability to say 'no' to the things it doesn't want. But I have to remind you: it is majority voting that eases the path of initiatives that Britain does want. In an enlarged EU of 28 or more countries, it is simply not possible to continue operating under a system which was conceived for the founding six."

Mr Vaz welcomed Mr Prodi's repetition of Tony Blair's observation in Warsaw in September that Europe should be a superpower but not a superstate. "I am Italian. I was proud to be prime minister of my country. I will not give up my national identity. And no one is threatening that I should," Mr Prodi said. "So let me say this loud and clear: this commission is not calling for a European superstate. Let's forget that fallacy once and for all.

"We have become, and we will remain, interdependent. Europe wants the UK to play its rightful role in the union: a leading role. But the choice is yours ... a leading role, or a country left lagging behind."

With Europe's single currency flagging, Mr Prodi studiously avoided mentioning possible British entry into the monetary system, though in this area, too, he argued at a later press conference that as a more active member of the club Britain would count more.

webTitle: My inspiration: Claire Tomalin

fields.headline: My inspiration
fields.standfirst: Claire Tomalin
fields.trailText: Claire Tomalin
fields.body:
Claire Tomalin is one of our best known non-fiction writers. She won the Whitbread Prize for her biography of Mary Wollstonecraft and Several Strangers, a collection of her journalism, has just been published in paperback.

'My father was French, so it seemed natural that I should go to nursery at the Lycée Français when I was four. My parents separated in 1940 when I was 7, and I became part of a bitter custody battle which meant I was shuffled back and forth between different schools in Cambridgeshire, Hertfordshire and London over the next few years. I particularly remember Oaklands, a small private school, with a wonderful Christian Scientist drama teacher, Miss Roberts, who was terribly disappointed when so many of us succumbed to measles.

'The divorce was horrible, incomprehensible and frightening and, apart from one terrible year as a boarder at the girls' grammar in Hitchin, when I was 8, school became my safe place. At Hitchin, we had to go to bed at six, even in the summer, and I wasn't allowed to read which was a disaster - reading was my solace through the bad years.

'In 1942, I was back with my father and was sent to the Lycée, which had relocated to Lake Ullswater. I became ill and the doctor recommended I be allowed to roam free, so for a while I lived a wonderfully Wordsworthian existence writing poetry among daffodils. Within a year I moved back in with my mother and returned to Hitchin as a day girl. This was a wonderful time; due to the war, the school had kept on a couple of teachers, Miss Hughes and Miss Wells, well beyond their retirement age and between them they brought English and history to life for me and cemented the idea that the subjects were not divided.

'By 15, I had become a thoroughly rebellious adolescent and was having problems with my mother, so it was decided I should go to Dartington Hall. I spent an idyllic year being taught English by Raymond O'Malley who suggested I have a trial run at Cambridge entrance a year early. To my surprise I got in.'

webTitle: Smarties Book Prize shortlist

fields.headline: Smarties Book Prize shortlist
fields.trailText: When JK Rowling generously bowed Harry Potter out of contention for this year's Nestles Smarties Book Prize which he had won for three year's running, she left the field wide open.
fields.body:
When JK Rowling generously bowed Harry Potter out of contention for this year's Nestles Smarties Book Prize which he had won for three year's running, she left the field wide open. This year's shortlist, drawn up by a panel of adults from which children will choose the gold medal winners, represents the breadth and quality of current children's books. The judges said: "A first class field of contenders that bodes well for the future of children's books. The final shortlist is varied and offers something for every child to read." The shortlist is as follows:

5 Years and under:

A brief collection of simple, if gawky lullabies, Husherbye (Cape, £9.99) shows John Burningham's exceptional ability to blur reality and fantasy. It is both reassuring and teasingly provocative, encouraging even very young children to question the world around them.

Super-heroes Mum and Dad, fly effortlessly across the big pages in Bob Graham's Max (Walker, £9.99), while their son remains firmly grounded. Bold illustrations capture the agonies of a child failing to live up to parental expectations, and the bliss when he is finally airborne.

Satoshi Kitamura's delight in the wilder flights of imagination is much in evidence in Me and My Cat? (Andersen, £9.99). After a midnight visit from an old lady in pointed hat, it's hard to tell which is Nicholas and which is his cat. Excellent visual jokes juxtapose well with a straightforward text.

6-8 Years:

Award-winning Lauren Child skates effortlessly across visual and textual boundaries to create dazzlingly original Beware of the Storybook Wolves (Hodder Children's Books, £9.99). When Herb accidentally lets the wolves out of his story book, he has to work like crazy to keep them happy. Forget safe bedtime stories; books can be dangerous!

Tony Mitton's accessible poems tell three separate stories in The Red and White Spotted Handkerchief (Scholastic, £9.99). Having nothing to lose Jack, in the title story, sets off with all his belongs tied up in a handkerchief. Kept going by his wits and his kindness, his magical adventures are neatly encapsulated.

Lizzie's stubbornness with a new step-family is perfectly captured by Jacqueline Wilson in Lizzie Zipmouth (Corgi, £3.99). Lizzie refuses to speak until she finds something that is so important she must break her vow of silence.

9-11 Years:

Snapshots of life in the Middle Ages are made earthily realistic in Kevin Crossley-Holland's Arthur: The Seeing Stone (Orion, £10.99). Woven in to the picture is a contemporary Arthur who dreams of Arthurian myths and his possible role in them.

Two shots fired from a car change life forever for Sade and Femi in Beverley Naidoo's The Other Side of Truth (Puffin, £4.99). For their safety they must flee Nigeria for Britain. This child view of refugees and asylum seekers is a valuable antidote to scaremongering.

William Nicholson wittily parodies current preoccupation with testing in The Wind Singer Mammoth, (£12.99). Kestrel Hath's quest to discover the evil power controlling the walled city of Aramanth, where exams are everything, is high quality adventure.

The prizewinners will be announced on November 29, 2000.

webTitle: BBC-backed UK Play relaunches as Play UK

fields.headline: UK Play relaunches with new website
fields.trailText: 12.30pm: The BBC-backed commercial channel UK Play is relaunching as ....Play UK, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
BBC-backed commercial channel UK Play is relaunching as ...Play UK.

The youth-oriented station, which is part of the UKTV joint venture with Flextech, will be given a new on-air and off-air brand identity.

It will also launch UKTV's biggest website to date, playuk.tv, which carries the same identity and style as the revamped channel.

Neil Morris, head of new media at UKTV, said: "It's the first big step for UKTV into new media and it's the first channel that is going to get a strong online supporting presence."

Mr Morris added that he was working on a number of enhanced TV initiatives that will sit behind the UKTV channels: UK Gold, UK Horizons, UK Style and UK Drama.

According to Simon Bucknall, an internet producer poached from Granada Broadband to run the site, the idea is to create an entity that people see as a resource where they can create and contribute content as well as access our music, clips and chat.

"We want the site to become a broker of views and information, and push the boundaries of a strict TV channel or programme-based website."

Aimed primarily at an audience of 16-34 men, playuk.tv has a number of unique features.

These include new games, one of which requires players to help Ann Widdecombe avoid drugs, and a new take on a chat room, Avatar chat baby, where users can see one another, move around the chat room onto sofas and even pick fights.

webTitle: Bright Station reports new round of pre-tax losses

fields.headline: Bright Station announces further losses
fields.trailText: 1pm:Internet company Bright Station is gambling on success in the US market after its losses increased. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Bright Station, the internet company that recently hired the former head of AltaVista UK, is gambling on success in the US market after its losses increased.

The company, which last week recruited Andy Mitchell as head of its WebTop search engine, reported a pre-tax loss of £4.6m from June to September, against a loss of £0.2m for the same period last year.

David Mattey, chief financial officer at Bright Station, said that the losses reflected increased investment in a push for sales across the Atlantic.

He said Bright Station planned to float its SmartLogiK subsidiary over the next nine months, though an IPO depends on the company's impact in the US.

"SmartLogiK has a US sales team in place, and it will build up a full head of steam over the next three months," added Mr Mattey.

Analysts have given SmartLogiK a £175m price tag, dwarfing Bright Station's £118m valuation.

Bright Station's other businesses include the OfficeShopper online stationery supplies service and the Sparza e-commerce company. Sparza uses the technology behind boo.com, the online clothes retailer.

Analysts said the amount of cash spent by Bright Station over the period was a cause for concern, as it amounted to nearly £500,000 per month, leaving the company with £19.5m in the bank.

Iain Staples, internet analyst at ABN Amro, said: "If they do not execute their business plan flawlessly over the next four months, then they will find it hard to recoup their investments."

webTitle: Rumours Unlimited

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's gossip is one point ahead in the latest tracking poll
fields.trailText: Leeds are set to make a £10 million bid for Newcastle United's Kieron Dyer according to the Mirror. David O'Leary wants the ex-Ipswich Town midfielder to add another attacking dimension to his injury-plagued squad. The Daily Star adds, however, that Bobby Robson will not let the 21-year-old leave St James's Park.
fields.body:
Leeds are set to make a £10 million bid for Newcastle United's Kieron Dyer according to the Mirror. David O'Leary wants the ex-Ipswich Town midfielder to add another attacking dimension to his injury-plagued squad. The Daily Star adds, however, that Bobby Robson will not let the 21-year-old leave St James's Park.

Rio Ferdinand and Paolo Di Canio could be on the move from Upton Park to raise funds to pay for Norweigan defender Ragnvald Soma from Byrne. Kjell Madland, a Byrne director, said the Hammers had already received a bid for Ferdinand and that the proposed sale of Di Canio had already fallen through.

Chelsea manager Claudio Ranieri, who was in Italy last weekend, wants to sign Marco Delvecchio from Roma and the Lazio midfielder Pavel Nedved, according to teamtalk.com.

The Daily Express reveals that Manchester City are ready to make another bid for Titi Camara as a replacement for George Weah at Maine Road. Liverpool have placed a £4 million price tag on the Guinean but, according to the Mirror, Joe Royle believes he can get his man for £2 million. Other strikers reported to be on Royle's list are Celtic's Mark Burchill, currently on loan at Birmingham, Ipswich's David Johnson, who has not secured a first team berth this season, Preston's Jonathan Macken and Marco Negri from Rangers.

Stuart McCall has six rivals for the vacant manager's job at Bradford, says the Mirror. Neil Warnock, currently at Sheffield United, ex-Huddersfield boss Steve Bruce, Joe Kinnear, Howard Kendall, Roy Evans and David Pleat are all in the running. The Sun adds Steve Coppell to the list of potential managers but suggests Evans and Kendall are front-runners for the post. The Daily Mail touts Pleat as favourite.

The £6 million price-tag that Claudio Ranieri has placed on out-of-favour Jody Morris at Stamford Bridge is too high for Leicester City, although Peter Taylor is interested, the Daily Star reports.

Manchester United are ready to sign Canadian defender Kevin McKenna from German club Energie Cottbus according to the Daily Star. However, according to planetfootball, West Ham are more likely to capture McKenna's signature.

Planetfootball claim Arsenal are pursuing Kennedy Bakircioglu, who once had a trial at Manchester United and is currently at Hammarby in Sweden. Barcelona and Gothenborg are also interested in the 20-year-old.

Bolton's South African international Mark Fish will sign for Charlton today for £700,000, according to The Sun.

Jim Smith is ready to let Lars Bohinen leave Premiership strugglers Derby while Coventry look to add to their Moroccan contingent by targeting Youssef Safri.

webTitle: Ant and Dec turn down third series of Friends Like These

fields.headline: Ant and Dec snub BBC for new ITV peak time show
fields.trailText: 12.45pm: Ant and Dec have turned down a third series of BBC Saturday night show Friends like These to do a new ITV show, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The BBC's head of light entertainment David Young was dealt his first major blow today after Ant and Dec refused to front a third series of the hit Saturday night show Friends like These.

Instead, Anthony McPartlin and Declan Donnelly have signed up to do a new peak time entertainment show for ITV.

They are already considered one of ITV's most valuable double-acts as presenters of the hit Saturday morning children's shows SM:TV Live and CD:UK.

However, a spokesman for ITV insisted that Ant and Dec had not signed an exclusive deal with ITV.

The Geordie pair will also be fronting a Christmas entertainment special for ITV and the 2001 Brit Awards, as well as continuing with the children's shows.

Mr Young, who made his name at Bazal Productions, is considered a rising star of the BBC. He has reinvigorated the entertainment department and helped devise the format for Friends Like These.

webTitle: Hinduja brothers in talks with Trinity Mirror on distribution deal

fields.headline: Hindujas in distribution talks with Trinity Mirror
fields.trailText: 9.30am: The Hinduja brothers are talking with Trinity Mirror about a distribution deal if their Express bid is successful, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
The Hinduja brothers have said they are in talks with Trinity Mirror about a distribution deal if their bid for the Express newspaper group is successful.

Sources confirmed talks were underway but stressed that the discussions are at a very early stage.They insisted there was no truth in reports the Hindujas were considering a joint bid for the Express with Trinity.

Meanwhile, Express owner United News & Media's demands that the Daily Mail pay a £60m non-refundable "deposit" before it releases confidential financial documents were being seen as a potential deal-breaker.

It could also put off an anticipated bid from Hollinger, owner of the Daily Telegraph. Analysts said United had a duty to put every bid before its shareholders, even those from rivals.

Meg Geldens, media analyst at Merrill Lynch, said: "If the bids are equal financially, then it must come down in favour of the Hindujas, who offer a quicker sale. But if the Mail comes in with a bigger bid, then United might decide to put it in front of the shareholders."

webTitle: Gore closes the gap

fields.headline: Gore closes the gap
fields.standfirst:
Too close to call as huge poll puts candidates a point apart

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Al Gore was closing the gap on George W Bush as  Americans prepared to go to the polls today to elect a  successor to Bill Clinton in one of the closest-fought  presidential election campaigns in US history.
fields.byline: Martin Kettle in Washington and  Duncan Campbell in Nashville
fields.body:
Al Gore was closing the gap on George W Bush as Americans prepared to go to the polls today to elect a successor to Bill Clinton in one of the closest-fought presidential election campaigns in US history.

The final daily tracking polls of the campaign showed Mr Gore, the Democrat, narrowing the long-standing lead of his Republican rival to well within the statistical margin of error.

One poll even gave Mr Gore a 2% lead on the back of a strong 48 hours of polling.

In the final Gallup tracking survey of the campaign, Mr Bush led by 47% to Mr Gore's 45%, compared with a 48%-43% lead at the weekend. In the final Zogby International tracking poll, Mr Bush led by just one point, 47% to 46%. A late tracking poll by Reuters/MSNBC put Mr Gore in the lead at 48% to 46%.

Further evidence of a neck- and-neck finish came last night in a Harris poll based on an unusually large sample, which showed Mr Bush leading 47%-46% in the popular vote, but projected Mr Gore as the next president by virtue of a 286-241 victory in the electoral college, with Washington state's 11 votes too close to call.

The Harris poll was based on a sample of 134,000 people and was carried out between October 30 and November 4.

It also supported the opinion of some experts that Mr Gore might become the first man since 1888 to be elected president without winning a majority of the popular vote.

Oozing confidence, Mr Bush took his campaign deep into opposition territory on the last full day on the stump, campaigning in Mr Clinton's Arkansas and Mr Gore's Tennessee before returning to his home in Austin, Texas.

"We've laid the groundwork for victory. Now it's up to us to get people to the polls," Mr Bush told supporters in Orlando, Florida yesterday.

Mr Gore campaigned in the key states of Iowa, Missouri, Michigan and Florida, all of which he needs to win if he is to fulfil his dream of succeeding Mr Clinton.

"You are the ones who are going to make the difference in this race," Mr Gore told Iowa campaign workers in a pre-dawn briefing. "That's what's going to win this race."

A new Gallup poll of independent voters showed a sharp swing from Mr Nader to Mr Gore. Last week, 41% of independent voters said they were backing Mr Bush, 36% Mr Gore and 13% Mr Nader. This week, Mr Gore is on 40% and Mr Nader is on 9%, with Mr Bush unchanged.

The crucial black vote is also hardening up for Mr Gore in the final hours, polls said. Mr Gore's support among African American voters has risen from 86% last week to 91% on the eve of poll.

"It's one of many hopeful signs," said a member of Gore's team in Nashville yesterday. "It is expected. It's traditional that third-party support slips at the end of a campaign and the base comes back."

Mr Bush's camp was just as confident, releasing private poll results which they claimed showed the Republican ahead in Florida and Michigan and neck-and-neck in California.

As well as a president, a new House of Representatives was being elected today by American voters, along with 34 members of the US Senate. The first projected results, based on exit polls, will come through after 11pm GMT.

webTitle: News of the World seeks replacement showbiz editor for Harpin

fields.headline: News of the World seeks new showbiz editor
fields.trailText: 12pm: The News of the World is seeking a new showbiz editor after Lee Harpin was told he was being moved from the job, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The News of the World is seeking a new showbiz editor after Lee Harpin was told he would not be able to continue in the job.

Mr Harpin confirmed that he had been told three weeks ago he was being moved from his job, but refused to comment further.

Deputy editor Andy Coulson also refused to comment on the move.

Insiders said Mr Harpin was in discussions with the newspaper about alternative positions or a severance package, but he is thought not to want another job at the newspaper.

Mr Harpin's exclusives included the recent revelation that Liam Gallagher was dating Nicole Appleton.

The move comes amid speculation that News of the World editor Rebekah Wade and Mr Coulson are planning a revamp for the paper.

webTitle: Sportel teams up with sportsmediarights.com to create online marketplace

fields.headline: Sportel links with online company for rights venture
fields.trailText: 12.30pm: Sportel, the TV sports programming market organiser, is developing an online marketplace with sportsmediarights.com. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Sportel, the TV sports programming market organiser, is developing an online marketplace with sportsmediarights.com.

The two companies have signed heads of agreement to work together to develop sportsmediarights.com as an e-commerce site for transactions between sports rights buyers and sellers.

Monaco-based Sportel owns and operates annual sports TV programming markets in Monaco and the US.

Sportsmediarights.com is expected to go live in May 2001. The online development is a joint venture between Aim-listed media consultancy and investment outfit Media Content and SDCi, which operates ProgrammeRights.com and e-adsales.com.

Leonard Fertig, SDCi chairman, said: "The combination of Sportel, the acknowledged industry leader in sports marketplaces, with Content Media's independent expertise and SDCi's unrivalled experience at ProgrammeRights.com, ensures that sportsmediarights.com will become the benchmark of online sports rights trading."

webTitle: Advertising growth slows

fields.headline: UK advertising growth slows
fields.trailText: 11.15am: Advertising growth is slowing down as the lure of the internet sucks marketing spend away from traditional media, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Advertising growth is slowing down as the lure of the internet sucks marketing spend away from traditional media.

The latest research from media monitoring company ACNielsen MMS shows that the growth in UK ad spend dropped to 4% in the year to September 2000, down from 7% in the previous year.

And the growth in advertising spend was mainly driven by the dot.com and IT sectors, prompting fears that the advertising market could fall if, as experts predict, struggling dot.coms begin to cut their marketing budgets.

In the last year advertising revenues have been dramatically boosted by the flood of internet companies launching high-profile TV and billboard campaigns.

The growth in dot.com ad spend is now falling as more and more internet companies go to the wall.

Several industries that have traditionally been big advertisers have actually cut their advertising spend over the last year.

The food and drink sector spent £1.073bn in the 12 months to September 2000, some £60m less than in the previous year. And the car sector saw a drop of nearly £100m, from £984m in 1998-99 to £887m in 1999-2000.

ACNielsen MMS analyst Jeremy Ridgeway said: "The advertising industry is used to high levels of growth but these latest figures show some potentially worrying results.

"A late surge in pre-Christmas advertising will almost certainly boost spend to the £10bn mark but the industry will do well to post growth over 5% this year."

Spending on direct mail fell in the 12 months to September as the financial services sector, traditionally the biggest user of direct mail, switched its allegiance to TV and press advertising.

webTitle: Education Spanish resources: Testigo - Archaeology

fields.headline: Testigo - Archaeology
fields.standfirst: Biologist Jos¿ Mar¿a Berm¿dez de Castro on his work examining remains of the oldest Europeans ever found
fields.trailText: Biologist Jos¿ Mar¿a Berm¿dez de Castro on his work examining remains of the oldest Europeans ever found
fields.body:
El archivo más completo de la evolución humana en Europa en el último millón de años está en la sierra de Atapuerca, a 14 kilómetros de Burgos (España). Allí encontramos los fósiles de europeos de 800.000 años, los más antiguos conocidos hasta ahora. Son fósiles de huesos que están muy muy fragmentados, pues son resultado del canibalismo.

También encontramos el cráneo más completo del registro fósil mundial. Estos dos son los hallazgos más excepcionales desde que empezaron las primeras excavaciones en Atapuerca en 1979.

El paisaje, el clima, la vegetación en la zona han variado poco en el último millón de años. Por ello es fundamental conservar el entorno natural y ecológico de las excavaciones. Esto será posible si la Unesco declara el yacimiento Patrimonio de la Humanidad. El único yacimiento paleontológico declarado hasta ahora Patrimonio de la Humanidad es el de Zhoukoudian, en China, donde se descubrió el Hombre de Pekín.

En las excavaciones el tiempo transcurre a un ritmo diferente. A veces tienes la sensación de que ha pasado mucho tiempo, y en realidad ha sido sólo una semana. Mi trabajo es planificar y controlar la logística: coordinar un grupo de cien personas que trabajan en seis excavaciones distintas, además del equipo de lavado en el río y el laboratorio. Las excavaciones duran un mes y medio y hay muy buen ambiente. El resto del año es para investigar el material encontrado, clasificarlo, asimilar la información...

Cuando hay un descubrimiento extraordinario recorre toda la excavación una emoción colectiva. Durante varios días flotamos como en una nube. En Atapuerca se podrá seguir excavando durante cientos de años. Nuestra mayor expectativa es encontrar fósiles aún más antiguos y más completos, y también fósiles más modernos, como el del neandertal.

Interview by Eulália Furriol

webTitle: Conjoined twin survives separation surgery

fields.headline: Conjoined twin survives separation surgery
fields.standfirst: More about the conjoined twins
fields.trailText: Conjoined twin Jodie today survived the complex separation operation which ended the life of her weaker sister, Mary, health officials said.
fields.body:
Conjoined twin Jodie today survived the complex separation operation which ended the life of her weaker sister, Mary, health officials said.

Surgeons and medical teams worked for 20 hours to separate the twins at St Mary's hospital in Manchester where they were born three months ago. The operation ended early today and Jodie was said to be in a "critical but stable condition".

"Unfortunately, despite all the efforts of the medical team, Mary sadly died," a hospital spokesman said. "As with all major surgery, the first few days following an operation are the most critical and our thoughts remain with Jodie and her parents."

Their parents, who opposed the operation for religious reasons, said their goodbyes to Mary before the operation started yesterday morning.

Mary, who had primitive brain functions, was said to have been "draining the life" out of Jodie, who is thought to have normal mental abilities. Jodie's heart and lungs had kept them both alive.

Jodie will now need extensive skin grafts and surgery but doctors say she could be of normal intelligence, able to walk, have children and have an average life expectancy.

The legal battle to save her began shortly after the twins were born with fused spines, joined at the abdomen and with arms and legs at right angles to their upper bodies.

Doctors from St Mary's went to the high court in August and won the right to operate despite the objection of the parents, who are strict Roman Catholics from the Maltese island of Gozo.

They challenged the decision in a privately funded appeal the following month, but lost after agonising deliberations by the three judges involved who decided Mary must die to save the life of her stronger sister.

An 11th hour appeal was lodged by the ProLife Alliance last Friday but it also failed to halt the surgery. The high court and court of appeal rejected an application to have the official solicitor, Laurence Oates, removed as Mary's legal guardian and replaced by the Alliance director, Bruno Quintaville.

They argued that the official solicitor had "improperly" refused or neglected to present an appeal to the Lords and that it was a case which "cried out" for their consideration because of all the wide-ranging issues involved.

webTitle: Freeserve launches interactive mouse mat

fields.headline: Freeserve launches interactive mouse mat
fields.trailText: 10.30am: Freeserve has come up with a new internet gadget for technophobes - an interactive mouse mat, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Freeserve is back in analysts' good books after coming up with a new internet gadget in time for Christmas - an interactive mouse mat.

Already being thought of as a "highly innovative product", the First Click Internet Power Pad essentially turns a mouse mat into a remote control.

It offers intuitive web browsing for those unfamiliar with using a mouse. This is a factor often seen as a major contributor towards non-PC users' despair at internet browsing, particularly when their first reaction is to pick up a mouse and use it like a TV remote control.

The Freeserve innovation was a welcome ray of sunshine for a company that has had a difficult time in recent months.

The market gave an immediate thumbs-up to the announcement with shares rising.

Buttons on the mouse mat connect users direct to their pre-set favourite websites. But perhaps one of the crucial elements of First Click is that it contains a smart card for secure e-commerce transactions. For new users going online this Christmas, this should go some way to easing shopping concerns.

The announcement that Dixons is selling First Click mouse mats exclusively through Dixons Group stores should not come as a surprise to anyone. But at £29.99 per mat, is Dixons going to make a killing in the stocking filler sector this year?

John Pluthero, chief executive officer of Freeserve, said: "By simplifying access and use of the internet and all the e-commerce sites it has to offer, our proprietary First Click device will drive to the Freeserve portals those users who are inhibited by technology and who might not otherwise contemplate shopping online.

"First Click is another exclusive advantage for Freeserve customers to enjoy, and further demonstrates how Freeserve is colonising internet use in the UK."

webTitle: Jobbins to leave BBC World Service

fields.headline: Jobbins to leave BBC World Service after 30 years
fields.trailText: 10.45am: One of the BBC World Service's most senior news executives, Bob Jobbins, is to leave after 30 years with the corporation, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
One of the BBC World Service's most senior news executives, Bob Jobbins, is to leave after 30 years with the corporation.

The director of English networks and news is planning a move into media consultancy, in the commercial and not-for-profit sectors. He will be leaving the World Service next spring, by which time his replacement is expected to be in place.

He spent many years as a correspondent, working mainly in the Middle East and south east Asia, before moving into management as head of the BBC Arabic Service and later editor of World Service news and current affairs.

Mr Jobbins was regarded as a moderniser, who played a key role in moving the World Service's English language output away from its "man in a bowler hat" image.

His most recent project has involved making the World Service English language programming internet compatible.

He said: "I am sad to be leaving an organisation where I have had such a stimulating career, but I am excited by the chance to take on completely new challenges."

Mark Byford, BBC World Service chief executive, said: "Bob Jobbins has been one of the BBC's great journalists of his generation. He has also been a really gifted managerial leader of change."
