webTitle: Analysis

fields.headline: Analysis
fields.standfirst: Why Archie Norman was slapped down
fields.trailText: Why Archie Norman was slapped down.
fields.body:
It was a telling moment at yesterday's annual meeting of Britain's bosses in Birmingham, when a leading Tory politician was slapped down by Digby Jones, the CBI director-general, as he denounced the network of government-sponsored regional development agencies.

The politician in question was the shadow environment spokesman Archie Norman. Once leading Tories were received with fawning deference and Labour spokesmen were not even allowed through the door. Not any more.

The CBI has just released its scrupulously even-handed business election manifesto. It is clear that its differences with Labour are skin-deep while those with the opposition are more fundamental.

Mr Jones, a west Midlands lawyer, replaced Adair Turner with a firm mandate to put more distance between the CBI and Labour.

To an extent this has happened, underlined by the organisation's campaign against government red tape and regulations, which it says have cost firms more than £12bn since May 1997, when Labour came to power. But Mr Jones and his team have no objection to the government's policies on the national minimum wage, shorter working hours or longer holidays. They also admit that the lion's share of the £12.3bn cost is accounted for by the value of the policies themselves.

The attack on red tape is partly a bargaining tool designed to dissuade ministers from bringing in new workplace rights such as paid parental leave. The CBI now goes out of its way to applaud Labour's achievements in office. Sir Iain Vallance, BT chairman and the CBI's new president, praised Gordon Brown on Sunday for his stewardship of the economy, particularly for creating and sustaining macro-economic stability after the boom-bust years of successive Tory chancellors. The strength of sterling remains a problem for the CBI's manufacturing wing but the body will not call for government intervention to force a devaluation.

Britain's leading employers' body also salutes government investment in education, especially in raising the nation's skills base and tackling chronic British problems of adult illiteracy and innumeracy. Under Mr Jones the CBI sees itself as critical to persuading deputy prime minister John Prescott to adopt a £180bn spending programme for transport over the next 10 years.

The differences with the Tories are glaring. Mr Jones has demanded assurances from Michael Portillo, shadow chancellor, that his proposed spending plans - with cuts of £8bn to £16bn in Mr Brown's own plans - will not affect the transport improvement programme.

The chief source of conflict between the CBI and the opposition is the euro. The CBI is as divided over the issue as the nation, although it remains wedded to the idea of joining in principle. It simply disagrees with the opposition's decision to rule out joining for virtually the whole of this decade, and this message has been delivered privately to William Hague and Mr Portillo repeatedly. "Why tie your hands behind your back?" Mr Jones said. "You should have the flexibility to deal with the set of cards given to you. They are mistaken in categorically closing down that option."

In the run up to next year's likely general election the CBI is bound to raise demands for fewer taxes and less regulation, key elements of the Tories' agenda. But without publicly endorsing Labour, the bulk of its senior officials and its members will be praying - and voting - for a second term for Tony Blair.

webTitle: Milan deny Barca bonus claim

fields.headline: Milan deny Barca bonus claim
fields.trailText: AC Milan have denied reports that Barcelona have offered them a bonus to beat Leeds in their Champions League encounter in the San Siro tomorrow night.
fields.body:
AC Milan have denied reports that Barcelona have offered them a bonus to beat Leeds in their Champions League encounter in the San Siro tomorrow night.

A Spanish newspaper, Sport, had suggested that the Catalan giants would give Milan's squad £1.6m if they won, a result that would leave Barcelona with a chance of qualifying for the second group stage. Leeds only need a draw to go through.

"No official from Barcelona has put a proposal to AC Milan, its members and officials, relating to a "reward" for an eventual victory over Leeds United on Wednesday", a club statement released through Milan's official website said today.

The statement was signed by Milan's vice-president Adriano Galliani, who has already insisted that Milan will play to win, in the interests of "fair play" and "respect".

In other developments, Milan's city authorities have banned the sale of alcohol on the day of the game, in an attempt to avoid any disturbances. This plan follows the successful scheme employed during Italia 90, when host cities were prohibited from serving alcohol on the day of the match.

webTitle: GWR's Daily Mail radio assets deliver below par performance

fields.headline: GWR's Daily Mail radio assets fail to deliver
fields.trailText: 11am: Radio broadcaster GWR has said that the Daily Mail's radio assets, which it bought in June, are performing below par. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Radio broadcaster GWR has admitted that the Daily Mail's radio assets, which it snapped up in June, are delivering a below-par performance.

The news comes as the owner of Classic FM said first-half pre-tax profits were £6.9m, down 24% from last year's £9.1m, although turnover rose 23% to £58.7m.

GWR spent £146m on the Daily Mail & General Trust's DMG Radio Group, boosting its portfolio with stations in the UK, Hungary and Australia.

But chairman Henry Meakin said the DMG purchase has got off to a poor start. "The financial performance of the UK stations during the three months of our ownership has been slightly below our expectations," he said.

He added that the Australian operations were also running below par, due to disappointing advertising revenues from the Sydney Olympics.

GWR has spent money on taking the lead in digital radio, investing in three digital multiplexes in Coventry, Wolverhampton and Bristol.

The group has joined forces with Kelvin MacKenzie's Wireless Group, Scottish Media Group, publisher Emap and Carphone Warehouse to bid for the next round of digital licences.

GWR's burgeoning new media interests are rounded off by its internet ventures, which include the koko.com local portal business.

"There are a host of opportunities for the group especially within digital radio and in the internet, both of which are at an early stage, and where the big rewards will be felt for years to come," added Mr Meakin.

webTitle: Out to gore the bullish Bush

fields.headline: Out to gore the bullish Bush
fields.standfirst: Al Gore has had the best kind of experience that a presidential candidate could hope for, but Julian Glover explains why this may not be quite enough
fields.trailText: Al Gore has had the best kind of experience that a presidential candidate could hope for, but Julian Glover explains why this may not be quite enough
fields.body:
Al Gore, vice-president since 1993, was born to high office. "We trained him for it", his father, also Al Gore and a leading Democrat senator, once said.

Educated with the nation's elite in Washington - but brought up outside term-time on the family's farm in Carthage, Tennessee - Gore went to Harvard university at a time when student life was in the throes of '60s counter-culture and protests against the Vietnam war. Unlike Bill Clinton, he did inhale.

He also volunteered for the draft to Vietnam in 1970, although both he and his father opposed the war. In south-east Asia, he served as a journalist - though rarely under fire, as rivals have pointed out.

On his return he worked as a journalist before standing for - and winning - a seat in the House of Representatives. He made a name as a defender of consumer rights and as something of a moral conservative. He voted against allowing abortion and spoke critically about homosexuality.

In 1984 he stepped up his career, entering the senate as one of Tennessee's two representatives. He became fascinated by a string of issues then outside the mainstream, including the environment and information technology.

After an unsuccessful bid for the Democratic presidential nomination in 1988, he wrote a best-selling book on environmentalism, Earth in the Balance. The book helped make his name - but also trapped him in the public mind as a politician obsessed with detail, and opposed to much that ordinary Americans hold dear - not least, cheap petrol.

Nonetheless, Bill Clinton chose him as his running mate in 1992 and Al Gore was sworn in as vice-president a year later. He has had a big stake in the Clinton presidency, with greater access to power than most of his predecessors.

That has brought advantages - but also damaged Gore's reputation, not least his refusal to condemn Bill Clinton after the Lewinsky affair.

He also became involved in a scandal over fundraising ahead of Bill Clinton's re-election in 1996: rumours about what exactly went on have never gone away.

Politically, Al Gore was a liberal reformer, campaigning against big government and supporting Bill Clinton in his decision to support Republican plans to cut taxes.

That upset some traditional Democrats, many of whom backed Bill Bradley for the presidential nomination in primary races earlier this year. Gore won though - and has been neck and neck in the polls with his rival George Bush ever since.

Even if he wins, the US will not love him as it has Bill Clinton. Republicans have made hay with Gore's leaden public character, and his boastful claims to have helped "invent" the internet.

In office, he would have to learn how to speak to the nation in a way it can understand and trust.

webTitle: Livingstone could veto Arsenal stadium plans

fields.headline: Livingstone could veto Arsenal stadium plans
fields.trailText: Arsenal's new 60,000 seater stadium could be vetoed by London mayor Ken Livingstone because of fierce opposition from local residents.
fields.body:
Arsenal's new 60,000 seater stadium could be vetoed by London mayor Ken Livingstone because of fierce opposition from local residents.

Earlier today, Arsenal executives unveiled blueprints for a £100m new stadium and leisure complex at Ashburton Grove, to be built by the 2003-2004 season. But if local residents get their way the stadium won't be built at all.

Despite Arsenal claiming to have the full support of Islington council, it is Livingstone - in his role of mayor - who has the final say over whether the plans will go ahead - and angry Islington residents have urged him to block the club's plans.

"This is not a local issue for a local council to decide and it is not just about football, said Alison Carmichael, press officer for the Islington Stadium Communities Alliance (ISCA) which represents 12 local groups.

"A stadium of this size would be the biggest built in such a densely populated area, anywhere in Western Europe. Only 5% of Arsenal fans at the recent home games against Liverpool and Charlton games actually live in Islington - half came from outside the M25.

"And with 60,000 fans coming and going from a huge multi-use stadium, with all the attendant policing, and disruption that will mean, will be too much for the narrow residential streets found in this part of North Islington," she added.

"If you look at other major stadium developments in recent years, like in Milan or, more to the point, Sydney, you will find that they are always well away from residential areas like ours," she continued. "We are prepared to take this all the way. We want Ken Livingstone to decide on this. It is an issue for the whole of London."

Greater London Authority spokesman Sean O'Curneen, admitted that by law the matter would have to be put to London's mayor, and added that Mr Livingstone would have the power to veto the decision should Islington council choose to accept the planning permission.

"For a proposal this size the mayor must be consulted and, should he deem the plans unacceptable he will be able to prevent the move from going ahead," he said.

But Arsenal are still hoping the new stadium will be approved. They argue that the move will ensure their survival among the elite in European football - and also claim that it will transform a run-down part of London.

Club director Ken Friar said: "Our proposals will act as a catalyst for the regeneration of the wider area by safeguarding and creating 3,500 jobs, providing over 1,000 new homes and injecting over £400m of investment into the area."

"For over 20 years the Lough Road area has been a blot on the Islington landscape. These proposals will provide substantial public benefit and, unlike previous failed schemes, can be delivered."

webTitle: A true blue-blooded Republican

fields.headline: A true blue-blooded Republican
fields.standfirst: George W Bush has the political background to succeed, but Julian Glover looks beyond family to examine the man who would be president
fields.trailText: George W Bush has the political background to succeed, but Julian Glover looks beyond family to examine the man who would be president.
fields.body:
George W Bush is a political blue-blood. Like his Democratic rival Al Gore, his father was a successful politician - and, also like Al Gore, he shares his father's name.

But even more than Gore, Bush's candidature suggests that the US is not quite the land of open-for-all opportunity people think it is.

If George Bush is elected to the White House, it will have as much to do with his father's reputation and fund-raising powers as it will with Bush's own character.

Nonetheless, he is typical of his generation and his country. A Spanish-speaking millionaire who has moved with the nation from his east coast roots to the booming south-west - in his case, Texas - he grew up more involved in baseball than in anything else.

He studied at Yale, where he was noted more for his personality than for his academic skills. webTitle: The colour of peace

fields.headline: The colour of peace
fields.standfirst: As his new movie Siam Sunset finally gets a UK release, Imogen Tilden finds Linus Roache at peace with the world and with himself
fields.trailText: As his new movie Siam Sunset finally gets a UK release, Imogen Tilden finds Linus Roache at peace with the world and with himself
fields.body:
Playing the lead in a comedy is not where you'd expect to find Linus Roache. Acclaimed for his riveting performance as the tortured Father Greg in 1994's Priest, and as the flawed journalist-gigolo in Iain Softley's adaptation of The Wings of the Dove, the 36-year-old actor is associated more with the intense and brooding shades of the acting spectrum than the lighter, comic ones.

Yet, he tells me one wet afternoon in a dark Leicester Square bar, what attracted him to the lead role in Siam Sunset was its humour. "I really wanted to do a comedy, but a lot of the comedies I'd seen or read were formulaic. Siam Sunset felt so off-the-wall and different and fresh and new, and had so many different qualities to it. It also had real drama, and an element of magic and mystery."

Siam Sunset is indeed far from formulaic. Part road movie, part romance, part thriller, part farce: it's a truly black comedy that explores what happens to a man after his wife dies in a bizarre accident - the kind of bizarre accident that you think is only an urban myth.

Perry (Roache), an industrial chemist who creates colours, believes that someone has "got it in" for him. After a lorry crashes through his living room, he decides to get away from it all, and heads for Australia on a touring holiday won at a bingo game. But his troubles are far from over. He finds himself on an antiquated coach with a variety of misfits led by driver Bill. Also along for the ride is Grace (Danielle Cormack), on the run from her drug-dealing boyfriend. The Siam Sunset of the title is 'the colour of peace' that Perry hopes to create. Phew.

"I hadn't done a film that actually gives people joy and fun. It's great to be in cinemas and watch people respond," explains Roache. "...it was great fun and it surprised me as well what happens at the beginning still makes me laugh now." He adds that he's been instructed not to reveal quite how his unfortunate 'wife' meets her end.

Passing unnoticed in the throng of Leicester Square, Roache is a slight figure, who is casually dressed and friendly and relaxed. He looks far too good for someone who's getting over jetlag and a non-stop seven month run of stage performances. He's just returned from Tokyo where he has been touring in productions of Richard II and Coriolanus, acting opposite Ralph Fiennes. He's in town today for the London Film Festival screening of Pandaemonium, in which he plays the poet Samuel Taylor Coleridge.

However, Siam Sunset is uppermost on his mind. Made over two years ago, and premiered at the 1999 Cannes Film Festival, Siam Sunset was Australian actor John Polson's directorial debut, but it has been sitting on the distributor's shelf for some time now. Roache acknowledges that it's a difficult film to sell: "It's a challenge because it's not clearly this kind of movie or that kind of movie, it's a road movie, a tragedy, a comedy, a farce, it's all these things. Maybe it's very ambitious in that way, it does make it hard to find your audience, but I think there's something in there for everybody."

I ask him about the filming. With the final third of the movie set in the desolate desert of the Australian outback amid extreme heat, it must have been a gruelling shoot.

Not really, he tells me. He remembers the experience fondly. "We were having a great time. We were a bunch of actors who really got on well with a director who's the kind of guy who makes you want to work for him, with a real sense of fun. It's an old metaphor, but it's a true one and it works: this guy ends up in the middle of nowhere with nothing, and there he finds peace. I liked that, and it's kind of true - you're in the desert and there's just the ground and the sky."

With roles extending from an accident-prone industrial chemist to one of England's greatest romantic poets, and then on to Shakespeare on stage, Roache - unlike his famous father Bill (who, as Coronation Street's Ken Barlow, is the world's longest-serving soap opera actor) - seems determined not to be defined by any one period or role. How does he choose his projects? "Sometimes out of reaction to what you've just done. If you've just done Wings of the Dove, you don't want to go near the next Merchant-Ivory, but quite often you do get asked to do the same sort of thing immediately again. So I did Shot through the Heart [in which he played a Croatian soldier] after Wings of the Dove, which couldn't be more different. And then Siam Sunset came along.

"I don't have a game plan, a strategy. You just smell your way around. I'm not in a position to just have the pick of the crop, but I am lucky enough to be able to take my time and choose a good job ...something I connect with. Basically I look for a good story."

Three years ago, critics were salivating over his performance in the Henry James adaptation Wings of the Dove, and Hollywood was calling. His breakthrough role in Antonia Bird's Priest in 1994 also led to acclaim on both sides of the Atlantic. So why has he not headed west? Does he envy the international success of his long-time acting associate Ralph Fiennes? "A few years ago I would have said yes," he confesses, but he's not so sure now. "Ralph is extraordinary. I really admire him - we've just spent seven months working together. But as well as carrying it all off, he's got all the responsibilities of a leading star - the publicist, the PA, the lawyers, he's got the whole machine and I don't want all that. I want to make films, I want to do bits of theatre, and do the things that I want to do... It's a lot to handle. I just want to enjoy my freedom and be able to be creative and do more movies. I'd like more choice - I'd like more power in that way, but I don't want to have to deal with all that."

But, he does admit that he would love to work in America, should the right thing came along, whatever that may be. "It's not necessarily an art film," he says. "I love a lot of mainstream movies. I love The Matrix - a genius, brilliant film. I'd love to be part of something big like that. I'd love to work with an American crew and experience a real Hollywood blockbuster. Not having to worry about using up too much film stock and doing too many takes."

Which was a problem he had to contend with on the Julien Temple project. "Pandaemonium was pandemonium," he laughs. Filming began straight after Siam Sunset, and "it was great to go and do something with such a different energy... [Coleridge] is such an extrovert, outwards character, and a lot of the characters I play are introspected, so that was a great shift."

I wonder whether Temple had a personal vendetta against Wordsworth, who is portrayed as a mean-spirited pedant who'd be more fitted to writing parking tickets than soaringly beautiful poetry. "Yes, Coleridge comes out very well," agrees Roache. "I think that was Julien's aim - to redress things. He feels that Wordsworth has been given all this respect for not much, and that, really, Coleridge was the genius." I suspect that Wordsworth fans will be up in arms, while Roache's involving performance as the opium-addicted Coleridge will do wonders towards rejuvenating his appeal, even if Temple's story bears little relation to reality.

Having worked across film, theatre and TV, is Roache one of those actors who claim they only really feel 'alive' on stage? Not so, apparently. "I prefer film, definitely. I like the concentration, the whole atmosphere round the film set, that you're constantly in a state of rehearsal." He compares it to theatre where "every night you have to go the whole nine yards and deliver. But in film, you've got your big scene, and you know it's coming up, and you work towards it, and you work it on that day, and then it's done. There's a certain freedom in that."

But don't most actors claim the opposite, complaining of a lack of freedom and control on the film set? "Yes, it can be frustrating, and I understand completely why actors end up directing and producing, because you are at the mercy of the editor and the director. But I don't have a burning desire to have that kind of power, and I'm quite happy to put myself in the hands of other people. I've been lucky - I've been in good hands, and most of the time I've been enhanced, not reduced by their work."

Roache's disinterest in the 'glamorous' side of the film industry is well documented. After the release of Priest, he ducked out of the limelight to take an 18-month trip through India. When asked how he feels about the flipside of his fame, he counters with, "What do you mean by glamour? What is glamorous about it? If there's glamour there I haven't seen it. Sure, sometimes you get treated very well and stay in nice places, but that's not really glamour."

But surely he feels something about the fact that his chiselled good looks are used to sell movies? "Is it inevitable to be a pin-up?" he muses. "How can you say no to that side of it? It's just the way it is. It's neither good nor bad. I don't court it. I just do that job." He tells me of his recent trip to Tokyo. "[Ralph and I] turned into pop stars. But it's not real. It's some worship thing that's projected onto you. It takes a lot to stay sane in the middle of it all... I'm not going to push it all away, but at the same time I'm not going to start feeding on it or adding to it. It just is what it is."

Roache credits much of his sanity to the spiritual organisation known as FACE (Friends of Andrew Cohen Everywhere) with which he became involved on his Indian pilgrimage. The group teaches spiritual enlightenment and independence through self-enquiry, and Roache is more than happy to talk about it: "Andrew Cohen is a big part of my life - the foundation of my life."

Does he worry about seeing himself and his beliefs ridiculed, as has happened in the past, with the organisation demonised as a cult, and Cohen vilified as a dangerous megalomaniac? "Well, people can read the magazine (What is Enlightenment) and find out for themselves," he says. "There's a lot of cynicism in the world today, but I can't let that stop me. What's wrong with investigating the nature of reality and truth in an unbiased and unprejudiced way?"

As far as his acting's concerned, Roache reckons his beliefs have made him "more relaxed, much less needy." Not that he's pretending it's solved all his problems: "I'm not totally free from all paranoias of acting, but I have a much saner relation with it.

"It's like a wheel - you can go on forever. I'd done film, I'd done TV, I'd done the West End, I'd done the RSC, and it's like: well, ok, what's next? A BIG movie. What's next? Another B-I-I-I-I-G movie. An Oscar! Ten! I thought, 'I don't want that'. So I took the time out to travel and look at things from a different perspective. A lot of people thought I was insane. But you follow your instincts."

Roache strikes me as someone who is incapable of doing anything but follow his instincts. Thinking back to Siam Sunset, he laughs as he remembers that despite his intention to do comedy, he found himself again playing the tragic figure.

"I was so excited to be in a comedy that I started goofing around. The first few days I was throwing a few comic looks and so on, and looking at the rushes, John said, 'I want you to be the tragic figure, the straight man, walking through all this. Let everybody else do the comedy, and let the situation be funny.' And that was quite a renunciation for me because I was wanting to be a little bit goofy as well."

I like the idea of him being a little bit goofy. Maybe the opportunity will present itself. But whatever happens, I feel sure that as long as Linus Roache the man follows those instincts, Linus Roache the actor will continue to be taken seriously.

 Tickets for Thursday's charity premiere of Siam Sunset are available on 020-7419 8109. Siam Sunset is released on November 10. Pandaemonium will be released early next year.

webTitle: You Bet Your Life: week twelve, the expert's view

fields.headline: You Bet Your Life: week twelve, the expert's view
fields.standfirst: Betting site Blue Square gave three Football Unlimited writers £100 each to bet with. Patrick Murray dissects the latest bets
fields.trailText: Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £170.34, Sean Ingle = £113.98, Football Unlimited punters collective = £57.77, Paul MacInnes = £56.46
fields.body:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £170.34, Sean Ingle = £113.98, Football Unlimited punters collective = £57.77, Paul MacInnes = £56.46

Scott Murray:
Middlesbrough v Arsenal, Arsenal to win at half-time £10 @ evens. Bet won £10.

After the metaphorical fireworks of the last few weeks this is a bit of a 5 November cop out by the legendary Mr Murray - a winner, it goes without saying, but a cop out nonetheless. We all know Arsenal are a good team in fine form (although not as impressive away as you might think); we all know Bryan Robson is a liability and that Middlesbrough can't play for toffee without Alen Boksic. It's obvious, and if its obvious the chances are it isn't value. The bookies aren't stupid (for the most part), they know what the man in the street wants to back and they make sure they're not laying value. This certainly isn't the kind of long odds bet we've come to expect from Midas Murray but a winner is a winner and whom am I to argue with the legendary Mr M.

Sean Ingle:
£10 treble, Fulham to beat Huddersfield @ 2/7, Watford to beat Grimsby @ 4/11 and Rangers to beat St Mirren @ 1/5. Bet won £10.82.

It was inevitable this monstrosity would win, I knew that from the moment I saw the bet on Friday. As sure as cheese is cheese Mr I was going to rub my nose in it again.

What can I say about this bet that I haven't said a thousand times before. This is the bet Mr Mug Punter and his millions of acolytes have every week. This is the reason you'll find the bookies cheering for the odds-on shots to be beaten every week and suffering on the rare occasions they're all winners. And this is the reason the bookies win fortunes over a season. Punters see a cert and they think it can't lose, price is irrelevant. 'Certs' do win most of the time but they don't win often enough to justify backing them at such prohibitive odds. And if you put bad value selections in a multiple the value just gets worse.

Fool that I am I really thought Sean had grasped the value nettle and weaned himself off 'easy' winners, to mix metaphors for a moment. The clocks have gone back, my S.A.D. is kicking in, and now this - it's enough to drive a man to despair. And I despair all the more because the damn bet won, so there'll be no incentive for Mr I to listen to a word I say. Still I've done my best, the rest is up to him.

webTitle: How does America choose the next president?

fields.headline: How does America choose the next president?
fields.standfirst: Martin Kettle and Julian Glover explain the complexities of election day in the world's leading democracy
fields.trailText: We explain the complexities of election day in the world's leading democracy.
fields.body:
Who gets to vote?
All US citizens aged over 18 have the right to vote - although this is qualified by a range of conditions, including, in some states, the long-term loss of voting rights by anyone sent to prison (a clause which has disqualified many poor, black citizens in the southern states). Most states allow voters to register to vote until 10 days or so before polling day and in recent years, the process has been simplified. Americans can apply to register online and even when they renew driving licences.

How does polling day work?
Again, the rules vary from state to state: but almost everywhere, voting is a different experience from the same process in Britain. For a start, only 1.7% of voters use British-style ballot papers. Traditionally, Americans vote using mechanical levers (a bit like adding up on an old-style cash register). About a fifth of US votes are still cast this way, but computer technology is taking over. Whichever system is used, the votes are counted quickly. Since polling stations close early in the evening, the result is often declared surprisingly early. Adding to the complexity, though, are America's multiple time zones. Exit polls from some eastern states are available before voters have finished choosing candidates in the west. This can have a big impact on the result.

What happens once the polls have closed?
The votes are counted and results declared state by state. Most international attention will be on the presidential race, but Americans will also vote on a huge range of other jobs, including some state governors, senators, members of the House of Representatives and local officials such as police chiefs. In some states voters also take part in referenda on contentious local issues.

But how does the presidential vote work?
American presidents are not elected directly but through an electoral college. In 48 of the 50 states, the candidate who finishes top collects all of that state's votes in the "electoral college" (in the two oddballs, Maine and Nebraska, the candidate who comes second is given one of the college votes as well).

How is the electoral college organised?
The college has 538 seats. A candidate needs 270 electoral college votes to win. Roughly, college votes are allocated to states by population. As the largest state, California has 54 votes in the electoral college. New York is second with 33. Seven sparsely populated states, plus the District of Columbia, have three votes each, the minimum allowed.

Which states will decide the election?
Mr Gore's hopes now rest absolutely on a victory in Florida, a state with 25 electoral college votes. At one time it seemed likely to go to Mr Bush, but as things have turned out, Mr Gore has been in the lead there in most opinion polls this autumn.

The other fiercely fought state is Pennsylvania (23 votes), where the polls now put Mr Gore ahead. He also needs to win in Michigan (18 votes), where the race has been neck-and-neck and the survey results contradictory, and in Wisconsin (11 votes). And he must squeeze Ralph Nader's Green support to take Minnesota (10), Oregon (7) and Washington state (11).

The most recent electoral college survey by Reuters showed Mr Gore lagging, with 196 votes solid or leaning his way, against Mr Bush's 209. This leaves 133 in states that are too close to call.

Could there be an upset?
Al Gore's Democratic camp hopes to upset the odds by winning the electoral college votes of the handful of key states that are too close to predict. Therefore, Mr Gore may become president even though more people nationwide voted for the Republican Mr Bush.

If that were to happen - a Gore win in the electoral college despite a Bush victory in the popular vote - it will be the third time in US electoral history. In 1876, Rutherford Hayes defeated Samuel Tilden this way, and Benjamin Harrison pipped Grover Cleveland in 1888.

webTitle: Latest Saatchi campaign stars bust of Ken Livingstone

fields.headline: Saatchi's uses Livingtone's bust for museum ads
fields.trailText: 10.15am:Ken Livingstone is the unwitting star of a new press campaign by Saatchi & Saatchi for the Museum of London. By Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
London mayor Ken Livingstone is the unwitting star of a new press campaign by Saatchi & Saatchi for the Museum of London.

Saatchi's is using a Roman-style bust of Mr Livingstone alongside the headline, "London 2000 years before Ken" to promote the museum's High Street Londinium exhibition.

The exhibition has been designed to transport visitors back to AD100 to reveal the sights, sounds and smells of life in Roman London.

The idea behind Saatchi's work is to highlight the parallels between the challenges facing today's mayor and those that faced his predecessor, governor Titus Avedus Quietus.

The poster launches this week to tie in with the Lord Mayor's Show on November 11 and will run as a full page in the official show programme.

It will be supported by a more widespread radio and poster campaign for the Museum of London, which was written by David Fowle and art-directed by Ajab Singh with typograpy by Roger Kennedy.

webTitle: Vivendi boss quashes speculation over future of Canal Plus head

fields.headline: Vivendi boss denies Canal Plus head is to go
fields.trailText: 9.15am:Jean-Marie Messier, boss of French media giant Vivendi, has rubbished speculation that the head of Canal Plus is to leave. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Jean-Marie Messier, chairman of French media giant Vivendi, has rubbished speculation that the head of its Canal Plus subsidiary is on his way out.

Mr Messier described French press reports that Pierre Lescure would be removed as chairman of the pay-TV channel at a board meeting this week as a "joke" and "total disinformation".

Vivendi is set to become a global media force following EU approval of its £66bn merger with Canada's Seagram, the owner of Universal Studios and Universal Music, to form a company called Vivendi Universal.

The company has been beset by rumours of boardroom unrest over the shape of the new organisation, with Mr Lescure often at the centre of the reports.

"There is no board meeting scheduled for this week, and the new positions in Vivendi Universal have been clarified, with Mr Lescure as co-chief operating officer," said a Vivendi spokesperson.

The spokesperson added that no progress had been made on Vivendi's sale of its 23% stake in Rupert Murdoch's BSkyB, which has been ordered by EU regulators as a condition of the Seagram deal.

Mr Messier has a time limit of two years to sell the holding, although he may decide to swap it for a stake in Sky Global Networks, Mr Murdoch's satellite TV operation.

webTitle: Independent to review advertising strategy

fields.headline: Independent announces advertising strategy review
fields.trailText: 8.15am:The Independent, which famously launched with the slogan '"It is...Are You?" is reviewing its advertising strategy, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
The Independent, which famously launched with the slogan '"It is...Are You?" is reviewing its advertising strategy.

The broadsheet is looking for a single media agency to handle its £3m planning and buying business.

Up to now, Zenith has handled the newspaper's media buying account while planning has been handled in house.

Trish Wadley, marketing director at the Independent and Independent on Sunday said that whichever agency was awarded the planning business would automatically win the buying account too.

"We need media planning agency. That's what I'm used to and that's what I want. I want to use a more rich and varied range of media in the future," she said.

Ms Wadley added that she hoped to have an agency in place by the end of month. She confirmed that Zenith and Media Planning would pitch for the business, but declined to name any other agencies in the frame.

She also denied that she was considering a review of the newspaper's creative account held by Euro RSCG Wnek Gosper.

Ms Wadley joined the Independent last month from Thomson Financial, where she was director of marketing and communications for Europe.

webTitle: Randall hits out at BBC's "liberal middle-class agenda"

fields.headline: Randall hits out at BBC's "liberal middle-class agenda"
fields.standfirst: Sunday Business editor Jeff Randall launched an uncompromising attack on the BBC's "liberal middle-class agenda" back in May. His strident views on the BBC's patronising and hostile attitude to business reporting caught Greg Dyke's eye and clinched his future as the BBC's first ever business editor. Here is the full diatribe.
fields.trailText: Sunday Business editor Jeff Randall launched an uncompromising attack on the BBC's "liberal middle-class agenda" back in May. His strident views on the BBC's patronising and hostile attitude to business reporting caught Greg Dyke's eye and clinched his future as the BBC's first ever business editor. Here is the full diatribe.
fields.body:
By Jeff Randall, Sunday Business, May 21 2000.

I was intrigued by the fuss over Andrew Marr's appointment as the BBC's political editor. As a former Labour party member and devotee of the Blair mission, his hiring has caused concern among some Conservatives who fear less-than-impartial reporting from him.

I suspect this will prove unfounded. Marr may not be a great newspaperman - his brief editorship of the Independent was a disaster - but he is long on integrity and will bend over backwards to be fair to those whose views he does not share.

The point here, however is that the BBC does not need Marr to set it on a leftward leaning course, because running through the corporation, from top to bottom, like the word Blackpool through a stick of rock, is a liberal agenda, set by patronising, middle-class, guilt-ridden do-gooders who dominate its corridors.

The worst examples can be heard daily on Radio 4. If this were your only source of news and information, you would inevitably conclude that happily married Anglo-Saxon, heterosexual law-abiding tax-payers are a dying breed on these islands.

No doubt, someone from the BBC will dub me a homophobic racist for saying so - a charge I reject - but Radio 4's programming displays an obsessive obsequiousness to the interests and concerns of social and ethnic minorities, the unemployed, and those who enjoy denigrating conventional values.

The BBC should, of course, cater for all sections of Britain. And that includes financially secure, hard-working citizens (ie, the vast majority), who are proud of this country, content with their lot, and do not regard the Union Jack as a symbol of evil.

Politically correct Radio 4 gives far too much credence to the claims of professional gripers who want compensation, usually in the form of government hand-outs, simply for being less well-off than they would like.

By contrast, the flagship station's coverage of business matters is almost non-existent. The Financial World Tonight was shunted off to the graveyard slot of 11.15pm on Radio 5 long ago.

Business is rarely covered in Radio 4 news bulletins, unless it is a story about a beastly multi-national making workers redundant or fat-cat directors collecting outrageous salaries.

It is as though this country's executive class, whose taxes underpin the funding of the BBC, does not exist.

The BBC's new director general, Greg Dyke, made a personal fortune from business. It's about time he looked at the corporation's institutionalised bias against free-enterprise wealth-creators - and did something about it.
fields.bodyText: By Jeff Randall, Sunday Business, May 21 2000. I was intrigued by the fuss over Andrew Marr's appointment as the BBC's political editor. As a former Labour party member and devotee of the Blair mission, his hiring has caused concern among some Conservatives who fear less-than-impartial reporting from him. I suspect this will prove unfounded. Marr may not be a great newspaperman - his brief editorship of the Independent was a disaster - but he is long on integrity and will bend over backwards to be fair to those whose views he does not share. The point here, however is that the BBC does not need Marr to set it on a leftward leaning course, because running through the corporation, from top to bottom, like the word Blackpool through a stick of rock, is a liberal agenda, set by patronising, middle-class, guilt-ridden do-gooders who dominate its corridors. The worst examples can be heard daily on Radio 4. If this were your only source of news and information, you would inevitably conclude that happily married Anglo-Saxon, heterosexual law-abiding tax-payers are a dying breed on these islands. No doubt, someone from the BBC will dub me a homophobic racist for saying so - a charge I reject - but Radio 4's programming displays an obsessive obsequiousness to the interests and concerns of social and ethnic minorities, the unemployed, and those who enjoy denigrating conventional values. The BBC should, of course, cater for all sections of Britain. And that includes financially secure, hard-working citizens (ie, the vast majority), who are proud of this country, content with their lot, and do not regard the Union Jack as a symbol of evil. Politically correct Radio 4 gives far too much credence to the claims of professional gripers who want compensation, usually in the form of government hand-outs, simply for being less well-off than they would like. By contrast, the flagship station's coverage of business matters is almost non-existent. The Financial World Tonight was shunted off to the graveyard slot of 11.15pm on Radio 5 long ago. Business is rarely covered in Radio 4 news bulletins, unless it is a story about a beastly multi-national making workers redundant or fat-cat directors collecting outrageous salaries. It is as though this country's executive class, whose taxes underpin the funding of the BBC, does not exist. The BBC's new director general, Greg Dyke, made a personal fortune from business. It's about time he looked at the corporation's institutionalised bias against free-enterprise wealth-creators - and did something about it.

Granada Media is expected to announce later today that John Willis, former United Productions chief executive, is staying with the company to run its production business in the south of England.

webTitle: High chance of survival in marathon surgery

fields.headline: High chance of survival in marathon surgery
fields.standfirst:
The background: Conjoined twins

More about Jodie and Mary, the conjoined twins
fields.trailText: The operation to separate the conjoined twins was long and complex but the surgeons at St Mary's believed from the start that Jodie had an excellent chance of surviving.
fields.body:
The operation to separate the conjoined twins was long and complex but the surgeons at St Mary's believed from the start that Jodie had an excellent chance of surviving.

And though she could need more corrective surgery and long-time care, they were confident there was a good chance of her living a full and active life.

Before the operation began yesterday there had already been a huge amount of preparatory work. Scores of x-rays and scans were taken to help build up a detailed picture of what the surgeons could expect.

In the days and weeks leading up to the surgery the 20-strong team, which included neonatal experts, paediatricians, neurosurgeons and anaesthetists, went through the process time and again so they all knew exactly where they had to be and what their jobs were at every point.

In America it is common for teams to practice on models, but it is not known if the St Mary's surgeons adopted this technique.

The team was also asked about their personal views on the surgery. All said they had no views which precluded them from taking part.

It is known the operation began at 8am. If the surgeons followed the normal procedure, the twins would have been anaesthetised by two sets of experts and brain and blood pressure scans set up. This could all have taken an hour or two.

The lead surgeon at St Mary's explained in court that the first part of the operation would include exploring the anatomy of the twins to verify what the scans had suggested. He said they needed to "confirm which bits are definitely whose".

The twins were joined at the abdomen, the lower ends of the spines fused and the spinal cord joined. Each twin had her own brain, heart, lungs, liver and kidneys. The crucial and unique feature is the shared blood supply, with Jodie's heart pumping blood around her body's and that of her twin.

Once the anatomy had been checked, the first incision would have been made, taking into account how the wound would be closed. Usually the first incision is made from the back, then the children are turned over and an incision made in the front.

In previous cases, this part of the surgery has taken anything between four and 18 hours. There is no particular hurry - the children could be kept stable under anaesthetic for 24 hours.

The plan was to separate the pelvic bones, then the spinal bones. The surgeons then intended to focus on the pelvic floor.

Throughout this part of the operation, Mary was expected to be alive. When the surgeons severed the two major blood vessels linking the twins - the continuation of Jodie's aorta which was taking oxygenated blood to Mary and the vena cava, which was returning unoxygenated blood from Mary to Jodie - the weaker twin would die.

The rest of the operation would then be, again in the words of the lead surgeon - who cannot be named for legal reasons - "essentially a reconstructive operation" for Jodie. For instance, her pelvic bones would have to be broken to allow the legs to be brought into place. She would also have needed skin grafts, possibly using tissue from her dead sister.

Though the operation was expected to take 15 hours, the surgeons and support staff would have taken regular breaks, perhaps every three or four hours. However, the work was bound to be exhausting.

Only a bare minimum of medics would have been allowed into the operating theatre. Students may have been allowed to watch via a CCTV link.

Lewis Spitz, of Great Ormond Street, who has taken part in 12 separations - though he has no direct knowledge of Jodie and Mary - said that the surgeons would have to expect the unexpected. He said: "They will have done all the preparatory work but could encounter something unexpected. Then the surgeons have to think on their feet and change their schedule and plan."

Because the surgeons have been able to choose the time of the operation, Jodie has an excellent chance of surviving. The St Mary's team believes that there is only a 6% chance of her perishing.

There were concerns, however, that Jodie's heart could fail at the time of separation. Doctors concede that in the worst case scenario, Jodie may not walk and could suffer double incontinence.

She has an anatomically sound heart, lungs and liver. Her bowel is also normal and separate from Mary's. She has two kidneys and a full spinal cord, but was born with one abnormal vertabra. She has two normal, functioning arms and legs, though the latter were widely spaced.

She is believed to have a normal brain and normal intelligence. A neonatalist described her as "very sparkling, wriggling, very alert, sucking on a dummy and using her upper limbs in an appropriate manner, very much a 'with it' sort of baby."

Surgeons believe they can give her a good quality and long life. The lead surgeon at St Mary's said: "There is nothing which suggests that the life expectancy should be any shorter than normal ... Jodie's problems are functional, not life-threatening."

They believe that she should be able to walk normally, go to an ordinary school, walk unaided, and have children.

But it is possible that she could need a colostomy and reconstruction of her rectum and sexual organs.

webTitle: Doctors separate twins

fields.headline: Doctors separate twins
fields.standfirst: More about Jodie and Mary's case
fields.trailText:
Doctors who performed complex surgery to separate conjoined twins Jodie and Mary are today expected to reveal details of the operation.
More about Jodie and Mary's case
fields.body:
Doctors who performed complex surgery to separate conjoined twins Jodie and Mary are today expected to reveal details of the operation.

The controversial separation, which was set to kill the weaker twin Mary, started at 9am yesterday and surgeons worked late into the night. Officials at St Mary's Hospital, Manchester, today remained tight-lipped about the results of the operation, but were expected to reveal its outcome later.

The girls' parents had opposed the surgery during a complex legal battle but were understood to have stayed at the hospital while they waited for the operation to be completed. The team of 20 medics was aiming to work to save Jodie but had not ruled out the possibility that she could be paralysed by the operation.

If successful, the surgery could allow Jodie to lead a relatively normal life, doctors said. Mary's death was always inevitable if the separation went ahead as she was born severely disabled and had survived because of her link with her sister, but surgeons warned both girls would die without the operation. The girls were born at the Manchester hospital in August and were born with fused spines which left them joined at the abdomen.

Doctors were given permission to separate the girls by the High Court after the twins' parents opposed the surgery. The strict Roman Catholic couple, from the Maltese island of Gozo, did not want the operation to go ahead for religious reasons, believing nature should be allowed to take its course.

webTitle: Fox Kids Europe beefs up online team

fields.headline: Fox Kids Europe beefs up online team
fields.trailText: 8.15am: Fox Kids Europe has shored up its new online and interactive division with a number of high profile appointments. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Fox Kids Europe has shored up its new online and interactive division with a number of high profile appointments.

Five new managerial appointments have been made as part of Fox's strategy to build a strong interactive playground for kids across Europe. The European online division now numbers 30 staff.

Maurice Van Sabben, formerly head of development, digital services at Spanish cable firm Ono, has been appointed director of business development, Online & Interactive.

Nick Harris from Dorling Kindersley joins the division as creative director; Phil Guest from Capital Interactive joins as general manager; Jason Robinson, also former of Dorling Kindersley, has been appointed head of design; and Tom Jahr from Norwegian-based games developer Bonnier Multimedia, joins as general manager of Fox Kids Scandinavia's online and interactive division.

Natalie Hugh, managing director of online and interactive at FKE, said: "Our aim is to become the leading online entertainment brand for children in Europe and the contribution made by Maurice, Nick, Jason, Phil and Tom will play a very significant part."

At present, FKE operates eleven websites in the UK, The Netherlands, France, Sweden, Denmark, Norway, Spain, Italy, Poland, Romania and Russia, with more regional websites planned.

webTitle: Willis stays, Wall goes from Granada

fields.headline: Willis stays, Wall goes, Granada confirms
fields.trailText: Granada Media has appointed John Willis and Marcus Plantin to new roles working across LWT and United Productions, as managing director and director of programmes, respectively.
fields.body:
Granada Media has appointed John Willis and Marcus Plantin to new roles working across LWT and United Productions, as managing director and director of programmes, respectively.

And it confirmed tonight that former United Broadcasting & Entertainment chief executive Malcolm Wall will be leaving the company shortly

The restructuring follows Granada's acquisition of United two months ago.

Mr Willis, who was chief executive of United Productions will also take responsibility for developing international factual programming.

Mr Plantin, formerly LWT director of programmes, will retain his brief to work across international entertainment programming.

Another senior UBE executive, chief operating officer John Cresswell, has been appointed director of operations at Granada Media.

Mr Willis and Mr Plantin will report to Granada Creative executive chair Andrea Wonfor and oversee around 1,500 hours of programming annually, worth £175m.

In addition, Mr Willis will be responsible for bringing together Granada Kids with United Children's and Manchester-based animation studio Cosgrove Hall.

Granada also confirmed that the managing directors of Meridian and Anglia, Mary McAnally and Graham Creelman would retain their positions.

webTitle: Leading internet publishers sign up to Sidewize navigation tool

fields.headline: Internet publishers sign up Sidewize browser tool
fields.trailText: 8.15am:Leading internet publishers have signed up to Sidewize, a new 'browser companion' tool that makes it easier to navigate the web. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
GuardianUnlimited, the Times Online and FT.com are among 39 of the leading internet publishers to have signed up to Sidewize, a new 'browser companion' tool that makes it easier to navigate the web.

The product is being launched today by Connextra, a technology company focused on information-based software.

David King Lassman, founder and chief executive of Connextra, explained that Sidewize would make the internet more easily accessible for users.

He said the need for an add-on browser was borne out of the increasingly frustrating experience of using the web.

Sidewize is a side bar that sits on the right of the browser window suggesting links to other relevant content on signed up publishers' websites.

For instance, if a user is viewing a story on FT.com about the BBC, Sidewize will suggest they visit Mediatheguardian.com to read additional stories and information. To this end, the tool is mainly a traffic builder but also has potential for targeted advertising.

Lucy Wood, head of active travel at Emap Online, which has signed 1Ski.com up to Sidewize, said: "Sidewize allows us to stick by our users providing them with invaluable timely information relevant to their current web activity.

"We hope to launch many additional services that give leverage to the Sidewize technology in the near future."

Other content partners include Ticketmaster, ZDNet, Motley Fool, dotmusic, Britannica, Ask Jeeves, Lonely Planet, TeamTalk and Firebox.

Sidewize is the first product to be launched by Connextra, which has raised almost £6m in funding.

webTitle: Roche Consumer Health backs Recharge launch with £5m

fields.headline: Roche Consumer Health puts £5m behind Recharge
fields.trailText: 8.15am: Roche Consumer Health is putting £5m behind the TV launch of its multivitamin brand, Recharge, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Roche Consumer Health is putting £5m behind the TV launch of its multivitamin brand, Recharge.

The campaign will target 25 to 45-year-old adults burned out by the demands of modern living, busy women struggling to balance the demands of family and career.

The ads have been created by D'Arcy and will break nationally on November 9 marking the first time the brand has received such advertising support.

Malcolm Peters, board account director at D'Arcy, said: "The commercial is very different from anything else in the multivitamins sector and the original idea will help to create real standout for the brand."

Supradyn Recharge ads will feature the antics of a little man who lives inside a family radio and who is responsible for producing the music and commentary for each family member's favourite station. He is seen performing easy listening for mum, football commentary for dad and rap for the teenage son.

Charlotte Charnock, brand leader at Roche Consumer Health, said: "This is one of the most exciting product launches in this sector for some time and demonstrates our commitment to developing brands internationally."

The ad was written by Mark Gilmore, art directed by Neil Bishop and directed by Jeremy Webb of 2AM Films. Media planning and buying is by Mediacom TMB.

webTitle: Another day, another attempt to prop up single currency fails

fields.headline: Another day, another attempt to prop up single currency fails
fields.standfirst: Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: The European Central Bank yesterday turned its financial firepower on the foreign exchange market for the second trading day in a row but failed to give the struggling euro more than a temporary boost.
fields.body:
The European Central Bank yesterday turned its financial firepower on the foreign exchange market for the second trading day in a row but failed to give the struggling euro more than a temporary boost.

The move helped the single currency climb more than half a cent to above the 87-cent level against the dollar but the recovery was undermined by figures showing the German economy could be slowing with the euro slumping to pre-intervention levels. By late trading the euro had fallen to just above 86 cents.

The ECB refused to comment on how much it had spent yesterday in support of the euro but said that it had acted unilaterally as it had on Friday. Dealers suggested the amounts involved were relatively modest and there is a growing belief that the ECB will be forced into further intervention.

The ECB "can't just suddenly stop because then everyone would ask 'do these guys have any intervention strategy at all?'," said Stefan Schneider, an economist at Deutsche Bank in Frankfurt.

The ECB is concerned that the weakness of the euro, which has lost more than a quarter of its value since it was launched at the beginning of last year, could lead to an increase in inflation in the eurozone.

Currency analysts at ABN Amro in London, however, questioned the effectiveness of continued intervention. "It is a truly dangerous game, as they are fighting against long-term flows that are still euro negative and flows that will generally not respond to intervention raids."

But other analysts suggested that intervention campaigns required considerable patience and it could be several months before the effectiveness of the ECB's strategy could be judged.

Yesterday's market operation was backed by support from Romano Prodi, the president of the European Commission. He shrugged off criticism of the ECB and said the strength of the European economy would lead to a higher euro. "The baby is growing up well", he said.

Mr Prodi was speaking at a press conference following a speech to the CBI in which he appealed for the public to give the ECB time to bed down. "When you look at the history of the US Federal Reserve you find it took 20 years to work properly. Please let us have two years. We don't need 20 years but give us two."

Asked whether he had confidence in the bank's president, Wim Duisenberg, Mr Prodi replied: "Of course. I think the euro is growing up and the central bank is working well in all its main tasks.

"The level of the rate of exchange is weak but I think that will change in the future because the fundamentals are good."

fields.headline: Public backs away from fuel tax protests
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Public backing for the fuel protesters is falling, with support for blockades down to 55% as concern grows over the threat to petrol and food supplies, according to a Guardian/ICM survey published today.
fields.body:
Public backing for the fuel protesters is falling, with support for blockades down to 55% as concern grows over the threat to petrol and food supplies, according to a Guardian/ICM survey published today.

The poll findings suggest that farmers and hauliers risk a backlash if they try to bring Britain to a standstill when the government refuses tomorrow to bow to their demands for a big cut in fuel tax.

A majority of the public would still back further disruption but support appears to be declining. The backing found by ICM is marginally down on poll results published at the weekend and well below the groundswell of support during September's protest when 80% backed the protesters' aims.

ICM found 39% of the public, including a majority of Labour voters, opposed any new blockades, as the home secretary Jack Straw claimed that the government was finally winning the propaganda battle.

The government's hand will also be strengthened after the survey found that a clear majority of voters, 56%, believe that raising pensions should take priority over reducing the cost of motoring.

Tony Blair and Gordon Brown will hold separate meetings with pensioners' leaders today, ahead of the chancellor's pre-budget statement tomorrow in which the elderly are expected to do better than the hauliers.

With the single pension expected to go up by £5 a week and that of a married couple by £8, fuel duty is likely to be frozen for two years - worth 2p a litre this financial year - rather than cut.

Mr Straw said: "The public understands that there are competing priorities for the same money, not least the claim of the pensioners."

Rodney Bickerstaffe, the retiring head of the Unison public service workers union, said: "A £5 increase may offer a short-term boost to pensions, but unless a regular uprating such as the link with earnings is restored, the state pension will continue to wither on the vine."

Improving public transport and cutting fares is also favoured by the government over cheaper motoring, but the longer-term damage to Labour inflicted by the fuel crisis is underlined by the poll, which shows Labour stuck on 40% and the Conservatives dropping by one point to 34%.

September's Tory lead has been reversed, though Labour's relatively slender advantage will heighten the pressure on Mr Brown to use his pre-budget statement as an electoral springboard.

Aware of the potential unpopularity of new demonstra tions, protest leaders have attempted to row back during recent days from earlier threats to disrupt Britain as tensions surface within the network of hauliers and farmers over how to press home their demands.

Support for the petrol protesters, according to the Guardian/ ICM survey, is greatest among the truckers' own C2 social grouping.

Mr Brown yesterday warned the Confederation of British Industry conference in Birmingham that the 26p fuel tax cut demanded by some protesters would drive up interest rates and jeopardise the economy. "The budget will respond to the genuine concerns of hauliers and motorists but I will do nothing that would risk returning the economy to 1980s boom and bust," he said.

Mr Blair's deputy spokesman, Godric Smith, gave clear endorsement to a threat by Mike Hodgkinson, the BAA chief executive, that his company would take out injunctions against any protesters who blocked the M25 and thereby impeded travel to and from Heathrow, Gatwick and Stansted airports.

Heathrow alone has 100,000 workers and ships £60bn worth of cargo a year, Mr Hodgkinson told the airport's transport forum.

His warnings are the latest twist in the government's get-tough rhetoric since steps were instigated, after the September blockades, to counter any similar action in the future.

In a significant move, the Tory leader William Hague and Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor, both rejected in advance hints that Mr Brown will merely freeze petrol duties. They are convinced that ministers are "so out of touch" they do not understand public anger at their "stealth taxes".

Complaining that the government now looks liked a flooded village - "awash with problems, increasingly without power and cut off from the rest of the world" - Mr Hague will today accuse Mr Blair of allowing a real sense of crisis to engulf the country on issues as different as railway paralysis, the NHS and high taxes.

ICM interviewed a random sample of 1,001 adults aged 18 and over by telephone from November 3-5. Interviews were conducted across the country and the results have been weighted to the profile of all adults.

webTitle: Protesters' split deepens amid blockade retreat

fields.headline: Protesters' split deepens amid blockade retreat
fields.standfirst:
Hauliers: Talk of mayhem denounced as 'poppycock'

Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Hauliers: Talk of mayhem denounced as 'poppycock'.
fields.body:
Divisions among the fuel tax protesters intensified yesterday as the chairman of the largest truckers' organisation accused protest organisers of operating in a clandestine and undemocratic way, while other campaign leaders dissociated themselves from threats of further disruption.

Mark Francis, who has effectively sidelined David Handley as chief spokesman for the People's Fuel Lobby after dissension over his role within the group, said calls for mayhem by other leaders had been misreported and that next week's motorway demonstration should not be disruptive.

"The aim is not to block the motorway," Mr Francis said of the lorry convoy scheduled to leave Jarrow on Friday for a London demonstration next Tuesday. "The vehicles should travel at a safe speed and listen to the police. All this talk of mayhem is poppycock."

The pronouncement represents a retreat from recent threats of renewed blockades - against fuel distribution centres and railways and action to disrupt the national grid - if the chancellor, Gordon Brown, fails to meet protesters' demands for a sharp cut in fuel duty.

It is also in sharp contrast with remarks made by Nigel Kime, spokesman of British Hauliers Unite and a member of Mr Francis's group, who was quoted yesterday as warning that if the truckers were prevented from demonstrating in London, they would "bugger up three major airports".

The British Airports Authority yesterday threatened injunctions against fuel protest leaders if there were attempts to blockade the M25 or airports.

Mr Francis argued that Mr Kime had not been reported accurately and said: "Anyone who goes to the national grid, the railways or food distribution centres will be taking their own and other people's lives into their hands. It would be a very irresponsible act".

Meanwhile, the People's Fuel Lobby came under attack from John Bridge, chairman of the Road Haulage Association - also John Major's Tory constituency chairman in Huntingdon - for using "clandestine and undemocratic" methods. Mr Bridge said he and like-minded others had been excluded from the People's Fuel Lobby, even though the RHA represented 10,000 hauliers.

The continuing dissension among the protest leaders reflects both tactical and personality differences and a realisation they have lost crucial allies and the element of surprise that helped make the September refinery blockades so successful.

The anti-fuel tax alliance, which two months ago became the focus for wider anti-government discontent, has already begun to fracture in the face of government preparations for a second round.

Differences of interest between farmers and hauliers have manifested within the protest groups, which have now also been heavily infiltrated by police special branch. The oil companies, whose passivity towards the September blockades was a vital element in their success, are back in harness with the government.

The Tory leadership, which was singing the praises of the "fine upstanding citizens" who led the blockades, has distanced itself from further disruption and newspapers which backed the September protests are now urging caution.

Most significantly, the Daily Mail, which played a key role as a focus for the anti-fuel tax protest movement both before and during the blockades has told the farmers and hauliers to "think long and hard about taking further action".

Few on the protesters' side believe whatever concessions Mr Brown makes tomorrow will measure up to demands. But the expectation is increasingly that, while disruptive protests are almost certain to resume next week, they are unlikely to have the national impact of the September upheaval.

webTitle: Sketch: Back to the domesday scenario

fields.headline: Back to the domesday scenario
fields.trailText: The cry of "doomed, doomed, we are all doomed!" has been going up from ministers over the past two weeks as they contemplate the horrors of global warming. They seem to believe that 2p off a litre of petrol will turn the planet into a spinning ball of dust, or alternatively a great sodden sponge. Our fate changes month by month.
fields.body:
The cry of "doomed, doomed, we are all doomed!" has been going up from ministers over the past two weeks as they contemplate the horrors of global warming. They seem to believe that 2p off a litre of petrol will turn the planet into a spinning ball of dust, or alternatively a great sodden sponge. Our fate changes month by month.

Tories are less interested, since it is hard even for them to blame bad weather on the government. Instead they have been yelling "domed, domed, we are all domed!"

They made a pretty poor job of attacking the giant yellow dutch cap in Greenwich, too. Peter Ainsworth, who has forgotten that the dome was a Tory idea, almost hyperventilated.

"I think 'e's been on the poppers again," said Dennis Skinner, and I don't suppose he meant the things you do up a duvet cover with.

John Wilkinson said that Lord Falconer, who is sole shareholder of the company which runs the dome, said he should do the honourable thing and resign.

This is normal political knockabout, but the minister, Janet Anderson, chose to treat the remark as if Mr Wilkinson had suggested Lord Falconer should be pegged out naked on the dome, smeared with treacle and have a bucket of soldier ants sprinkled on top. "I shall treat the cheap point he makes in the way it deserves," she sniffed. Whatever people say about the dome, no-one has called it cheap.

Peter Ainsworth returned. Why shouldn't Lord Falconer resign? he asked.

Ms Anderson was outraged all over again. "Lord Falconer is doing an extremely good job, and the answer is no!" Had Mr Ainsworth suggested that the Queen should be humanely put down to save money, she could not have sounded more appalled - which is what ministers do when they know what they are defending is indefensible.

David Treddinick, the Tory MP for Bosworth, demanded to know why so much public money had been spent without turning a profit. He should be an expert, since he is one of those MPs who, in the Major administration, tried to turn a profit by agreeing to take cash for parliamentary questions.

"If something is not done," he announced, "the ball and chain will be on the front of the next Labour manifesto!" (In this he is right, but it will be Jack Straw's latest scheme for dealing with truancy.)

Bizarrely, Tony Banks switched from the dome to that other unloved pile, Portcullis House, the £230m giant crematorium which serves as MPs' offices. "It is absolutely stunning!" he announced, having said that it looked just like a Novotel. He wanted the public to be admitted. "We should let people see what their taxpayers' money has gone into."

I can't think why. The atrium is a mad jumble of annoying decoration, as if a small boy with Lego, Meccano, plasticine and a pencil box had been asked to do the decor, blindfold. Taxpayers would be furious.

Suddenly the mood changed. Once a month, the Commons hears the murmur of organ music, sniffs the odour of incense, and the benches become pews as Stuart Bell MP, a Church commissioner, answers questions. I lied about the incense, but the place does calm down. (Mind you, the average Anglican church is rather better attended on a Sunday than the Commons on a Monday.) "Welcome to your first commissioners' questions, Mr Speaker," Mr Bell intoned. "This is a non-partisan session, and we are protected from on high."

This seemed a little steep. Does Mr Bell really imagine that God likes to brew a tea, pull up his chair in front of cable TV and say, "Ooh, this is my favourite bit of the month"?

webTitle: Plan for haulage shakeup

fields.headline: Plan for haulage shakeup
fields.standfirst:
Options: Ministers offer freeze and aid to quit business industry

Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Options: Ministers offer freeze and aid to quit business industry.
fields.body:
The government has after weeks of debate decided to face down the fuel protesters, but is to offer instead a mix of concessions designed to speed a restructuring of the haulage industry.

Ministers have decided to freeze fuel duty for the general motorist - in effect a real terms cut of 2p - since duty will not be uprated in line with inflation. The freeze may be extended for a further year.

In view of the huge hike in fuel prices even since the last September protest, this hardly represents a major concession. Fuel prices have risen by between 2p and 4p in most petrol forecourts over the past few weeks.

Lord Macdonald, the transport minister, has rejected evidence of 30% over-capacity in the industry, arguing the statistics are four years out of date and based on doubtful methodology. Nevertheless, he appears attracted to the idea of scrappage allowance, under which the government would pay hauliers to leave the industry. This would be linked to an increase in the cost to hauliers of the special licence needed to enter the industry. He has also examined the degree to which foreign truckers are penetrating the British industry and concluded competition in hauling goods across the channel has become more intense.

This suggests he will accept the case for a Britdisc in which foreign hauliers will have to pay a tax to use British roads. The proposal will not breach EU law so long as the disc is also imposed on British hauliers, but matching compensation would be offered to British hauliers through lower rates of vehicle excise duty.

Ministers also want to help rural motorists more dependent on petrol. The government has rejected lower vehicle excise duty based on the owners' postcode.

But ministers are attracted to relaxing business duties on rural petrol stations, many of which could be regarded as a social service.

Some form of windfall tax on the oil companies is also ruled out. The measure would hit some marginal seats in eastern England and Scotland.

It would also infuriate the powerful oil barons many of whom have been investigated by the competition authorities only less than two years ago.

However, the office of fair trading may give the oil companies a blast for trying to squeeze out independent petrol retailers.

webTitle: Majority puts pensions before fuel tax

fields.headline: Majority puts pensions before fuel tax
fields.standfirst:
ICM poll Support and criticism for Labour

Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: ICM poll Support and criticism for Labour.
fields.body:
Tony Blair and Gordon Brown's decision to put the elderly at the front of the cash queue ahead of motorists has widespread support among voters, according to a Guardian/ICM poll published today.

The public by a clear majority of 56% to 36% think priority should be given to raising pensions against reducing the cost of motoring.

Ministers have repeatedly claimed lower fuel could only be paid for by cuts in public services or help for other groups and, after playing up the value of potential increases in pensions, will give the findings a cautious welcome.

They will be concerned, however, that the 18 to 34-year-old group still wants cheaper motoring but the prime minister and chancellor will take heart from the figures when they meet pensioners' leaders today.

Mr Brown will be walking a political tightrope tomorrow when he makes his pre-budget statement after the Guardian/ ICM poll produced distinctly mixed results for the government. The permanent damage Labour has suffered as a result of the fuel crisis is underlined by voting intentions, which suggest the double-figure "comfort zone" leads the government enjoyed for so long really are history.

Labour is unchanged on 40% and the Conservatives dipped one point to 34% to confirm that September's Tory lead after the crisis erupted was short-lived. The Liberal Democrats are up one on the month to 20%.

Of the two issues - pensions and petrol - likely to feature most in Mr Brown's statement, he can take only limited comfort from the poll.

Mr Brown will be happy his drive to target financial aid on the least well off pensioners appears to have public support, 55% wanting him to concentrate extra spending on the poorest pensioners compared with 42% believing priority should be given to increasing the state pension.

Here again there is a sting in the tail for the chancellor with the position reversed among the group most directly affected - pensioners still smarting from this year's 75p rise in the single person's pension.

Those 65 and over gave the state pension priority by 55% to 39%, a position endorsed by a more narrow 52%-47% among Tories.

The scale of the "grey vote" revolt triggered by the 75p rise can be gauged from the Tory lead among OAPs, 49% to 27%.

The poll shows the government could face an even bigger struggle over the single currency than it does over fuel. Support for the euro is down three points this year to 18%, opposition up two to 71%.
