webTitle: End of the line

fields.headline: End of the line
fields.standfirst: Public-private partnership for the tube is unpopular even with London's new transport chief. An alternative should be found
fields.trailText: Public-private partnership for the tube is unpopular even with London's new transport chief. An alternative should be found.
fields.body:
It is becoming less and less likely the government's public-private partnership (PPP) to improve and expand London's tube will see the light of day.

Here comes Bob Kiley from New York as transport commissioner and with him a chance to resolve the funding question once for all. He demonstrated that investment in a municipally owned urban railway can be secured and he knows how to do it. Mr Kiley, in London yesterday full of doubts about the government scheme, starts full-time in January.

The PPP proposed three separate 30-year contracts with private companies which would do track and signalling plus a fourth public company running trains. Even before the Hatfield crash it was unpopular and poorly understood.

The crash eroded confidence in the ability of a private company to manage a railway. The inquiries into Paddington and other accidents may or may not conclude that privatisation was a factor but the general public will see PPP as more of the "fragmentation" that ministers have themselves condemned. It is also inconsistent to devolve power to a London authority, then expect the mayor and commissioner to be responsible for deals negotiated for them by Whitehall.

In any case, the sheer complexity of negotiations make it uncertain the PPP deal will be completed by the latest target date - April 2001, already a year late. Labour faces the prospect of an election campaign without having achieved any of its 1987 objectives for the tube, whilst incurring vast expense on consultants.

There are two alternatives to PPP. One is to simply keep the tube under the direct control of central government. This could have been accepted without more ado from the beginning. A much more sensible alternative would be to pass it to the mayor and leave him to decide how to pay for investment. Mr Kiley's proven experience teamed with Mr Livingstone's strong electoral mandate should be quite a force.

But how to pay? Some new method needs to be found and while the American experience of using revenue bonds is useful, there is work to be done to establish such a scheme in the UK.

The ball has to land in the Greater London Authority's court. Contrary to popular belief, the PPP relates only to the underground as it is and the GLA will have to find ways to finance any new tube lines. Second, the mayor is committed to introducing congestion charging. This will make much more sense as part of transport strategy if part of the revenue can be capitalised to finance trains and buses.

A "plan B" is going to be needed anyway. The government can proceed with the PPP only if the independent health and safety executive says it is safe and the national audit office certifies it gives value for money. The absence of either could stop the PPP and it would be intolerable to suffer further delay.

A different approach would involve issuing bonds under the GLA's auspices. Two types are possible: government-guaranteed bonds (such as those for the Channel tunnel rail link) or "revenue bonds", backed by dedicated revenues, without government guarantee. The Americans use a "public benefit corporation" through which government retains control but management and finance are done separately. New York's metropolitan transportation authority is an example.

Here trusts were common in the 18th century as a means of funding and procuring local services - they were the very beginnings of local government. The port of London authority was created in 1908 as a public trust agency with the capacity to issue its own bonds, secured by port revenues. It still exists. The London passenger transport board, existed as a trust from 1933 to 1948, with Treasury authority to issue bonds for capital investment.

For argument's sake, if a London body issued bonds for a term of 30 years paying 7.5% a year, London Underground's operating surplus of £250m a year could support a bond issue of approximately £3bn. Every £100m a year of added cash would support bonds worth £1.2bn. That added cash could be government grant (which would be forthcoming in any case under the PPP) or special fees or levies. This type of financing structure could accommodate other kinds of capital spending as London's local government develops. The chart shows how income from fares generates a surplus over running costs, but not enough to pay for needed investment.

The counter argument is that bonds would leave London Transport's poor-quality management intact. But Mr Kiley will expect to seek efficiencies and it would be perfectly possible for bond issues to be invested in pro jects where private firms are brought in to manage projects or goods and services procured using the best business practice.

The point is that there are precedents for almost any financing structure. One of the advantages of the way we are governed is that almost anything can be created - though enabling legislation might be required. It is a matter of government deciding how, realistically, it wishes to achieve its ends. When that is done, Treasury rules and local government financing restrictions can be varied to accommodate the policy, as has happened often enough in the past. All it needs is the GLA and the central government to sit down together to design a workable capital funding arrangement for London.

Stephen Glaister is professor of transport at Imperial College, London

webTitle: Pakistan enters arms market

fields.headline: Pakistan enters arms market
fields.trailText: Pakistan will hold one of the world's biggest defence shows later this month, making its first attempt to break into the lucrative international arms export market.
fields.body:
Pakistan will hold one of the world's biggest defence shows later this month, making its first attempt to break into the lucrative international arms export market.

The military government hopes to sell tanks and ammunition to countries such as Zimbabwe, Rwanda, Indonesia and Malaysia, and administrative bodies such as the Palestinian Authority.

At least 34 countries with a combined arms budget of $20bn (£13.8bn) will send delegations to the four-day "Arms for Peace" exhibition in Karachi.

"The delegations coming are for business. They are serious about buying," the show's organiser, Major-General Ali Hamid, said last night.

"Unfortunately, to date we have not had a very focused marketing and selling of our defence products. Defence is not something that has been commercialised in this country."

Pakistan has long been a major importer of defence equipment, particularly its navy, which has bought Agosta 90-B submarines from France and British Sea King helicopters.

Its generals will be looking for air-defence systems and radar to buy during the show, Gen Hamid said. But they will also be keen to export goods.

Most Pakistani-made defence equipment is produced by state-owned companies, although a handful of small private firms make components such as fuses and bomb casings. "Ammunition is one of our strongest areas," the general said.

Pakistan Ordnance Factories, the country's biggest producer of defence equipment, will be seeking to sell artillery and tank ammunition, he said.

The army also hopes to sell its upgraded version of the T-59 tank, the Al-Zarrar, which is equipped with a 125mm gun with computer guidance and improved composite armour.

No nuclear devices or surface-to-surface missile systems will be on offer, although missile systems will be on display.

Gen Hamid said Pakistan had no ban on selling arms to specific countries. "I don't think we have a problem on that score. Maybe Israel we wouldn't like to sell weapons to," he said. Pakistan would also be unlikely to sell to its arch-rival India.

All major British defence contractors were invited to attend the show but declined because of concern about the military regime which seized power in Pakistan a year ago.

"They said with the Commonwealth policy towards this country that they couldn't exhibit," said Asim Siddiqui, chairman of Pegasus Consultancy, which is arranging the show. "But we have been given assurances that they will be here for the next show in 2002."

Land Rover, which is now owned by Ford, will have a stand.

"[A deal] is in the pipeline and will involve more than 1,000 Land Rovers," Gen Hamid said. "Our requirement is fairly large, we are a seven-corps army."

They are serious about buying," the show's organiser, Major-General Ali Hamid, said last night. "Unfortunately, to date we have not had a very focused marketing and selling of our defence products. Defence is not something that has been commercialised in this country." Pakistan has long been a major importer of defence equipment, particularly its navy, which has bought Agosta 90-B submarines from France and British Sea King helicopters. Its generals will be looking for air-defence systems and radar to buy during the show, Gen Hamid said. But they will also be keen to export goods. Most Pakistani-made defence equipment is produced by state-owned companies, although a handful of small private firms make components such as fuses and bomb casings. "Ammunition is one of our strongest areas," the general said. Pakistan Ordnance Factories, the country's biggest producer of defence equipment, will be seeking to sell artillery and tank ammunition, he said. The army also hopes to sell its upgraded version of the T-59 tank, the Al-Zarrar, which is equipped with a 125mm gun with computer guidance and improved composite armour. No nuclear devices or surface-to-surface missile systems will be on offer, although missile systems will be on display. Gen Hamid said Pakistan had no ban on selling arms to specific countries. "I don't think we have a problem on that score. Maybe Israel we wouldn't like to sell weapons to," he said. Pakistan would also be unlikely to sell to its arch-rival India. All major British defence contractors were invited to attend the show but declined because of concern about the military regime which seized power in Pakistan a year ago. "They said with the Commonwealth policy towards this country that they couldn't exhibit," said Asim Siddiqui, chairman of Pegasus Consultancy, which is arranging the show. "But we have been given assurances that they will be here for the next show in 2002." Land Rover, which is now owned by Ford, will have a stand. "[A deal] is in the pipeline and will involve more than 1,000 Land Rovers," Gen Hamid said. "Our requirement is fairly large, we are a seven-corps army."

webTitle: Software firm's fortunes turn

fields.headline: Software firm's fortunes turn
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Terence Chapman Group, the banking software specialists, yesterday claimed that a new wave of businesses investing in internet projects had turned the company's fortunes around after the millennium bug had paralysed consultancy work at the turn of the century.
fields.body:
Terence Chapman Group, the banking software specialists, yesterday claimed that a new wave of businesses investing in internet projects had turned the company's fortunes around after the millennium bug had paralysed consultancy work at the turn of the century.

"We have nearly doubled our consultancy projects since that period, which was a curious time for us - and very much in the past now," said Terence Chapman, who floated the group in June last year and remains chief executive.

The company, whose clients include Charles Schwab Europe, Deutsche Bank and JP Morgan, had signalled in February that performance for the year to end of August would "fall short of expectations".

But yesterday the results came in at the top end of revised forecasts. Turnover was at £30.9m for the full year, up a modest £300,000 on the previous year, and pretax profit at £4.1m, down £400,000.

Mr Chapman said: "A huge new phase of internet adoption is under way. This time it is bigger and deeper - a real phase of integration online - with £3m, £5m, even £10m, projects being taken up." He cited deals the group had struck with ABN Amro, Bradford & Bingley and JP Morgan.

The group's share price yesterday rose 6.5p to 292.5p.

webTitle: Bin Laden quits base to dodge US reprisal

fields.headline: Bin Laden quits base to dodge US reprisal
fields.trailText: Osama bin Laden, America's most wanted terrorist, has left his main camp in Afghanistan because of the imminent threat of a US missile strike and moved to a secret base in the Hindu Kush mountains, according to a diplomatic source in Kandahar.
fields.body:
Osama bin Laden, America's most wanted terrorist, has left his main camp in Afghanistan because of the imminent threat of a US missile strike and moved to a secret base in the Hindu Kush mountains, according to a diplomatic source in Kandahar.

Mr Bin Laden, who is suspected by US officials of being connected with the attack last month on a US warship in Yemen, left the disused air base near the southern desert city of Kandahar on October 22. His convoy of 15 or 16 four-wheel drive trucks was seen heading west towards the central mountain area of Oruzgan, an Afghan source said.

The Saudi dissident is suspected by the US of being involved in the attack on the USS Cole on October 12. Seventeen American sailors were killed when a boat packed with explosives rammed into the hull of the destroyer as it refuelled in Aden harbour.

Mr Bin Laden's decision to flee his base followed top-level meetings of the Taliban in Kandahar, where the movement's spiritual leader, Mullah Mohammed Omar, lives.

"Bin Laden has left Kandahar," one source said last night. "He was in a convoy of brand-new Land Cruisers. The convoy was not carrying Afghans, but heavily armed Arabs. They were moving west at some speed, heading towards the mountains. Though no one can say for sure, he is almost certainly now in Oruzgan province."

Mr Bin Laden, who is in close contact with Mullah Omar, moves frequently between several bases in Afghanistan. They include a farmhouse in Farmihadda, near the eastern city of Jalalabad, his main camp 20 miles west of Kandahar, and a small base built last year in Oruzgan.

He travels with around 100 fighters, usually leaving his three wives and numerous children behind, an Afghan source said.

Two years ago the Americans fired 75 cruise missiles at his training camps at Khost and Jalalabad after holding him responsible for the US embassy bombings in east Africa, which killed more than 200 people.

He was reported to have left the Khost camp an hour before the strike. The hardline Islamic Taliban regime has repeatedly refused to hand him over, despite UN sanctions imposed a year ago and a $5m reward offered by the US for information leading to his capture.

Such is the sensitivity regarding Mr Bin Laden's whereabouts that the vehicle of a UN team inspecting aid projects close to the Kandahar base was recently forced off the road by three Land Cruisers packed with his men.

Two UN officials were taken at gunpoint to the residence of Kandahar's Taliban governor to explain themselves. They were released after admitting that they had made a mistake, UN sources reported.

Mullah Omar has also stepped up his personal security since a bomb attack last year which appears to have been more devastating than originally thought.

As many as 50 people, including members of his family, may have died when a truck parked outside his house exploded. The toll was originally put at 10. Mullah Omar has now moved to a more secure house in Kandahar, allegedly paid for by Mr Bin Laden.

webTitle: Wolves stalker snaps up Oriental Restaurant for starters

fields.headline: Wolves stalker snaps up Oriental Restaurant for starters
fields.trailText: Robert Breare, the leisure entrepreneur stalking Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries, yesterday tabled a £14.4m agreed takeover bid for Oriental Restaurant Group with plans to roll out its Yellow River Cafe brand nationwide.
fields.body:
Robert Breare, the leisure entrepreneur stalking Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries, yesterday tabled a £14.4m agreed takeover bid for Oriental Restaurant Group with plans to roll out its Yellow River Cafe brand nationwide.

However, Mr Breare insisted that his attention was still focused on capturing the bigger prize, and he revealed that Wolves & Dudley had finally allowed him access to its detailed financial accounts.

Mr Breare said: "We've been working on both things in parallel for some weeks now. We've received quite a bit of due diligence from Wolves and we've been working on that for over a week."

The purchase of Oriental Restaurants is through Noble House, one of Mr Breare's investment vehicles. The 150p-a- share deal is intended to capitalise on the success of Yellow River, a five-strong chain of informal Asian restaurants endorsed by the celebrity chef Ken Hom.

Mr Breare intends to roll out Yellow River alongside Jim Thompson's - a chain of oriental bars which Noble House already owns. He said: "We have significant ambitions in the overall brewing and pubs industry. We're sorting out some very strong brands and themes capable of a national roll-out."

The deal is small compared to the proposed £470m takeover of Wolves & Dudley, which is being considered by Botts & Co - another vehicle closely associated with Mr Breare. Market rumours last month suggested Botts' interest in Wolves & Dudley had waned.

Mr Breare denied this, saying: "We're going as fast as they'll let us go."

Wolves & Dudley announced a month ago that it had begun a strategic review, in a move interpreted to mean that the struggling business was up for sale. That followed pressure from shareholders, who objected to the firm's refusal to open up its books to possible bidders.

It is understood that Wolves' advisers have split the due diligence process into two stages - "indicative" and "detailed" scrutiny. The first of these stages is under way.

Wolverhampton & Dudley is Britain's biggest regional beer firm with four breweries and 1,700 pubs - including the Pitcher & Piano chain. The brewer has struggled to swallow a rapid series of acquisitions and has fallen victim to a slowdown in takings at traditional neighbourhood pubs.

webTitle: £2.4bn link puts British oil in the spotlight

fields.headline: £2.4bn link puts British oil in the spotlight
fields.standfirst: More consolidation likely following bid for Lasmo
fields.trailText: More consolidation likely following bid for Lasmo.
fields.body:
American oil company Amerada Hess yesterday tabled a £2.4bn agreed bid for British independent Lasmo, raising speculation about further consolidation within the sector.

Shares in Enterprise Oil and BG, the last big independent exploration and production companies in the UK, were marked higher after news of the bid broke.

The merger of Amerada and Lasmo will create the leading second-tier oil exploration company in the world. But it will still be dwarfed by the likes of Shell, BP and Exxon.

Amerada is offering a mixture of cash and paper valuing the Lasmo shares at 180p each, a 28% premium over Friday night's closing price.

Lasmo shares closed 34p higher at 175p as the market discounted expectations that Italian energy group ENI might mount a counterbid.

Analysts' reaction to the deal were mixed, with some suggesting Amerada could have been more generous and others saying it was paying a full price for a stock which this year had traded below 100p.

The Lasmo board has been under pressure from its institutional shareholders to take action to boost its shares price and had been looking at selling individual assets from within its portfolio and returning cash to shareholders.

Its chief executive, Joe Darby, said the option of selling assets "piece by piece" and reinvesting the proceeds or returning them to shareholders was not viable because of the time such sales took and because of the uncertainties surrounding the oil price.

Lasmo sources said that the US group had initially approached the British group with a view to buying its Dacion field in Venezuela but the talks had subsequently broadened out to encompass the whole company.

Amerada executives said that the deal would result in 150 job losses in Britain, which could account for $45m of the $65m annual savings they expected to make. Lasmo's London headquarters is expected to be sold for about $10m.

The takeover would also result in a reduction in overall exploration spending. Amerada planned to spend $285m and Lasmo $110m. When the deal is completed, the two companies aim to reduce their combined exploration programme to $330m.

Amerada directors hinted that the group might sell its 25% stake in Premier Oil, another UK independent. "The shareholder return on Premier has been disappointing," an Amerada spokesman said.

The US group said that it hoped to avoid running into problems with US sanctions against Iran and Libya by financing and managing Lasmo's interests in those countries through its British subsidiary.

It said the proposal had not yet been blessed by the US state department. Amerada was the largest buyer of Iranian crude oil before the hostage crisis which led to the US sanctions.

Antony Hitchens, Lasmo's chairman, said: "This deal is an attractive opportunity to realise value for our shareholders."

Amerada said the deal would enable it to achieve its strategic goal of boosting growth in its international oil and gas reserves. "The deal enhances our competitive position in a consolidating industry," said John Hess, the US group's chairman.

As hopes of further bids took hold, shares in Enterprise Oil, which made an unsuccessful bid for Lasmo in 1994, were up 39p at 562p while BG shares added 4.5p to 270p. "The principle is that it is far easier to buy an exploration company than to do it yourself," one London dealer said.

webTitle: New Bhs boss vows to smarten up the fashions

fields.headline: New Bhs boss vows to smarten up the fashions
fields.trailText: Former Asda boss Allan Leighton was named chairman of the high street chain Bhs yesterday, and immediately pledged to smarten up the company's clothes range by using more British suppliers.
fields.body:
Former Asda boss Allan Leighton was named chairman of the high street chain Bhs yesterday, and immediately pledged to smarten up the company's clothes range by using more British suppliers.

Mr Leighton has taken on the job as part of his plan to "go plural" with several different jobs following his sudden resignation as chairman of Wal-Mart Europe two months ago.

He intends to keep Bhs in the "middle market" but admitted that the quality of some products, particularly womenswear, was poor. "It's a great brand, known for good quality and exceptional value. But I don't think the product range fits the brand values. We've got to address ladieswear in particular.

"In some of the ladies' products, the quality is just not good enough. We've got to change that without affecting the pricing."

He said one of the solutions would be to drop Far Eastern suppliers in favour of British textiles companies. This would reduce the time lag in placing orders, and give Bhs more flexibility to change its products at short notice.

The appointment means Mr Leighton, 47, will be working closely with Philip Green, the Monaco-based entrepreneur who bought Bhs for £200m from Storehouse in May. The company now has a high-profile management team. Former Debenhams boss Terry Green joined as chief executive in May.

At the beginning of the year, Philip Green attempted to put together a takeover bid for Marks & Spencer. Insiders say this idea is unlikely to be revived. One said: "The best thing for Bhs is an underperforming Marks & Spencer - why would we want to rescue it?"

Marks & Spencer, C&A and others have been hit by a slump in the popularity of mid-priced retailers.

Mr Leighton said Bhs will resist the temptation to radically reposition itself.

"The middle market is a great place to be. This is largely because everyone's trying to vacate it by either moving up or down." He revealed however that Bhs would introduce "affordable luxuries" - premium products, pitched at more discerning shoppers.

Since his departure from Wal-Mart Europe, Mr Leighton has been appointed chairman of Lastminute.com and housebuilder Wilson Connolly. He has also joined the board of Dyson, the maker of vacuum cleaners and washing machines. Mr Leighton has two more jobs lined up, one with a North American-based company.

webTitle: Eddington takes BA back to basics

fields.headline: Eddington takes BA back to basics
fields.standfirst: Notebook Chairman tries to restore service
fields.trailText: Notebook Chairman tries to restore service.
fields.body:
Rod Eddington, the new chief executive of British Airways, has made an impressive start. Although much of what the airline announced yesterday had been started by the deposed Bob Ayling earlier this year - a point which Mr Eddington recognises - the root and branch examination of BA's operation is Mr Eddington' s initiative alone.

The personable Australian has spent the past six months carefully studying the company's structure. Both the frills and the no frills are out, starting with Go, BA's low-cost carrier, which will be sold off to the highest bidder as soon as possible. The frills are the extras that BA has acquired over the past few years, appendages that are unprofitable and have diverted the airline from what it once did best: providing an excellent service at top of the market prices.

So it is back to BA's core business for Mr Eddington, and those passengers at the rear of the aircraft will just have to live with the cramped conditions. They have their place on long-haul trips, of course, but the burgeoning business of the low-cost carriers will take care of them. Witness Luton and Stansted early in the morning.

Still, it is a high-risk policy to tempt premium passengers with the promise of more frequent flights in flat beds in and out of Heathrow, even though the numbers are beginning to stack up.

If Mr Eddington can win back BA's tarnished reputation as an airline that puts customer care first, he will win new friends. And if he can do it without firing staff, he will do much to restore staff morale. Under the Ayling regime it suffered badly.

However, the hurdle of what to do with Gatwick remains, as does the long-term position of the airline which is in danger of being throttled because it cannot expand out of Heathrow.

BBC rethink

Ah! So you have arrived here on Page 29, half way between an obit of Jimmie Davis and the Derby/West Ham fixture. These are the financial pages. Either you are on a very long train journey or you have an interest in the world of business and economics.

The BBC has been serving you badly. You probably already know that, having sat from time to time through a 20-minute dissection of Serbo-Croat politics by Mark Urban, only to watch Peter Jay trying to explain why interest rates have gone up with the aid of some toy-town graphics, all in the space of two minutes, twenty seconds.

Greg Dyke, the BBC's director general, issued you all an apology yesterday. While speaking at the Confederation of British Industry conference in Birmingham, he promised lots more resources to both expand business coverage and modernise editorial thinking on business stories across the corporation's flagship news programmes.

Implementer-in-chief will be Jeff Randall, the current editor of Sunday Business, who is moving to the newly created position of BBC business editor.

Mr Randall is a business journalist of substantial swagger (not to mention sway in the Savoy Grill Room). He will find willing journalistic talent in corners such as the Financial World Tonight or the professionally turned Business section of BBC Online. All the same, nudging other parts of the corporation away from the assumption that all bosses are greedy men who just enjoy sacking people will take time.

For what it is worth, Mr Randall's favourite line to fire at one-paced reporters is "get an alarm clock". But John Humphries and his colleagues on the Today programme might already have an answer to that one.

Snookered?

Hans Snook, chief executive Orange, said yesterday that we will have to wait another month before we know whether he is retaining a senior executive role at the mobile phone business once the new owners, France Telecom, refloat it early next year.

His comments follow the unexpected move by the French last month to install a new chief executive (Jean-Francois Pontal) at Orange and then, more recently, news that the business will have its primary share listing in Paris rather than London - fuelling further speculation on Mr Snook's future.

Whatever France Telecom's advisers say, it is difficult to avoid the conclusion that the man is being edged out of a business which has been largely built in his idiosyncratic image.

Orange has been padded out with France Telecom's existing mobile phone interests and the assumption is that the top man, Michel Bon, did not want someone like Mr Snook throwing their weight around.

This is a shame, since the world of mobile telephony will be a less colourful place without him. But the man knows about brands and how to build them. The scores of millions Mr Snook has made at Orange will probably pale into insignificance at his next venture.

You probably already know that, having sat from time to time through a 20-minute dissection of Serbo-Croat politics by Mark Urban, only to watch Peter Jay trying to explain why interest rates have gone up with the aid of some toy-town graphics, all in the space of two minutes, twenty seconds. Greg Dyke, the BBC's director general, issued you all an apology yesterday. While speaking at the Confederation of British Industry conference in Birmingham, he promised lots more resources to both expand business coverage and modernise editorial thinking on business stories across the corporation's flagship news programmes. Implementer-in-chief will be Jeff Randall, the current editor of Sunday Business, who is moving to the newly created position of BBC business editor. Mr Randall is a business journalist of substantial swagger (not to mention sway in the Savoy Grill Room). He will find willing journalistic talent in corners such as the Financial World Tonight or the professionally turned Business section of BBC Online. All the same, nudging other parts of the corporation away from the assumption that all bosses are greedy men who just enjoy sacking people will take time. For what it is worth, Mr Randall's favourite line to fire at one-paced reporters is "get an alarm clock". But John Humphries and his colleagues on the Today programme might already have an answer to that one. Snookered? Hans Snook, chief executive Orange, said yesterday that we will have to wait another month before we know whether he is retaining a senior executive role at the mobile phone business once the new owners, France Telecom, refloat it early next year. His comments follow the unexpected move by the French last month to install a new chief executive (Jean-Francois Pontal) at Orange and then, more recently, news that the business will have its primary share listing in Paris rather than London - fuelling further speculation on Mr Snook's future. Whatever France Telecom's advisers say, it is difficult to avoid the conclusion that the man is being edged out of a business which has been largely built in his idiosyncratic image. Orange has been padded out with France Telecom's existing mobile phone interests and the assumption is that the top man, Michel Bon, did not want someone like Mr Snook throwing their weight around. This is a shame, since the world of mobile telephony will be a less colourful place without him. But the man knows about brands and how to build them. The scores of millions Mr Snook has made at Orange will probably pale into insignificance at his next venture.

webTitle: Hint of tax breaks cheers industry

fields.headline: Hint of tax breaks cheers industry
fields.standfirst: Investment incentives to accompany call for more productivity
fields.trailText: Investment incentives to accompany call for more productivity.
fields.body:
The chancellor, Gordon Brown, yesterday wooed the business community with hints of more generous tax breaks for research and development and capital gains as he set out his agenda to close Britain's productivity gap with other leading western economies.

In a speech warmly welcomed by the CBI, Mr Brown pledged help for exporters struggling with the strength of the pound, and he held out the prospect of measures in the next Budget to boost innovation and investment.

The chancellor said he would consider extending tax credits for R&D from small and medium-sized companies to larger concerns.

He would also look at ways of encouraging entrepreneurs to plough back capital gains into new businesses.

Laying out the themes of tomorrow's pre-Budget report, Mr Brown said the government was determined to avoid a return to boom and bust. "As a country the choice is clear. We can either retreat into the old short-termist ways, fail to take seriously the need for constant monetary and fiscal discipline, fail to invest for our future, fail to tackle our productivity gap.

"This would eventually put at risk the very stability all of you have rightly urged us to pursue.

"Or we can, by prudence and financial discipline, make stability our platform at this time of restructuring for building long-term economic strength.

"We could entrench in our country for the first time in a generation a long-term culture favouring low inflation and low interest rates, invest for the future and not squander surpluses on unsustainable consumer booms.

"And, even more important, modernise and achieve high levels of productivity growth, so that we can have even more profitable and successful British companies and rising living standards for all."

Mr Brown said there were times when the best course of action for government was to "get out of the way".

But he added that governments "must never again, either through playing politics with interest rates, or taking risks with the public finances - or just through short-termism - allow our hard won economic stability to be put at risk."

The pre-Budget report would focus on the challenge of closing Britain's productivity gap with other leading countries, the chancellor said.

"While we have world-class companies, whose successes I congratulate and in which the whole of Britain takes pride, overall productivity in Britain is far too low. It is far behind the US, still behind France and Germany."

But shadow chancellor Michael Portillo will today use his speech to the CBI conference to savage Mr Brown's record for delivering higher taxes, lower growth and exports as well as falling productivity since 1997. He will demand tax cuts now.

Specifically Mr Portillo will argue that tax levels have now "nearly caught up with mainland European rates" - an 8.5% larger share of GDP than in the US - and that growth has averaged 2.4% since 1997, barely half the US rate and below the EU average of 2.8%.

He will also argue that growth in productivity, one of the chancellor's main tests of his own performance, has halved to 1.1%.

Meanwhile, official figures showed manufacturing output falling by 0.4% between August and September.

webTitle: Loop levy points to £10 a month bill

fields.headline: Loop levy points to £10 a month bill
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Consumers could pay as little as £10 a month for new high-bandwidth services made available by the break-up of British Telecom's monopoly of the local telephone network.
fields.body:
Consumers could pay as little as £10 a month for new high-bandwidth services made available by the break-up of British Telecom's monopoly of the local telephone network.

The first indication of what it will cost the public to acquire high-speed internet connection was given yesterday when the telecoms regulator Oftel announced the proposed prices BT will levy on rivals which want to store their equipment in its exchanges and to take over local lines.

Rival operators will have to pay BT £118 annual rental for each customer they sign up, plus a £95 connection charge.

The charges will create a base for operators to set their charges to consumers. If competition is fierce enough, they may even subsidise costs in the hope of generating further revenues through e-commerce.

Additional charges could be imposed for specific services such as pay television or for subscription to an internet service provider.

Rivals hope to employ ADSL (asymmetric digital subscriber line) technology which can upgrade existing copper wires for uses such as high-speed internet access or the transmission of multi-channel TV.

BT's rivals, which have vented their fury at the pace of the so called "unbundling of the local loop" were for once satisfied with the charges.

Bob Cushing, group marketing and business development director at Redstone Telecom, said: "The thing that will make the largest difference to operators over time is the charge for line rental, and that's not bad."

Mr Cushing was critical, however, of hidden charges for all but the most simple of installations. Households that want separate lines for voice calls and ADSL, for instance, face a charge of £262.

The proposed charge for connecting 100 lines to an operator's equipment is an annual £21 rental and a £1,433 connection charge.

Other costs which rival operators will incur include rental of space within BT exchanges and their contribution to energy costs.

BT said the figures were in line with what it had been expecting.

David Edmonds, Oftel director general described the charges as "another important step towards local loop unbundling".

He said: "I am confident that these charges are at a level that will encourage competition in the provision of broadband services. They will allow other operators to provide new higher-bandwidth services to consumers at competitive prices."

The consultation period on the proposed charges will end on December 4 after which date there will be a final determination in time for the prices to take effect at the start of next year.

webTitle: Comment: Tara Mack on Ralph Nader

fields.headline: It's our best hope
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: I voted this week. I dug through a pile of papers to find my absentee ballot, scribbled a quick "x", and jammed the forms into an envelope before I could change my mind. It was very exciting. It was very painful. I voted for Ralph Nader for president of the United States.
fields.body:
I voted this week. I dug through a pile of papers to find my absentee ballot, scribbled a quick "x", and jammed the forms into an envelope before I could change my mind. It was very exciting. It was very painful. I voted for Ralph Nader for president of the United States.

It wasn't an easy decision. The person I realistically want to win the election is Al Gore. And if he loses to Bush, a Catholic sense of guilt inherited from my father (minus the actual Catholicism) will leave me feeling that I am personally responsible. But even if Bush becomes our next president, I do not believe my vote will have been wasted. Nader's candidacy will have left an indelible mark on the American political script.

It was thanks to Nader that I started paying attention to the elections. I spent the early months of the race doing my damnedest to avoid it. I refused to vote in the primaries.

Then I heard this summer that the Green party was running a candidate and that he was doing pretty well. I started looking for election stories. I scanned magazines for profiles of Nader. What I found, to my great relief, was someone echoing some of my own concerns - reasserting the supremacy of democracy over capitalism, universal health care, support for trade unions - and being taken seriously. By September, when I went back to the States for a visit, I was determined to register for an absentee ballot.

Voting for Nader felt like a tiny step into a broader movement, an act that connected me with protesters in Seattle and Prague. While I was in the States I gave the Greens a small donation, my first to a political party. Just for good measure, I also gave a little to the Coalition to Stop Gun Violence. Hardly revolutionary acts, but they are a modest start and far more than Gore could have inspired me to.

The last time I was this excited about voting was in 1992 when Bill Clinton was first running for president, promising to end what seemed, from my 20-year-old perspective, like an endless Republican reign in the White House. I imagined Clinton would throw open the White House doors and let a fresh breeze of liberalism air out a stale den of conservatism.

Then came the don't ask, don't tell policy. Then the collapse of the health-care project. Then welfare reform. Then Monica Lewinsky. It became obvious that Clinton is not a champion of the left, but a page boy for a nebulous centre.

Just because you're enthusiastic about the person you're voting for, it doesn't mean you'll get a fairytale ending. Idealistic voting doesn't always work. Gore's supporters won't let us forget that. "A vote for Nader is a vote for Bush," they shout, like it's a campaign slogan. There's some truth to that. If Nader weren't around and the race was still this close I might have been frightened into voting for Gore. But what is the value of a vote cast out of fear?

The Democrats are treating their liberal supporters as though the only thing they have to do to earn our votes is conjure up the spectre of a Republican presidency. That's not enough. My vote is my power as a citizen of a democracy. If I allow the Democratic party to convince me that I have no choices at the polling booth, then I allow them to strip me of that power. The only way to make the Democratic leadership pay attention is by showing them I can take my vote elsewhere. The wonderful thing about this election is that liberal Americans have finally been offered an elsewhere.

It's not easy to vote for Nader. The potential consequences are serious. But then, it only matters when it hurts. What are the "a vote for Nader is a vote for Bush" people trying to suggest? That you should support a third party only if it has no impact on the race whatsoever? What would be the point then? For the ideas that Nader and the Green party represent to have an impact, it's got to sting a little.

That sting is already making a difference. Gore has been forced to acknowledge Nader's presence. With enough votes, maybe Nader and the Greens can keep that momentum going, get the left organised again into a more viable political force.

Or we could simply vote for the lesser of two evils. But then we shouldn't be surprised if we always end up with evil. I think it's worth giving idealism another try.

 Tara Mack is an American journalist based in London

webTitle: Matthew Engel: Elections are always unmissable

fields.headline: Whoever wins, I'll lose sleep
fields.standfirst:
It's not as much fun as a British election, but still unmissable

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: It's not as much fun as a British election, but still unmissable
fields.body:
Right, have I got everything? Plenty of wood for the fire; black coffee; snacks; matches (for lighting up if it's tense, for propping open eyelids if it's boring); whisky for drowning sorrows (probably); pens; map of the United States for colouring in the results, TV doofer (where's it hidden THIS time, then?) to switch to CNN if the BBC gets really irritating . . .

No, I'm not sad; perfectly happy, actually. I love election nights, whenever and wherever. The psephologist David Butler once said that, for him, they were the equivalent of cup finals. In the case of American elections, the analogy is an exact one for us ballot-omanes. We don't really have a direct interest but pick a team anyway, and pretend we're really bothered.

An American election has to be second-best to our own because no other country - it is a small British boast - gets the comedy-drama of election night as right as we do. We cannot reasonably expect to see anything on TV in the early hours of tomorrow as cathartic as the eclipse of Portillo. Nor will the next leader of the United States have to stand next to a defeated candidate with a bucket on his head, as John Major did when the Huntingdon result was declared in 1992.

Indeed, we will not see any results being announced at all. Screeds will appear on the screen, announcing that 3% of the precincts have been counted in Mississippi or somewhere; network analysts will crunch the numbers and then hand Mississippi to Bush. If it's close, it may take longer. But the human factor will be absent. This may be one reason why less than half of US adults vote, compared to 75% in Britain.

Close votes are the best, no matter what the occasion. The tension in the final stages of the referendum on Welsh devolution, when everything depended on the response of a handful of voters in Carmarthen, was mind-blowing. For an ideal election night, though, you need a closely-fought front-line battle and innumerable subplots. The problem with American elections is that the real subplots - ie the sub-subplots - won't make it on to TV at all.

Most politics junkies like to pretend that their hobby is actually IMPORTANT, unlike sport, which is entirely TRIVIAL. But Americans long ago concluded (another reason why they don't vote) that it makes no difference who the president is. If elected, George Dubya could theoretically get confused between Russia and Moscow and, say, Rusholme and Moss Side, and blow South Manchester to smithereens any time after January 20 next year. But the world survived eight years of Ronald Reagan. Al Gore may be more clued-up about global warming. However, if he gets in, he will still want to carry Michigan in 2004, so he is unlikely to raise fuel tax much, even if Congress would let him.

In so far as this election matters to Americans, it matters on levels way beneath our radar. The main election issue in Pawnee County, Kansas, (I see from the Great Bend Tribune) is whether large-scale dairy farms should be allowed there. Meanwhile, Louisiana is voting on Amendment 4, which would let local government hand over money dedicated to economic development directly to companies that agree to move to the area. The Opelousas Daily World is against it. Their world is a small one, but they ain't stupid. "It will open the way to cronyism. Enough said."

There is a fierce battle to be county prosecutor in Cheboygan County, Michigan. Tim MacArthur was appointed (by his ex-law partner, opponents note) when the job fell vacant, but now has to face the voters. "My family has lived in Cheboygan County for over 130 years," he says, "and I was raised here with old-fashioned values." A local cop, however, claims that McArthur knows nothing of criminal law while his opponent, Ms Mickey Castagne, is a tough prosecutor: "The choice couldn't be clearer if keeping our community safe from crime is your primary concern."

In North Dakota (says the Devils Lake Journal), Mary Eksteen is hoping to be the first Democrat to be elected state auditor since 1892. The Idaho Statesman tells us they do have a Democratic sheriff in Ada County, Idaho. Many Republicans there like Frank Walker, but their state party chairman, Trent Clark, is cross with them: "It's one thing having a get-along go-along Democrat who works well with his colleagues. But Frank Walker is very partisan. He campaigns on weekends for Democrats. His kids put up signs for Democrats. Frank Walker will hurt us." .

And so on and on and on . . . from sea to shining sea. We won't hear the outcome of any of these contests before dawn tomorrow. But some of these results might actually affect the voters - rather more than Gore v Bush.

webTitle: Front-line Ouse battlers braced again

fields.headline: Front-line Ouse battlers braced again
fields.standfirst:
The flood fighter • The business • The evacuees

Special report: the weather
fields.trailText:
The flood fighter

It took nine men to carry the main freezer into Phil and Jackie Black's sandwich bar in York when they set up the business two years ago. In less than nine minutes last week the swollen river Ouse flicked it over on its side.
fields.body:
The flood fighter

It took nine men to carry the main freezer into Phil and Jackie Black's sandwich bar in York when they set up the business two years ago. In less than nine minutes last week the swollen river Ouse flicked it over on its side.

As the power cut out and the Tower Pantry's pans and crockery floated towards the door, the brown, filthy water was waist high. Today at noon Mrs Black and her husband, a former army chef at York's northern command HQ, face similar flood levels at their key location by the city's famous keep, Clifford's Tower.

"It means we can't do much today except count the cost," said Mrs Black, whose calculations have already topped £30,000. "Two years to get the business up and running, and a few hours to see it ruined."

When the water curled round Tower Place on Thursday it suddenly became clear that this wasn't the ordinary, annual York flood.

"We hadn't even registered for the floodline warning," said Mrs Black. "The only precaution - thank goodness - was that the outfitters were told to put power sockets halfway up the wall."

Part of the brown smear on everything is sewage which backed up as drainage collapsed. "It'll be the new year before we're back in business," said Mr Black.

The business

Martin Horner is running on chocolate and corned beef hash after working since Monday last on 20-hour shifts with four hours of sleep in between.

Over that time he has overseen the buying and filling of 120,000 sandbags to top the hard-pressed flood defences of York, along with the battle of the hay bales. "I'd never seen anything like it," says Mr Horner, whose normal responsibilities include supervising the city street-sweeping fleet and the team of craftsmen who point and chisel the famous walls. "Nine bales got swept into the Foss on the really bad night - Friday gone - and it looked as if York was going to be drowned."

Weighing over a ton on dry land, the drenched rolls of hay swelled to over three tonnes once waterlogged, but the spate was so powerful that they were carried down to wards the city. "They were either going to end up barricading the footbridge, like a beaver dam," says Mr Horner, "or they'd have got into the Foss flood barrier mechanism and wrecked it."

The bale battle saw Martin and a diving team from South Yorkshire police wrestle in the dark with hawser lassoes until the bales were hauled back to land by a tractor. Meanwhile the city council's temporary sandbag factory was searching all over the region for sacks (another 20,000 were ferried in yesterday) and over 2,500 tonnes of sand.

"The wagons have been bringing it by the 20 tonne load round the clock," says Mr Horner, whose other role since Monday last has been patrolling the hard-pressed concrete walls beside the Ouse and Foss, answering regular calls about water bubbling up on the wrong side.

All were false alarms - just. Mr Horner faces the same heart-stopping scene today when the Ouse peaks again.

The evacuees

Jaquie Chivers and Sonia Ingamells' living room looks like the victim of a specially insane episode of Changing Rooms, with the sofa balanced on a table beside a sculptural-looking pile of wellies.

The rest of the ground floor is virtually bare, with everything moveable now upstairs. Sonia, a writer, said: "Until Friday, this was a two storey house. Now it's a first floor flat."

The change came suddenly, said Jaquie, when a thud announced the flinging of sandbags on the doorsteps of Colenso Road. Then came a knock on the door. A man from York council pointed to water seeping round the end of the terrace. Her two children were dancing up and down with excitement as the street became a canal.

Evacuation followed, with Mark, six, and Nicola, eight, packed off to grandparents in Lincolnshire.

Partners Jaquie and Sonia came back to see what the Ouse had done. "Miraculously, it stopped on our doorstep," said Jaquie, "but the power was off and we spent the weekend without heating or hot water. It got to me at my university class today; I just suddenly burst into tears."

Her subject is stress counselling.

webTitle: At this price?

fields.headline: At this price?
fields.standfirst: P&O Princess
fields.trailText: P&O Princess
fields.body:
P&O Princess Cruises has encountered choppy seas since its recent demerger from parent P&O. Its shares have sunk 60p to 250p since they began trading a fortnight ago.

Over the same period shares in its erstwhile parent, now a ports, ferries and logistics company, rose by nearly the same amount.

The cruise company, the world's third largest, is to report third-quarter results on Thursday and shareholders will be looking for positive news. It may not be easy for the company to satisfy them. There are strong indications that the cruise industry has peaked for the time being.

The company's big rivals, Royal Caribbean and Carnival, reported early in the year that advanced bookings were down. There is little evidence that the industry's aim of attracting a younger generation to floating hotels has succeeded.

The well-heeled Americans upon whom P&O Princess relies for 75% of its business are keeping their cash in their pockets until the US presidential race is over.

There is, however, confidence that the attraction of cruise ship holidays will return. Orders for new ships continue to roll in.

Yesterday Carnival confirmed the Queen Mary 2 would be built for its Cunard subsidiary by Alstom's Chantiers de l'Atlantique in France. The boss of the French yard said the 150,000 tonne vessel, due to come into service in 2003, would be "a piece of history and a work of art".

P&O Princess took delivery of two ships this year, the 77,000 tonne, 2,020 berth Ocean Princess and the 76,000 tonne, 1,870 berth Aurora. It has nine more on order.

But new ships mean more competition. P&O Princess recently announced a deal with America Online enabling people to book cruises over the internet.

Next year will be tough. The leading firms may gain extra business as smaller rivals are forced out of the market or out of business.

P&O Princess's ships may be sound but the shares appear to have little buoyancy.

webTitle: Building a better future

fields.headline: Building a better future
fields.trailText: To use a tired, old phrase, things can only get better for Heywood Williams, the building materials group that saw its share price slide last week after the company warned that full-year profits are unlikely to meet expectations.
fields.body:
To use a tired, old phrase, things can only get better for Heywood Williams, the building materials group that saw its share price slide last week after the company warned that full-year profits are unlikely to meet expectations.

With margins in its core UK windows and doors arm under pressure and management seemingly unsure what to do next most investors would be avoiding the stock at all costs. However, broker Merrill Lynch sees things differently.

Merrill upgraded its rating on the stock to "accumulate" from "neutral" yesterday on the grounds that things cannot get much worse in its core UK businesses and once it has managed to offload its US operations a bid of around 200p could be on the way.

Indeed, only six months ago the company received an indicative offer worth 300p a share.

With the shares closing at 163.5p, up 10p, last night, the predator might be tempted to return.

webTitle: On hold for Brown and Bush

fields.headline: On hold for Brown and Bush
fields.standfirst:
Market forces

Special report: the US elections
Special report: the Budget
fields.trailText: Market forces
fields.body:
A strange day in the Square Mile. Although the main indices finished higher in brisk trading, the mood among City traders was never bright.

Perhaps it had something to do with the difficulties getting to the office after another night of violent storms in the south-east. But a quick glance at the best-performing stocks of the day told a different story.

Driving both the FTSE 100 and FTSE 250 higher were the oil and pharmaceutical sectors - classic places to park cash in times of worry or uncertainty. Of course, second-line oil stocks were enlivened by the bid for Lasmo, up 34p to 175p, but that had little to do with the performances of Shell, 12p higher at 541p, BP, up 6.5p to 568p, or drug stocks AstraZeneca, 160p better at £33.20, and Glaxo Wellcome, up 38p at £20.35.

Put simply, the market is worried - or, more accurately, uncertain - about a number of important events this week. Most important is the US presidential election, though Gordon Brown's pre-Budget statement and the meeting of the monetary policy committee are also causing some anxiety.

A victory for George Bush is seen by the City as the favoured outcome for equities because his hands-off business policies and tax cuts are likely to keep the US economy ticking along at a fair rate. But until the result is known, traders are not prepared to chase the higher end of the market.

So dealers decided to turn their attention either to defensive stocks or altogether less taxing matters. One subject drawing an unusual amount of attention was the prospects of a small dot.com company called Arthur Shaw. Many traders sat transfixed as the share price of the engineering company-turned-internet content provider, which boasts the former manager of Pink Floyd as chairman, dived 0.625p, or 13.71%, to 3.775p.

According to the market gossips, Arthur Shaw is having problems getting its business - broadcasting live events such as pop concerts over the web - operating. Apparently big City institutions are proving reluctant to back the company because of concerns about the make-up of the board. However, chairman Bryan Morrison insisted that things were going well. "We have plenty of money in the bank," he said yesterday.

Away from such sideshows the FTSE 100 finally came to rest 45.6 points ahead at 6,431, with the FTSE 250 adding 77.6 to 6,826.8.

With investors plumping for defensive issues, technology and telecom issues were bound to suffer. The TechMark eased 0.87 to 3,498.51, with Vodafone having another miserable session, falling 10p to 243p as last week's profit downgrades continued to undermine sentiment.

Energis was also unloved, falling 13p to 540p. Over in the tech sector, Sema Group dropped 32p to 857p and Misys shed 18p to 725p.

Marks & Spencer failed to join in the "old economy" buying spree, falling 13p to 185p with investors unsettled by a number of reports suggesting today's figures will make gloomy reading.

News that ex-Asda chief Allan Leighton has teamed up with Philip Green at Bhs was also viewed as negative. Far from trying to take over M&S, it seems Mr Green and his dream team are going to tackle the ailing retailer head-on.

British Airways continued the good work of last week, rising 21p to 351p on the back interim figures which, the market's more clairvoyant players had guessed, were better than expected.

In fact, they were almost a carbon copy of last week's figures from KLM, which had started the buying spree. Sentiment was also boosted by news that the group wants to offload Go, its budget airline.

Lower down the corporate scale, Thus slipped 6p to 84p on talk that Wednesday's results are going to make tough reading, and Manchester United added 17p to 249p after securing a £300m sponsorship deal with Nike.

Floor coverings and furnishings group Headlam, down 22.5p to 135p, was rocked by the departure of its chief executive.

webTitle: US bishop says church treats women badly

fields.headline: US bishop says church treats women badly
fields.standfirst: Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: One of the most controversial bishops in the Anglican community has accused the Church of England of treating women like second class citizens.
fields.body:
One of the most controversial bishops in the Anglican community has accused the Church of England of treating women like second class citizens.

Bishop Jack Spong, a radical cleric in the US Episcopalian church, the American sister body to the Church of England, ended a month-long visit to Britain by accusing it of being a declining force in British society because of its backward attitudes.

He told the Guardian: "The church in Britain is way behind the United States. It seems to spend its time keeping the one million people who attend its services happy without reaching out to the 50 million who do not.

"Only two things keep the Church of England together, its pension fund and Wippell's, the clerical outfitters.

"The statistics are all downward. After the Archbishop of Canterbury called that silly decade of evangelisation in 1990 to attract more people into church the result was fewer people than ever attending services.

"Part of its problem is the church's attitude to women. It is still preoccupied with supporting those who do not like women priests while not worrying about affronting the women who do attend its services.

"I don't see how you can treat women as second-class citizens in the 21st century. If you have biblical reservations you should do what the Mormons do and get yourself another divine revelation to get things changed."

Bishop Spong, 69, who retired as bishop of Newark, New Jersey, last January, is used to causing waves with his outspokenness, particularly among evangelicals, with his support for women's ordination and gays in the church and his scepticism about the literal truth of the Bible. He recently said that if he had to choose between believing in the Virgin Mary and Wonderwoman he would plump for the latter.

So outraged was one female fundamentalist that when Bishop Spong's first wife died in 1988 she invaded the funeral service to strike him as he prayed by the coffin. "I have wanted to get that bastard for years," she cried as she was led away.

The views of clerics such as him have come close to splitting the Episcopalian church in the US. Here, where rows have generally been more restrained, many women ordained in the past eight years have reported harassment and insults from hardline opponents.

Bishop Spong clashed most publicly with Dr George Carey, the Archbishop of Canterbury, two years ago at the Lambeth conference of Anglican bishops over a statement, partly dictated by developing world bishops, on the church's attitude to homosexuality.

He views the archbishop with near contempt for suggesting that the church's position should reflect the reservations of bishops from the developing countries. "You can't expect the church in the US, or Canada or Britain to go along at the same pace as Chad. Robert Runcie would never have acted in that way because he had a world vision, but George Carey is running along behind his church, not trying to lead it," he said.

He added: "Men who were hounded out of the church a few years ago are now recognised to have held views now recognised as mainstream. I have no interest in debating with the ecclesiastical version of the Flat Earth Society, those who deal in verbal graven images out of the Bible. I want the church still to be able to speak to my children and grandchildren in 30 years' time."

webTitle: Comment: Jacob Weisberg on Ralph Nader

fields.headline: It's sectarian idiocy
fields.standfirst:
US elections Ralph Nader's maverick candidacy is causing splits and recriminations among American liberals

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: US elections Ralph Nader's maverick candidacy is causing splits and recriminations among American liberals
fields.body:
Over the past 10 days, liberals have been voicing shock and dismay at the imminent prospect of their old hero, Ralph Nader, intentionally throwing the election to George W Bush. A first, eloquent protest came 10 days ago from a group of a dozen former "Nader's Raiders," who asserted that their former mentor had broken a promise not to campaign in states where he could hurt Gore and begged him to reconsider doing so. Others, including Newsweek columnist Jonathan Alter, have expressed a similar sense of disappointment and betrayal.

Nader's response to all this heartfelt hand-wringing has been to scoff and sneer. On Good Morning America, he referred contemptuously to his old disciples as "frightened liberals". The Green party nominee is spending the final week of the campaign stumping in Michigan, Minnesota, Wisconsin, Oregon, and Washington - the very states where a strong showing stands to hurt Gore the most.

Nader has said he wants to maximise his vote in every state in hopes of attaining the 5% of the vote that will qualify the Green party for $12m in federal matching funds in 2004. Speaking to foreign journalists in Washington yesterday, he explicitly rejected internet vote-swapping schemes that could help him reach this qualifying threshold without the side-effect of electing Bush president. In various other TV appearances, Nader has stated bluntly that he couldn't care less who wins.

This depraved indifference to Republican rule has made Nader's old liberal friends even more furious. A bunch of intellectuals organised by Sean Wilentz and Todd Gitlin are circulating a much nastier open letter, denouncing Nader's "wrecking-ball campaign - one that betrays the very liberal and progressive values it claims to uphold".

But really, the question shouldn't be the one liberals seem to be asking about why Nader is doing what he's doing. The question should be why anyone is surprised. For some time now, Nader has made it perfectly clear that his campaign isn't about trying to pull the Democrats back to the left. Rather, his strategy is the Leninist one of "heightening the contradictions". It's not just that Nader is willing to take a chance of being personally responsible for electing Bush. It's that he's actively trying to elect Bush because he thinks that social conditions in American need to get worse before they can better.

Nader often makes this "the worse, the better" point on the stump in relation to Republicans and the environment. He says that the Reagan-era interior secretary James Watt was useful because he was a "provocateur" for change, noting that Watt spurred a massive boost in the Sierra Club's membership. More recently, Nader applied the same logic to Bush himself. Here's the Los Angeles Times' account of a speech Nader gave at Chapman University in Orange, California, last week: "After lambasting Gore as part of a do-nothing Clinton administration, Nader said, 'If it were a choice between a provocateur and an anaesthetiser, I'd rather have a provocateur. It would mobilise us.' "

Lest this remark be considered an aberration, Nader has said similar things before. "When [the Democrats] lose, they say it's because they are not appealing to the Republican voters," Nader told an audience in Madison, Wisconsin, a few months ago, according to a story in the Nation. "We want them to say they lost because a progressive movement took away votes."

That might make it sound like Nader's goal is to defeat Gore in order to shift the Democratic party to the left. But in a more recent interview with David Moberg in the socialist paper In These Times, Nader made it clear that his real mission is to destroy and then replace the Democratic party altogether. According to Moberg, Nader talked "about leading the Greens into a 'death struggle' with the Democratic party to determine which will be the majority party". Nader further and shockingly explained that he hopes in the future to run Green party candidates around the country, including against such progressive Democrats as Senator Paul Wellstone of Minnesota, Senator Russell Feingold of Wisconsin, and Representative Henry Waxman of California. "I hate to use military analogies," Nader said, "but this is war on the two parties."

Hitler analogies always lead to trouble, but the one here is irresistible since Nader is actually making the argument of the German Communist party circa 1932, which helped bring the Nazis to power. I'm not comparing the Republicans to fascists or the Greens to Stalinists for that matter. But Nader and his supporters are emulating a disturbing, familiar pattern of sectarian idiocy.

You hear these echoes whenever Nader criticises Bush half-heartedly, then becomes enthusiastic and animated blasting the Green version of the "social fascists" - Bill Clinton, Gore, and moderate environmentalists. It's clear that the people he really despises are those who half agree with him.

To Nader, it is liberal meliorists, not rightwing conservatives, who are the true enemies of his effort to build a "genuine" progressive movement. He does have a preference between Republicans and Democrats, and it's for the party that he thinks will inflict maximum damage on the environment, civil rights, labour rights, and so on. By assisting his class enemy, Nader thinks he can help pull the wool from the eyes of a sheep-like public.

If Nader's goal were actually progressive reform - a ban on soft money, a higher minimum wage, health-care coverage for some of the uninsured, a global warming treaty - it would be possible to say that his strategy was breathtakingly stupid. But Nader's goal is not progressive reform; it's a transformation in human consciousness. His Green party will not flourish under Democratic presidents who lull the country into a sense of complacency by making things moderately better. If it is to thrive, it needs villainous, rightwing Republicans who will make things worse.

Like Pat Buchanan, Nader understands that his movement thrives on misery. But the comparison is actually unfair to Buchanan (words I never thought I'd write) because Buchanan doesn't work to create more misery for the sake of making his movement grow the way Nader does. From a strictly self-interested point of view, Nader's stance is the more rational one.

So Gore supporters might as well quit warning the Green candidate that he's going to put George W Bush in White House. Ralph Nader is a very intelligent man who knows exactly what's he doing. And they only seem to be encouraging him.

This has been extracted from Slate magazine www.slate.com
fields.bodyText: Over the past 10 days, liberals have been voicing shock and dismay at the imminent prospect of their old hero, Ralph Nader, intentionally throwing the election to George W Bush. A first, eloquent protest came 10 days ago from a group of a dozen former "Nader's Raiders," who asserted that their former mentor had broken a promise not to campaign in states where he could hurt Gore and begged him to reconsider doing so. Others, including Newsweek columnist Jonathan Alter, have expressed a similar sense of disappointment and betrayal. Nader's response to all this heartfelt hand-wringing has been to scoff and sneer. On Good Morning America, he referred contemptuously to his old disciples as "frightened liberals". The Green party nominee is spending the final week of the campaign stumping in Michigan, Minnesota, Wisconsin, Oregon, and Washington - the very states where a strong showing stands to hurt Gore the most. Nader has said he wants to maximise his vote in every state in hopes of attaining the 5% of the vote that will qualify the Green party for $12m in federal matching funds in 2004. Speaking to foreign journalists in Washington yesterday, he explicitly rejected internet vote-swapping schemes that could help him reach this qualifying threshold without the side-effect of electing Bush president. In various other TV appearances, Nader has stated bluntly that he couldn't care less who wins. This depraved indifference to Republican rule has made Nader's old liberal friends even more furious. A bunch of intellectuals organised by Sean Wilentz and Todd Gitlin are circulating a much nastier open letter, denouncing Nader's "wrecking-ball campaign - one that betrays the very liberal and progressive values it claims to uphold". But really, the question shouldn't be the one liberals seem to be asking about why Nader is doing what he's doing. The question should be why anyone is surprised. For some time now, Nader has made it perfectly clear that his campaign isn't about trying to pull the Democrats back to the left. Rather, his strategy is the Leninist one of "heightening the contradictions". It's not just that Nader is willing to take a chance of being personally responsible for electing Bush. It's that he's actively trying to elect Bush because he thinks that social conditions in American need to get worse before they can better. Nader often makes this "the worse, the better" point on the stump in relation to Republicans and the environment. He says that the Reagan-era interior secretary James Watt was useful because he was a "provocateur" for change, noting that Watt spurred a massive boost in the Sierra Club's membership. More recently, Nader applied the same logic to Bush himself. Here's the Los Angeles Times' account of a speech Nader gave at Chapman University in Orange, California, last week: "After lambasting Gore as part of a do-nothing Clinton administration, Nader said, 'If it were a choice between a provocateur and an anaesthetiser, I'd rather have a provocateur. It would mobilise us.' " Lest this remark be considered an aberration, Nader has said similar things before. "When [the Democrats] lose, they say it's because they are not appealing to the Republican voters," Nader told an audience in Madison, Wisconsin, a few months ago, according to a story in the Nation. "We want them to say they lost because a progressive movement took away votes." That might make it sound like Nader's goal is to defeat Gore in order to shift the Democratic party to the left. But in a more recent interview with David Moberg in the socialist paper In These Times, Nader made it clear that his real mission is to destroy and then replace the Democratic party altogether. According to Moberg, Nader talked "about leading the Greens into a 'death struggle' with the Democratic party to determine which will be the majority party". Nader further and shockingly explained that he hopes in the future to run Green party candidates around the country, including against such progressive Democrats as Senator Paul Wellstone of Minnesota, Senator Russell Feingold of Wisconsin, and Representative Henry Waxman of California. "I hate to use military analogies," Nader said, "but this is war on the two parties." Hitler analogies always lead to trouble, but the one here is irresistible since Nader is actually making the argument of the German Communist party circa 1932, which helped bring the Nazis to power. I'm not comparing the Republicans to fascists or the Greens to Stalinists for that matter. But Nader and his supporters are emulating a disturbing, familiar pattern of sectarian idiocy. You hear these echoes whenever Nader criticises Bush half-heartedly, then becomes enthusiastic and animated blasting the Green version of the "social fascists" - Bill Clinton, Gore, and moderate environmentalists. It's clear that the people he really despises are those who half agree with him. To Nader, it is liberal meliorists, not rightwing conservatives, who are the true enemies of his effort to build a "genuine" progressive movement. He does have a preference between Republicans and Democrats, and it's for the party that he thinks will inflict maximum damage on the environment, civil rights, labour rights, and so on. By assisting his class enemy, Nader thinks he can help pull the wool from the eyes of a sheep-like public. If Nader's goal were actually progressive reform - a ban on soft money, a higher minimum wage, health-care coverage for some of the uninsured, a global warming treaty - it would be possible to say that his strategy was breathtakingly stupid. But Nader's goal is not progressive reform; it's a transformation in human consciousness. His Green party will not flourish under Democratic presidents who lull the country into a sense of complacency by making things moderately better. If it is to thrive, it needs villainous, rightwing Republicans who will make things worse. Like Pat Buchanan, Nader understands that his movement thrives on misery. But the comparison is actually unfair to Buchanan (words I never thought I'd write) because Buchanan doesn't work to create more misery for the sake of making his movement grow the way Nader does. From a strictly self-interested point of view, Nader's stance is the more rational one. So Gore supporters might as well quit warning the Green candidate that he's going to put George W Bush in White House. Ralph Nader is a very intelligent man who knows exactly what's he doing. And they only seem to be encouraging him. This has been extracted from Slate magazine www.slate.com

webTitle: A country diary

fields.headline: A country diary
fields.standfirst: Highlands
fields.trailText: Highlands
fields.body:
The first dusting of snow on the hills the other side of the strath will mean far more snow on the distant Cairngorms, and it reminded me that this is the first year for a long time that I have not gone to hear the red deer roaring in the rut.

The winter snow affects animals and birds in different ways. Many move to lower ground, but there are a few that stay on high tops for the short winter days.

That large game bird the ptarmigan has adapted to the snowy conditions by moulting into a white winter plumage, the only British bird to achieve this camouflage, although they look conspicuous and rather incongruous when there is no snow around.

The mountain hare has a white winter coat and whether it stays on the high ground depends on the depth of snow and how long it lies. The hare moves downhill to feed as night falls and then before dawn it moves back again; sometimes the well-worn routes are easy to see.

The nearest mountain hares to me, along the sides of the River Findhorn, have the unusual habit of digging out holes in the ground or finding ones in the scree and sitting outside for most of the day; they dart into safety when a predator such as a golden eagle passes over.

One mystery with mountain hares are the black ones found in south east Caithness, which first appeared in the early 1900s. Until the owner of the estate stopped them being shot, many were sent to the taxidermists of the day. Whether these black hares turned white in winter was solved when someone shot a black one in the snows. Black mountain hares are virtually unknown elsewhere in Scotland and they persist on the estate to this day.
