webTitle: Watch this

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Logan's Run | Escape From New York | The Idiots | Coupe De Ville | Love And Death On Long Island
fields.body:
Logan's Run

(Michael Anderson, 1976)

9pm, Sci-Fi

Escape From New York

(John Carpenter, 1981)

midnight, Sci-Fi

A pair of cult sci-fi films to which time has been particularly unkind. The costumes and effects in Logan's Run, even though it was made the year before Star Wars, now look like cast-offs from a primary school Nativity play. Meanwhile, Kurt Russell rescues Donald Pleasence from the high-security prison formerly known as Manhattan. The 1997 dateline may have seemed ultra cutting-edge at the time. Not any more.

Andy Bodle
The Idiots

(Lars Von Trier, 1998)

10pm, FilmFour

Von Trier's satire caused uproar at the Cannes festival two years ago, not so much because it was made under the purist Dogme regulations but because of the content: it concerns a small group of people who have fun pretending to be disabled. Demanding, funny and explicit, it is flawed, but also more than just a sick joke.

Coupe De Ville

(Joe Roth, 1990)

12 midnight, Carlton Cinema

Enjoyable road movie that's light on action but strong on character. An odd trio of brothers - a college boy, a military man and a delinquent - are persuaded by dad Alan Arkin to drive a 1954 Cadillac from Detroit to Florida for mum's 50th birthday present. Along the way they rediscover brotherly love, and gambler-uncle Joseph Bologna. It's touching, funny and fuelled by a classic 60s pop soundtrack.

Love And Death On Long Island

(Richard Kwietniowski, 1996)

2.05am, Sky Premier

An impressive debut from Kwietniowski, who also scripted this adaptation of Gilbert Adair's novel. It's the story of crusty, widowed author Giles De'Ath (John Hurt, pictured), who, wandering into the wrong screening at the cinema, conceives a sudden, infatuation with its star, Ronnie Bostock (Jason Priestley). Soon he's en route to Long Island, and engineering a meeting with the shallow lad. It's very funny, with a wonderful performance from Hurt.

webTitle: Getting personal with the X Files' cigarette-smoking man

fields.headline: Answer me
fields.standfirst: Getting personal with the X Files' cigarette-smoking man
fields.trailText: Getting personal with the X Files' cigarette-smoking man
fields.body:
Full Name:
William Bruce Davis

Have you ever adopted a pseudonym and if so, why?
No, I'm known as Bill mostly.

Have you ever lied about your age and if so, why?
I changed my age on my driving licence so I could buy alcohol.

How would you describe yourself in a lonely hearts ad?
Tall, good looking, athletic, intelligent, well read, sophisticated and generous.

What was the last illegal thing you did?
There was the time I robbed Barclays Bank.

What was the last kind hearted thing you did?
There are so many things to choose from.

Who's the nicest person you've ever worked with?
Ron Hastings, a Canadian actor. His influence on my theatre company was so positive.

What are the initials of the most unpleasant person you've worked with?
JW, because he would pick on people and destroy their confidence.

Has a critic ever made you cry?
I've been upset when they didn't like my work, but sometimes it wasn't months or years later I'd realise they were right.

What would you advertise without a fee?
A range of cultural things such as the theatre, opera, symphony orchestras.

What would you never advertise?
Cigarettes.

What wakes you up screaming at four in the morning?
Other people's music.

What takes you to a "happy place"?
Whistler, British Columbia.

 The X-Files Season One DVD box set now out to buy £89.99, Twentieth Century Fox Home Entertainment.

Interview by Samantha Gillings

webTitle: Last night's TV

fields.headline: Death becomes her
fields.trailText: Brookside | One Foot In The Grave | Andes To Amazon
fields.body:
Susannah is dead. Decorative but dead. Scattered around her body are helpful clues. A key fob with the initial M on it or, looked at the other way, W. A snapshot. Two wine glasses. A broken phone. A video of her as a laughing child. A Teddy Bear. What kind of person would kill a woman like this?

Half Brookside (Channel 4), since you ask.

This week's teasing triple bill will remind everyone of Who Shot JR? (It was Bing Crosby's daughter and we all felt faintly cheated.) Brookside Close has a certain affinity with Southfork, wouldn't you say? All these people, who could easily seek more soothing surroundings, living in each other's pockets. Even when someone moves out, they invariably move in next door, which is already bulging with irritating in-laws, children of uncertain parentage and, sometimes, hurriedly buried bodies. Susannah has a more than nominal likeness to Sue-Ellen. She's a good-looking woman who, if she calmed down a bit, would be a nymphomaniac.

And she certainly put the pussy among the pigeons in Brookside. The pigeons in order of flutter are Max, her ex-husband, Darren, her doctor, Greg, her lover, who died in flagrante when the health club was blown up, and Mick, who was going to marry her today.

It was a bumpy pre- nuptial night. As Susannah was trying on her champagne ensemble with the matching peignoir, everyone who had a grievance arrived in rotation to harangue her. That's the trouble with northern neighbours, always dropping in uninvited for a cup of gin and a frank exchange of views.

First was Jacqui Dixon with £30,000 in used notes to buy back her surrogate son, a vacant-looking child. I blame the turkey baster. Then "Ding-dong!" it's Dr Darren calling. Should you require medical attention, I advise you to steer clear of Dr Darren ("It's only a scratch. You'll live.") Oh no, she won't. Today I confidently expect Emily, demented daughter of the deceased Greg, and Mick, who could go on as Othello without make-up or rehearsal. Susannah's blonde poshness and Mick's mahogany nobility carry a subliminal punch.

On Wednesday we will know who slew Susannah. In my view, the woman deserves to die for her ear-aching indulgence in cliché. "I can read you like a book" ... "Love and hate are two sides of the same coin" ... "The first one who resorts to violence is the one who's lost the argument." Then again, the first one who resorts to violence is the murderer.

While we are on the subject of mortality, Victor Meldrew continues to rage against the dying of the light. Particularly as One Foot In The Grave (BBC 1) was in the middle of a power cut. Amid the encircling gloom and reminders of steadily disintegrating equipment - Great Aunt Joyce's glass eye and Uncle Dick's false arm - Mr Smedley arrives, helplessly fat and startlingly literal. When Mr Smedley says he's going to read his book, that is precisely what he does ("Chapter 8. Late that evening I was surprised at my lodgings....") When he says he is going to the toilet, he means that too ("No, I'm going to the toilet now. As I speak.") He was a poignantly comic creation. And he was Roy Hudd.

Andes To Amazon (BBC2) seemed to have escaped from the National Geographic Channel. All those animals with implausible names, which will come in so handy for Countdown, making a dash for it. The pirarucu, the viscachas, the guanaco, maras, rhea, koati and - an endearing sequence - the racing llamas, their ears flying fluorescent pink and orange fringes. The music was of that peculiarly piercing quality played, I shouldn't wonder, on the nose flute. It gave me a fellow feeling for the anchovy, which is stunned and confused by the high frequency sounds dolphins make. I stand shoulder to shoulder with the anchovy on this.

Pelham Aldrich-Blake's script rattled with statistics. "In just over two square miles of forest scientists have counted 3,000 varieties of plant, 530 kind of birds and 11 species of monkey... 650 species of beetle and 80 kinds of ant have been found on one tree." It was, not unlike South America, inimical and indigestible. And, if he calls the Amazon mighty once more, I will wrap it round his neck. The next programme is called The Mighty Amazon.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: The Reference Library | America Decides With Peter Allen
fields.body:
Simon Fanshawe opens a second series exploring treasures of the The Reference Library (9.30am, Radio 4). His first started with Whitaker's Almanack, that guide to almost any official statistic. This time he focuses on something far more important, the Wisden Cricketers' Almanack.

Unofficial projections of America's election results emerge minutes after eastern polling stations close (some at midnight GMT, others two hours later). America Decides With Peter Allen (Midnight, Radio 5 Live) follows the returns in a programme broadcast simultaneously across America. With the closest presidential race for 40 years, early exit polls should be treated with caution. Hillary Clinton's senate bid in New York is one Congressional highlight but Missouri has the real nailbiter. There a dead candidate's widow could achieve Democratic control of the Senate.

webTitle: In brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Zimbabwe farmers get day in court
Zimbabwe's embattled white farmers told the supreme court yesterday that President Robert Mugabe's "fast- track" land redistribution programme was violent and unconstitutional.
fields.body:
Zimbabwe farmers get day in court
Zimbabwe's embattled white farmers told the supreme court yesterday that President Robert Mugabe's "fast- track" land redistribution programme was violent and unconstitutional.

The Commercial Farmers Union (CFU), representing 4,200 farmers, almost all white, said on the opening day of the trial that it was challenging Mr Mugabe in the supreme court because it had exhausted all other efforts at negotiating with the government. The CFU said it is not against land reform but it is opposed the illegal and often violent land seizures, which the police have done little to stop.

"The fast-track land resettlement is a blatant negation of the rule of law. The whole exercise should be stopped, according to the constitution, [and] in the interest of the country," its lawyer, Adrian de Bourbon, said.

"The fast-track programme is an attempt to bypass the courts . . . the government is not concerned with the legalities of the present land resettlement exercise. It is prepared to go about it in willful disregard of the law."

Mr De Bourbon told the court, consisting of one Asian, two white and two black judges, that 3,000 farms had been designated for compulsory acquisition without a transparent selection process.

Mr Mugabe was quick to dismiss the challenge.

"Whatever the courts might say on the matter, the land is ours and we will take it," he said on state television on Sunday. [Andrew Meldrum, Harare]

Shark kills Australian swimmer
One man was killed and another injured when a shark attacked a group of swimmers in Western Australia early yesterday.

Witnesses said the 16ft (5-metre) great white shark tore the leg off Ken Crew, 49, in waist-deep water at Cottesloe Beach, Perth. The local businessman was hauled from the water alive but died on the beach, despite attempts to revive him.

Another swimmer, Dick Avery, 52, who tried to rescue him, was in a stable condition after undergoing surgery for leg and foot injuries.

"There was a whole sea of blood," said Kim Gamble, a cafe owner. "From the balcony I could see this huge shark. When we saw the fin and the tail, people thought it was two sharks, it was so big."

More than 100 people were on the beach when the shark struck. "All of a sudden I heard all this yelling and screaming and looked down the beach [and] saw the blood in the water," said Di McCusker, who had just come out of the sea.

It was the third fatal shark attack in Australian waters in recent weeks. This one struck in a place which has not seen a shark-related death for 75 years. In late September two surfers were killed in shark attacks on the south coast.

Perth's beaches were closed yesterday as the Western Australia fisheries department monitored the shark's movements. The fisheries minister later issued a special permit to kill the great white, which is usually a protected species in Australia. [Patrick Barkham, Sydney]

Sandinista mayor for Managua
A leftwing Sandinista candidate was declared mayor of the Nicaraguan capital, Managua, yesterday.

Herty Lewites, who defeated a candidate from the Liberal Constitutionalist party, which has governed the capital and the country since the Sandinistas were defeated by the US-backed contra rebels, declared victory on Sunday night after the preliminary vote was announced.

President Arnoldo Aleman conceded his party's defeat but he vowed that it would continue to be Nicaragua's strongest political force.

He predicted that it would win at least 90 of the 154 mayoralties contested on Sunday.

With less than 4% of the votes in the capital counted early yesterday, the Sandinista party had won 45%, followed by the Liberal Constitutionalists on 27% and the Conservative party on 26%. Mr Aleman blamed his party's defeat on the Conservatives, saying they divided the vote. [AP, Managua]

Pompeii yields hotel fresco
A cycle of frescoes almost 2,000 years old has been unearthed near Pompeii during the delayed excavation of a building thought to have been an ancient luxury hotel.

They were painted shortly before the eruption of Mount Vesuvius in AD79 which buried Pompeii, the city's art superintendent, Pier Giovanni Guzzo, said yesterday.

One of the best-preserved works portrays Calliope, the Greek muse of epic poetry, against a vivid red backdrop. Others depict Erato, the lyre-playing patron of lyric and erotic poetry, and Urania, the muse of astronomy.

The paintings adorn the walls of a building about 600 metres (2,000ft) outside the walls of Pompeii by the side of the modern road between Naples and Salerno.

The building, discovered in 1959, is believed to have been a 1,000 square-metre hotel with thermal baths.

There were no excavations at the site between 1959 and 1999, when an extension of the road was announced.

Archaeologists were sent in to survey the site. Their leader, Salvatore Nappo, said the luxurious building suggested that Pompeii was at the peak of its wealth when the whole area was buried in lava and volcanic ash.

The frescoes are undergoing restoration. [AP, Pompeii]

Fuel tanker crash kills at least 150
At least 150 people were killed when a petrol tanker lost control and crashed into a long queue of vehicles in south-west Nigeria at the weekend, newspapers reported yesterday.

Police in the Ile-Ife area, in south-west Osun state, could not immediately verify the death toll but confirmed that the accident happened on Sunday on the Ibadan-Ife road, about 150 miles north of the commercial capital, Lagos.

"The accident occurred on Sunday evening and it was reported to the police immediately. But I can't give the number of those who died now," a police officer said.

The newspapers said the tanker rammed into vehicles queueing at a police road block.

fields.bodyText: Zimbabwe farmers get day in court Zimbabwe's embattled white farmers told the supreme court yesterday that President Robert Mugabe's "fast- track" land redistribution programme was violent and unconstitutional. The Commercial Farmers Union (CFU), representing 4,200 farmers, almost all white, said on the opening day of the trial that it was challenging Mr Mugabe in the supreme court because it had exhausted all other efforts at negotiating with the government. The CFU said it is not against land reform but it is opposed the illegal and often violent land seizures, which the police have done little to stop. "The fast-track land resettlement is a blatant negation of the rule of law. The whole exercise should be stopped, according to the constitution, [and] in the interest of the country," its lawyer, Adrian de Bourbon, said. "The fast-track programme is an attempt to bypass the courts . . . the government is not concerned with the legalities of the present land resettlement exercise. It is prepared to go about it in willful disregard of the law." Mr De Bourbon told the court, consisting of one Asian, two white and two black judges, that 3,000 farms had been designated for compulsory acquisition without a transparent selection process. Mr Mugabe was quick to dismiss the challenge. "Whatever the courts might say on the matter, the land is ours and we will take it," he said on state television on Sunday. [Andrew Meldrum, Harare] Shark kills Australian swimmer One man was killed and another injured when a shark attacked a group of swimmers in Western Australia early yesterday. Witnesses said the 16ft (5-metre) great white shark tore the leg off Ken Crew, 49, in waist-deep water at Cottesloe Beach, Perth. The local businessman was hauled from the water alive but died on the beach, despite attempts to revive him. Another swimmer, Dick Avery, 52, who tried to rescue him, was in a stable condition after undergoing surgery for leg and foot injuries. "There was a whole sea of blood," said Kim Gamble, a cafe owner. "From the balcony I could see this huge shark. When we saw the fin and the tail, people thought it was two sharks, it was so big." More than 100 people were on the beach when the shark struck. "All of a sudden I heard all this yelling and screaming and looked down the beach [and] saw the blood in the water," said Di McCusker, who had just come out of the sea. It was the third fatal shark attack in Australian waters in recent weeks. This one struck in a place which has not seen a shark-related death for 75 years. In late September two surfers were killed in shark attacks on the south coast. Perth's beaches were closed yesterday as the Western Australia fisheries department monitored the shark's movements. The fisheries minister later issued a special permit to kill the great white, which is usually a protected species in Australia. [Patrick Barkham, Sydney] Sandinista mayor for Managua A leftwing Sandinista candidate was declared mayor of the Nicaraguan capital, Managua, yesterday. Herty Lewites, who defeated a candidate from the Liberal Constitutionalist party, which has governed the capital and the country since the Sandinistas were defeated by the US-backed contra rebels, declared victory on Sunday night after the preliminary vote was announced. President Arnoldo Aleman conceded his party's defeat but he vowed that it would continue to be Nicaragua's strongest political force. He predicted that it would win at least 90 of the 154 mayoralties contested on Sunday. With less than 4% of the votes in the capital counted early yesterday, the Sandinista party had won 45%, followed by the Liberal Constitutionalists on 27% and the Conservative party on 26%. Mr Aleman blamed his party's defeat on the Conservatives, saying they divided the vote. [AP, Managua] Pompeii yields hotel fresco A cycle of frescoes almost 2,000 years old has been unearthed near Pompeii during the delayed excavation of a building thought to have been an ancient luxury hotel. They were painted shortly before the eruption of Mount Vesuvius in AD79 which buried Pompeii, the city's art superintendent, Pier Giovanni Guzzo, said yesterday. One of the best-preserved works portrays Calliope, the Greek muse of epic poetry, against a vivid red backdrop. Others depict Erato, the lyre-playing patron of lyric and erotic poetry, and Urania, the muse of astronomy. There were no excavations at the site between 1959 and 1999, when an extension of the road was announced. Archaeologists were sent in to survey the site. Their leader, Salvatore Nappo, said the luxurious building suggested that Pompeii was at the peak of its wealth when the whole area was buried in lava and volcanic ash. The frescoes are undergoing restoration. [AP, Pompeii] Fuel tanker crash kills at least 150 At least 150 people were killed when a petrol tanker lost control and crashed into a long queue of vehicles in south-west Nigeria at the weekend, newspapers reported yesterday. Police in the Ile-Ife area, in south-west Osun state, could not immediately verify the death toll but confirmed that the accident happened on Sunday on the Ibadan-Ife road, about 150 miles north of the commercial capital, Lagos. "The accident occurred on Sunday evening and it was reported to the police immediately. But I can't give the number of those who died now," a police officer said. webTitle: The Paula I knew

fields.headline: The Paula I knew
fields.standfirst: Just who was Paula Yates? An out-of-control wild child, or a home-loving mum who fell into bad company? Tonight, a Channel 4 documentary aims to uncover the truth.  Michelle Hodgson, her former publicist, is impressed
fields.trailText: Just who was Paula Yates? An out-of-control wild child, or a home-loving mum who fell into bad company? Tonight, a Channel 4 documentary aims to uncover the truth. Michelle Hodgson, her former publicist, is impressed
fields.body:
A few years ago, I was working with Paula Yates on the publicity for her novel, and had booked her on a chat show in Dublin. Afterwards, we went clubbing with the other guests, Lennox Lewis and fashion designer John Rocha. While Lewis's entourage cruised the club in search of women, he and Paula sat on a sofa having a natter. After an hour, she headed back to the hotel to be with her kids. "Lennox is very sweet but I think he's a bit inexperienced with women," she told me the next day. That really summed Paula up. She wanted to be fantastically glamorous, but what she really loved was an intimate chat before heading to bed with a cup of cocoa.

When Princess Diana met Paula before Michael Hutchence died, she thanked the presenter for sharing the duty of keeping the tabloids sated. For the most photographed woman in the world, who could spark a debate on cellulite from a car-seat imprint on her thigh, the presence of another blonde who gave good headline was a welcome respite. And, of course, Paula's public response to any tabloid abuse was newsworthy in itself: she would strut through Heathrow wearing a skimpy "Little Miss Naughty" T-shirt.

The Diana anecdote, told by Michael Hutchence's brother Rhett, appears in The Real Paula Yates, tonight's Channel 4 documentary, which has been hastily - but tastefully - put together in the wake of her death. Channel 4 was, in many ways, Paula's natural home, from her Pretty in Punk days at The Tube to her bedroom antics on The Big Breakfast. Clips of her interviewing Hutchence on both shows, several years apart, sizzle with sexual tension.

The programme covers a lot of familiar ground: her isolated childhood; the jelly and ice-cream party she wanted her own family life to be; the career that paved the way for female presenters; and her comet-blaze of passion for Hutchence, the Heathcliffe to her Cathy. It has an impressive roster of contributors who genuinely knew her sharing their insights and memories, including her friend Brenda Brewin's summation that Paula "wanted to be somewhere between Marilyn Monroe and Mary Poppins".

Among the TV clips is the first edition of The Tube, when Paula, sprightly in a fairy ball-gown of candy-pink tulle, cheerfully confesses that her stomach will be growing week by week. The Tube's producers had wanted a wild child presenter for their anarchic new show; instead they got one with child. And this was a decade and a half before the Pregnant Spices and Zoë Ball could Carry On Up The Duff without raising the collective public's eyebrow.

I was glad to find something to smile about in many of the clips and anecdotes, because the Paula Yates I worked with was fun. She would dash out of her stint at The Big Breakfast looking like a Barbie punk princess in a lacy designer dress with balcony-cleavage that needed more flesh-coloured undergarments than a village hall production of Hair. There is nothing quite like a publicity book tour to bring a celebrity down to earth, but Paula kept her sense of humour throughout, even when her interview on BBC Radio 4's Woman's Hour was preceded by an item on constipation that was as painfully long as the affliction itself.

"Flirting is the very essence of my being", was Paula's tongue-in-cheek answer for one magazine questionnaire. "She was great at flirting and keeping it at that," Simon Le Bon explains in the documentary. But she also loved a girly giggle with other women. She called me "the lissom Michelle" and pinched my bum when I wasn't looking. We discussed make-up, underwear, families, life in general and - once - drugs. She told me she had heard that Hutchence took drugs and didn't I think drug users were unsavoury, all that lying in the gutter and dribbling at the mouth? Then she gave that lupine grin.

The literary dinners she attended were the first time she spent nights away from her girls, and she would dive into toyshops to stock up on fairy outfits to take back for them. It was only after she started seeing Hutchence that the drug rumours began. It was a far cry from the home-loving, clean-living Paula of old.

The documentary contains some poignant images of Tiger Lily, a "bonsai Michael" as Paula described her, clinging to her mother's torso at her father's funeral like a wide-eyed koala cub. I was reminded of Frances Bean after Kurt Cobain's death three years earlier, same eyes, same grip. The all-too-frequent cry nowadays of "What about the children?" - the innocent casualties of celebrity crash and burn - is put into context by Chris Hill from Ensign Records. "If she'd stayed clean when Michael had gone... she would have got on with her life, because the kids meant that much to her... [the drink and the drugs] made the kids secondary." It's no excuse, as they say, but it's a reason.

Nonetheless, Brenda Brewin gives evidence that Paula was starting to pull herself out of the domino effect of the tragedies that had blighted the final three years of her life. Her last summer was spent in Hastings where she was planning to move into a house by the sea. Paula once told me how much she envied people who had the courage to give everything up for a more peaceful way of life. Perhaps she is walking along that beach now, barefoot, her sparkling evening gown skimming the sands.

 The Real Paula Yates, tonight, 9.30pm, C4

webTitle: Girl, 16, sues father over payment of school fees

fields.headline: Girl, 16, sues father over payment of school fees
fields.standfirst:
Computer executive refused to fund daughter's studies at new institution as part of feud with ex-wife, court hears in landmark case
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Computer executive refused to fund daughter's studies at new institution as part of feud with ex-wife, court hears in landmark case.
fields.body:
A schoolgirl yesterday took her estranged father to court in an attempt to force him to pay her private school fees.

Nicole Lavelle, 16, told Stirling sheriff court that her father, Callum, was happy to pay £12,000 a year for her to attend an exclusive school of his choosing, but withdrew his support when she decided to go to a cheaper school closer to her mother's home.

Miss Lavelle said that her father, who lives in Dunblane, near Stirling, told her that she must decide between a relationship with him and a relationship with her mother.

As she took the stand, dressed in her navy school uniform, Miss Lavelle said she had tried to find equal ground between her parents when they divorced in 1998. But she could think of no other reason for her father's actions than the feud between her parents.

She is suing Mr Lavelle for the £6,600 a year she needs to continue her education at King's School, Worcester.

If Miss Lavelle is successful, she will become the first child in Scotland to use the "right to aliment", which is contained in the Family Law (Scotland) Act 1985, to force a parent to pay private school fees.

The court heard that when Miss Lavelle's parents split up she decided to stay in Scotland with her father, a computer executive in Stirling.

Initially the pair lived together in a rented flat. But the pressures of Mr Lavelle's job made him decide to send his daughter away to school.

"My dad said I had to go to a boarding school because he worked abroad a lot and there would be nobody at home," she told the court. "He said it was in everybody's best interests."

While her father stayed in Dunblane and remarried, Miss Lavelle studied at Harrogate Ladies' College, North Yorkshire. Although she initially enjoyed her time there, she became increasingly unhappy as she watched the day girls return to their homes each evening. Believing she was missing out on a home life, Miss Lavelle tried to enrol in Cheltenham Ladies' College so that she could be on "neutral ground" with her parents.

She told the court that she planned to spend weekends with her mother and sister in Peopleton, near Worcester, and longer breaks with her father. The court heard that her father was amenable to this, but then he visited her at Harrogate and told her he had changed his mind.

She said her father gave her an ultimatum; she could stay at Harrogate or have a relationship with her mother and never see him again.

She said her father, who is reported to earn £85,000, told her that he had been contacted by the Child Support Agency. "He told me that people who were contacted by the Child Support Agency committed suicide," she added. It was at this point that Miss Lavelle moved to the school closer to her mother, Belinda, with whom she now lives.

Later, Mr Lavelle told the court he had initially agreed that he would fund his children through boarding school.

"I simply cannot meet the regular fees for private education at this moment in time," he said. The court's decision will be issued within 28 days.

webTitle: The return of the Roman empire

fields.headline: The return of the Roman empire
fields.standfirst: It is Great Jubilee year in the Eternal City. Buildings have been restored, churches made more accessible - and now some stupendous art exhibitions have opened.  Jonathan Jones  on two masters, Poussin and Botticelli
fields.trailText: It is Great Jubilee year in the Eternal City. Buildings have been restored, churches made more accessible - and now some stupendous art exhibitions have opened. Jonathan Jones on two masters, Poussin and Botticelli
fields.body:
Nicolas Poussin and Sandro Botticelli were painters of myth, who pictured the gods and demigods of ancient Greece and Rome as immediately as if they had been born 2,000 years ago in the fields of Campania, worshipping Bacchus. Poussin was obsessed with Rome. Born in Normandy in 1594, he tried and failed twice to travel to the city before he finally secured the patronage to live there. Poussin was an artist of ruins, decline and melancholy. His classical world is perfect but doomed. "Et in Arcadia ego," says the writing on the tomb discovered by the shepherds in his most famous painting: "I too was in Arcadia."

The 15th-century artist Botticelli only came to Rome because the Pope invited him to paint part of the Sistine Chapel. According to Vasari in The Lives of the Painters, the great city was too much for him; he spent all his money and went home to Florence with his tail between his legs. Botticelli's ancient world is defined by sharp lines, sensual bodies and the lucidity of dreams. In The Calumny of Apelles (c.1494), based on ancient descriptions of a lost masterpiece by the painter Apelles, Botticelli stages the action against classical architecture, a monumental setting in which statues seem alive and living people frozen like statues.

Poussin and Botticelli were painters of myth yet both, according to two major exhibitions in Rome, were orthodox Christians, good Catholics all along. This year is Rome's Great Jubilee 2000, a massive celebration declared by the Vatican that has drawn pilgrims to the city from all over the world. Buildings have been cleaned and restored, churches opened at more congenial hours; the eternal city looks more eternal than ever - and there are some stupendous art exhibitions.

The French Academy, which occupies the Villa Medici on the Pincio hill at the top of the Spanish Steps, has The Hidden God, co-curated by Neil MacGregor, director of the National Gallery in London. MacGregor recently presented the TV series Seeing Salvation, which accompanied a show at the National Gallery, and The Hidden God continues his argument that at the core of great European painting is Christianity. Here he focuses on French classicism in the first half of the 17th century, the age of Poussin, the period of a supremely intellectual art - manifesting itself also in the drama of Racine and Corneille - that replaces the sensuousness of Italian Renaissance painting with a self-consciously distanced, historically grand aesthetic.

According to The Hidden God, the art of Poussin and his contemporaries - painters such as Philippe de Champaigne, Charles Le Brun, Simon Vouet and Jacques Stella - is profoundly religious. Yet it is also about myth. French classicism is a deeply melancholy art that acknowledges its own inability to do what painting dreams of doing: to set an absent scene before us. When Italian painters in the early 17th century wanted to paint Christian stories, they went to extremes to make the Bible real.

Down the hill from the Villa Medici you can step into the church of Santa Maria del Popolo, where Caravaggio's The Crucifixion of St Peter has three men struggling with the weight of St Peter as they try to erect the cross upside-down to which he is nailed. This painting tries to make the martyrdom immediate, as if we were there; the French religious paintings MacGregor and his co-curator Olivier Bonfait have collected do the opposite. They seem to delight in the remoteness of the Christian story, holding it up for scrutiny and, in the case of Poussin, to an analysis of mythic narrative.

Poussin's Annunciation (1657) states explicitly that this is a painting - not the real thing, but an attempt to visualise a written narrative in the Bible. Poussin designed his paintings using a kind of toy theatre in which he arranged little clay figures. This painting bears the traces of that theatre; it is consciously stagey. Mary and the angel are posed on a raised stone stage. Below Mary is a plaque fixed to the stone pedestal on which she sits declaring "Poussin faciebat", Poussin made it, and giving the date. Poussin made this; it is not an image directly inspired by God. The kinds of theology popular in elevated circles in 17th-century France made space for doubt, for a faith won intellectually rather than emotionally.

The Hidden God is a quotation from Pascal, who described painting as a secondary reality that cannot approach the true divine reality and is condemned to be a mourning for what is absent. This mourning is explicit in Poussin's Lamentation, on loan from the National Gallery of Ireland, in which stately robed figures weep over the grey, lifeless body of Christ. To the right is a classical tomb with a black doorway to death; in the distance are the walls of a city. This painting takes us to the still, tragic centre of Poussin's art. He is a tragedian; but is he also a theologian? When a man in an otherwise supremely calm landscape is poisoned and dies in the National Gallery's Landscape with a Man Killed by a Snake, are we really looking at a Christian allegory?

That's what this exhibition suggests. But you can also see Poussin's religious paintings as essays in the power of myth. Poussin was a student of antiquity - he goes to enormous lengths to set his paintings in archaeologically accurate versions of the ancient world - and you can see him as an anthropologist, exploring the meanings of myths in Ovid and in Bible stories alike. In his painting The Abandonment of Moses, he seems most interested in the antiquarian details of the setting: the Sphinx, a pyramid, an obelisk. Poussin concocts a rich blend of Christian and pagan melancholy, a gloomy dance to the music of time. He is a genius of atmosphere. Poussin's paintings juxtapose planes of colour, receding into a distant landscape.

Botticelli is much sharper, more resolved. He defines everything with clear lines and firm perspective: the perfect Florentine Renaissance artist. Pallas and the Centaur stand there before you in the exhibition Sandro Botticelli: Painter of the Divine Comedy on the Quirinale hill. Botticelli does not paint myth at one remove, as a narrative ruin. He puts flesh on the story. Pallas Athena, goddess of wisdom, swathed in laurels and armed with a lethal-looking axe, holds by his tangled, wild hair a centaur, half-man, half-horse, a creature famous for being savage. Their bodies are strong and vivid, and the join of the man's body to that of a horse is so anatomically convincing you can imagine the artist having done some terrible surgical research. Athena is supremely alive, sexy. Botticelli's men and women are "always attractive" noticed the Victorian aesthete Walter Pater.

Botticelli moved in the same circles as the Medici family in Florence, where pagan and Christian ideas were treated as aspects of the same divine truth. Botticelli gives ancient myth an unadorned energy. He does the same thing when he paints the Christian story. When in the 1490s Botticelli became a follower of the religious extremist Savonarola, who predicted the destruction of Florence and the salvation of only the few, he painted the Apocalypse with passionate urgency. In his Crucifixion with the Madonna and an Angel (1498-1500) Florence is about to be destroyed by fire from heaven.

Botticelli's lucid way with myth makes his illustrations to Dante's Divine Comedy, which are the core of this exhibition and will tour next year to the Royal Academy, his masterpiece and one of the giddiest high points of western art. His drawings take us in detail through Dante's three books, Inferno, Purgatorio and Paradiso, telling the entire poem in a sublime comic strip, presenting a diagram of Hell as an inverted mountain, a stepped funnel leading down to the place where great Satan eats souls. Botticelli keeps to this spatial conception as we follow Dante and Virgil from one scene of horror to another. They enter the City of Dis, where the houses are tombs imprisoning sinners in perpetual fire; they cross rivers of boiling blood where souls are tormented by "hellrakers", demons with spiked rakes; and they meet Centaurs, employed in hell along with harpies and gorgons to torture sinners.

Botticelli's underworld is a fusion of Christian and pagan myth, drawn with a precise, unhesitating line that makes you believe he has just seen it all and set it down, quickly and accu rately. This is a mythological world that is comprehensively visible - until we reach Paradise. There, Botticelli leaves the pages almost blank. Paradise is not visible like Hell. It is not something we can picture. You cannot reinvent either Poussin or Botticelli as straight- forwardly Christian. Rome is right to celebrate the Christian dimension to European art in the Vatican's Jubilee Year. But to enjoy great works of art like these, you must also acknowledge the pagan mysteries.

 The Hidden God, The Villa Medici, Rome (00 39 06 67611) until January 28. Botticelli: The Drawings for Dante's Divine Comedy (currently at the Scudiere Papali al Quirinale, Piazza Quirinale, Rome) opens at the Royal Academy, London, March 17, 2001.

Poussin was obsessed with Rome. Born in Normandy in 1594, he tried and failed twice to travel to the city before he finally secured the patronage to live there. Poussin was an artist of ruins, decline and melancholy. His classical world is perfect but doomed. "Et in Arcadia ego," says the writing on the tomb discovered by the shepherds in his most famous painting: "I too was in Arcadia." The 15th-century artist Botticelli only came to Rome because the Pope invited him to paint part of the Sistine Chapel. According to Vasari in The Lives of the Painters, the great city was too much for him; he spent all his money and went home to Florence with his tail between his legs. Botticelli's ancient world is defined by sharp lines, sensual bodies and the lucidity of dreams. In The Calumny of Apelles (c.1494), based on ancient descriptions of a lost masterpiece by the painter Apelles, Botticelli stages the action against classical architecture, a monumental setting in which statues seem alive and living people frozen like statues. Poussin and Botticelli were painters of myth yet both, according to two major exhibitions in Rome, were orthodox Christians, good Catholics all along. This year is Rome's Great Jubilee 2000, a massive celebration declared by the Vatican that has drawn pilgrims to the city from all over the world. Buildings have been cleaned and restored, churches opened at more congenial hours; the eternal city looks more eternal than ever - and there are some stupendous art exhibitions. The French Academy, which occupies the Villa Medici on the Pincio hill at the top of the Spanish Steps, has The Hidden God, co-curated by Neil MacGregor, director of the National Gallery in London. MacGregor recently presented the TV series Seeing Salvation, which accompanied a show at the National Gallery, and The Hidden God continues his argument that at the core of great European painting is Christianity. Here he focuses on French classicism in the first half of the 17th century, the age of Poussin, the period of a supremely intellectual art - manifesting itself also in the drama of Racine and Corneille - that replaces the sensuousness of Italian Renaissance painting with a self-consciously distanced, historically grand aesthetic. According to The Hidden God, the art of Poussin and his contemporaries - painters such as Philippe de Champaigne, Charles Le Brun, Simon Vouet and Jacques Stella - is profoundly religious. Yet it is also about myth. French classicism is a deeply melancholy art that acknowledges its own inability to do what painting dreams of doing: to set an absent scene before us. When Italian painters in the early 17th century wanted to paint Christian stories, they went to extremes to make the Bible real. Down the hill from the Villa Medici you can step into the church of Santa Maria del Popolo, where Caravaggio's The Crucifixion of St Peter has three men struggling with the weight of St Peter as they try to erect the cross upside-down to which he is nailed. This painting tries to make the martyrdom immediate, as if we were there; the French religious paintings MacGregor and his co-curator Olivier Bonfait have collected do the opposite. They seem to delight in the remoteness of the Christian story, holding it up for scrutiny and, in the case of Poussin, to an analysis of mythic narrative. Poussin's Annunciation (1657) states explicitly that this is a painting - not the real thing, but an attempt to visualise a written narrative in the Bible. Poussin designed his paintings using a kind of toy theatre in which he arranged little clay figures. This painting bears the traces of that theatre; it is consciously stagey. Mary and the angel are posed on a raised stone stage. Below Mary is a plaque fixed to the stone pedestal on which she sits declaring "Poussin faciebat", Poussin made it, and giving the date. Poussin made this; it is not an image directly inspired by God. The kinds of theology popular in elevated circles in 17th-century France made space for doubt, for a faith won intellectually rather than emotionally. The Hidden God is a quotation from Pascal, who described painting as a secondary reality that cannot approach the true divine reality and is condemned to be a mourning for what is absent. This mourning is explicit in Poussin's Lamentation, on loan from the National Gallery of Ireland, in which stately robed figures weep over the grey, lifeless body of Christ. To the right is a classical tomb with a black doorway to death; in the distance are the walls of a city. This painting takes us to the still, tragic centre of Poussin's art. He is a tragedian; but is he also a theologian? When a man in an otherwise supremely calm landscape is poisoned and dies in the National Gallery's Landscape with a Man Killed by a Snake, are we really looking at a Christian allegory? That's what this exhibition suggests. But you can also see Poussin's religious paintings as essays in the power of myth. Poussin was a student of antiquity - he goes to enormous lengths to set his paintings in archaeologically accurate versions of the ancient world - and you can see him as an anthropologist, exploring the meanings of myths in Ovid and in Bible stories alike. In his painting The Abandonment of Moses, he seems most interested in the antiquarian details of the setting: the Sphinx, a pyramid, an obelisk. Poussin concocts a rich blend of Christian and pagan melancholy, a gloomy dance to the music of time. He is a genius of atmosphere. Poussin's paintings juxtapose planes of colour, receding into a distant landscape. Botticelli is much sharper, more resolved. He defines everything with clear lines and firm perspective: the perfect Florentine Renaissance artist. Pallas and the Centaur stand there before you in the exhibition Sandro Botticelli: Painter of the Divine Comedy on the Quirinale hill. Botticelli does not paint myth at one remove, as a narrative ruin. He puts flesh on the story. Pallas Athena, goddess of wisdom, swathed in laurels and armed with a lethal-looking axe, holds by his tangled, wild hair a centaur, half-man, half-horse, a creature famous for being savage. Their bodies are strong and vivid, and the join of the man's body to that of a horse is so anatomically convincing you can imagine the artist having done some terrible surgical research. Athena is supremely alive, sexy. Botticelli's men and women are "always attractive" noticed the Victorian aesthete Walter Pater. Botticelli moved in the same circles as the Medici family in Florence, where pagan and Christian ideas were treated as aspects of the same divine truth. Botticelli gives ancient myth an unadorned energy. He does the same thing when he paints the Christian story. When in the 1490s Botticelli became a follower of the religious extremist Savonarola, who predicted the destruction of Florence and the salvation of only the few, he painted the Apocalypse with passionate urgency. In his Crucifixion with the Madonna and an Angel (1498-1500) Florence is about to be destroyed by fire from heaven. Botticelli's lucid way with myth makes his illustrations to Dante's Divine Comedy, which are the core of this exhibition and will tour next year to the Royal Academy, his masterpiece and one of the giddiest high points of western art. His drawings take us in detail through Dante's three books, Inferno, Purgatorio and Paradiso, telling the entire poem in a sublime comic strip, presenting a diagram of Hell as an inverted mountain, a stepped funnel leading down to the place where great Satan eats souls. Botticelli keeps to this spatial conception as we follow Dante and Virgil from one scene of horror to another. They enter the City of Dis, where the houses are tombs imprisoning sinners in perpetual fire; they cross rivers of boiling blood where souls are tormented by "hellrakers", demons with spiked rakes; and they meet Centaurs, employed in hell along with harpies and gorgons to torture sinners. Botticelli's underworld is a fusion of Christian and pagan myth, drawn with a precise, unhesitating line that makes you believe he has just seen it all and set it down, quickly and accu rately. This is a mythological world that is comprehensively visible - until we reach Paradise. There, Botticelli leaves the pages almost blank. Paradise is not visible like Hell. It is not something we can picture. You cannot reinvent either Poussin or Botticelli as straight- forwardly Christian. Rome is right to celebrate the Christian dimension to European art in the Vatican's Jubilee Year. But to enjoy great works of art like these, you must also acknowledge the pagan mysteries.  The Hidden God, The Villa Medici, Rome (00 39 06 67611) until January 28. webTitle: Sidelines

fields.headline: Sidelines
fields.body:
Floods, fuel crises, falling cod stocks... the country is riven with disasters of biblical proportions. And into this arena of ghastliness, a further horror has plopped. Last weekend's revelations that traces of cocaine have been found inside the houses of parliament left us reaching for the Christmas rum in tremulous disbelief. The Sunday Times claimed that a gram of cocaine would give four people enough of a hit to keep them alert through "many hours" of parliamentary sittings. Does this multiple of two indicate that our parliamentarians are operating some sort of narcotic pairing system? And who were the poor sods who had to spend hours in the bogs, carefully covering the cisterns with sticky tape to pick up those "white particles"? Anyone applying for work experience at the Times now knows what to expect. Beats photocopying the tea.

: According to a recent poll of pregnant women, impending motherhood induces cravings for, among other oddities, children's gym shoes. But how does one serve such a shoe? Shucked, or with the foot still in place? Next to a big bowl of something lovely (our preferred option)? Or were you just trying to get attention, ladies?

 Researchers at the University of California claim that women cope better than men under stress. While men react to pressure with a "fight or flight" response, women's hormonal make-up causes them to "tend and befriend". Ain't oestrogen grand? Peculiar, then, that anxiety produces a somewhat different response in Sidelines - either "scream and shout", "punch and kick" or "drink and fall over".

 Proof, if proof be needed, that it is possible to have too much of a good thing. George Clooney has lost his £10m job as Batman because he is, according to studio executives, too handsome. Which reminds Sidelines of the time we were asked to leave the world for being too hilarious.

webTitle: Government advice on getting married

fields.headline: Oh yes you do
fields.standfirst: He's dropped to one knee, you've got the rock, now all you need is the government's helpful leaflet on getting married.  Kate Clanchy wonders what advice it will give
fields.trailText: He's dropped to one knee, you've got the rock, now all you need is the government's helpful leaflet on getting married. Kate Clanchy wonders what advice it will give
fields.body:
Marriage is good for you - New Labour says so. Not that they are prepared to do anything radical to encourage it, of course, like changing tax allowances or turning Buckingham Palace into the People's Register Office. Instead, each affianced couple will be given an official government leaflet on how to get/stay married.

It was revealed last weekend that the book, Married Life, will go to every couple planning a wedding, provided they can get through the complexities of proposing without state assistance. Presumably it will have a photo of Tony and Cherie on the front, and be filled with sound advice drawn from Relate. There will be a particularly cringe-making bit on sex, I'm sure, featuring two round, sad cartoons under a floral blanket.

The guide will include advice on keeping the romance in your marriage after the first child is born, emotional commitment and talking to your partner lovingly. There will, one hopes, be a list of appropriately breathless language endorsed by the likes of Robin Cook, and pensees on marital teething troubles from the cabinet's own newly-wed, Gordon Brown. Eventually, Britain will be populated by a grinning morass of emotional automatons, unable even to hand-hold without parliamentary assent.

Wives, I imagine, will read the guide more than husbands, searching earnestly through the pages on dividing household chores, wondering if any of the solutions applies. Women work harder at most things - they tend to be grateful to be married at all. "If you can't cut a good slice of bread, you'll never find a good husband," my great-grandmother balefully proclaimed to my grandmother, and by the time the list of necessary virtues got to me, I felt it had expanded to having a good career, being a kitchen whizz, maintaining a perfectly toned figure and never, ever seeming needy.

We still tend to assume all men are Martin Clunes, desperately avoiding commitment, and all women are Bridget Jones, desperately searching for it, yet all the statistical evidence points to an opposite set of facts: that marriage makes men wealthier, healthier and happier, women sadder and sicker. Marriage, in short, seems to be something men have to be persuaded into for their own good, like warm socks, and women should be discouraged from. Perhaps we need two leaflets. Men's could be filled with images of happy fathers and husbands, like a Gillette ad, while women's could include the following warnings...

Don't get married because you want a big wedding. The satin meringue, the train, the veil, the flowers and general hoo-ha disseminated by fairy tales and Sindy dolls are instruments of oppression designed to co-opt you into the pitfalls of marriage. They reached their apogee with Diana and look what happened to that marriage.

Don't get married because you want a minimalist wedding, either. Romeo Gigli slips, Emma Hope slippers and artfully deconstructed flowers only look different - what matters is the groom. If you find yourself haunted by images of yourself in such a get-up, then buy it and wear it round the flat. It will be cheaper in the long run.

Don't get married to triumph over your girlfriends, either by sending out coy announcements or making them dress up in peach tulle lampshades. You may need them yet.

Don't get married to shut your mother up. She'll only just be getting started.

Don't get married because you're about to turn 30/35/40. It is exaggerated about your eggs going off, and consider how much worse it is to be 30/35/40 and married to someone ghastly than 30/35/40, free and single.

Don't get married because you've been together seven years and need something to talk about. Remember, the wedding only lasts one day.

Don't get married because you think it might improve him. All that security and comfort is only going to make him even more like himself.

Don't get married because you think he'll do. If you find yourself carefully enumerating his good qualities over and over - reconsider.

Don't get married until you have a joint bank account.This is what "for richer, for poorer" means. Shun anyone who breathes the word "allowance".

Don't get married unless you're absolutely certain he understands that housework exists, is hard and must be catered for in the family budget.

In fact, I don't think these precepts should be consigned to a leaflet at all. I think they should be carefully intoned to new fiancees by an impressive state appointee, someone along the lines of Barbara Castle. True, it might be alarming, but I'm sure it would bring the divorce rate down and that, presumably, is what the government wants.

webTitle: Figuring out the facts in drive on begging

fields.headline: Figuring out the facts in drive on begging
fields.trailText: A young man in tracksuit bottoms and grubby trainers is slumped against a wall. In his hands is a piece of cardboard with the scrawled words: "If you really want to help me, call Change a Life 0845 60 61 62 3"
fields.body:
A young man in tracksuit bottoms and grubby trainers is slumped against a wall. In his hands is a piece of cardboard with the scrawled words: "If you really want to help me, call Change a Life 0845 60 61 62 3"

Mo Mowlam, the Cabinet Office minister, standing beside the posters to launch the government's campaign on begging, kept urging photographers to "get the number".

But other numbers were preoccupying the media yesterday. The Express trumpeted "startling links between begging and crime" - unpublished government figures said that 75% of arrested beggars had criminal records, it claimed. The BBC reported another figure: 86% of rough sleepers were drug users, it said.

A spokeswoman for Shelter, which declined to take part in the government campaign, said: "If we are told that this isn't an anti-begging campaign, then why were two hardline figures leaked to the media in advance of full publication of the research ?

"They did not leak the one that said over a third of people are looking for assistance with a drug problem, or issues about family breakdown in the background, or about finding accommodation."

It was not surprising that many homeless people have criminal records, the spokeswoman said, as the problems of housing ex-prisoners were well-known. As for drugs, the government research quoted by the BBC was less dramatic than the bald figure suggests. While 86% of rough sleepers reported some drug-taking, only 57% were "problem drug users" who regularly abused a hard drug.

Launching the Change a Life campaign yesterday, Ms Mowlam insisted that the government was not telling people not to give. "It's rubbish that we are telling people not to give. We are saying, If you want to give, please give. But if you want to give in a way that will change a life, think again."

The £240,000 advertising campaign will encourage the public to donate to a fund split equally between four homeless charities - Centrepoint, Crisis, the National Homeless Alliance, and the Salvation Army.

Ms Mowlam and Louise Casey, director of the Rough Sleepers Unit, spoke of the hold that drug dealers have on the homeless.

"Every time I walk home from the House of Commons after a late vote, I walk down the Strand where I see the homeless being hassled by pushers," Ms Mowlam said. "If someone on the streets isn't an addict, they will be."

Shelter has warned that discouraging giving to beggars could lead to an increase in crime. In some parts of the country there is a waiting time of up to six months for rehabilitation, it says.

Shaks Ghosh, chief executive of Crisis, was keen to see the debate shift away from the controversy over begging. "The campaign must be part of a wider response and much more needs to be done to help people battling drink or drug problems."

webTitle: Comment: Hugo Young on the US elections

fields.headline: Cynical, fickle, grasping - and that's just the electorate
fields.standfirst:
Old political certainties have gone, but voters still want firm government

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Old political certainties have gone, but voters still want firm government
fields.body:
Once upon a time, politics was easy. Two rules governed almost every move. First, the choice could be defined as left versus right, and allegiances arranged themselves accordingly. In the 1951 British election, when 83% turned out to vote, 97% of them voted Labour or Conservative. Second, economic competence, as proved or disproved in the previous few years, had a correlation with the next election result. There seemed to be a direct trade-off between votes and jobs. Democracies rewarded leaders who supplied high growth, low inflation and reduced unemployment.

Neither rule any longer holds. Allegiance has lost the glue of heavy doctrinal disagreement. Politicians no longer refer to themselves, or the other side, as left or right (though it was startling to read in Peter Mandelson's important Morrison lecture last week a straight-faced reference to "what Tony Blair calls One Nation socialism" - a phrase not recently heard, I think, from Mr Blair). Simultaneously, economic success no longer guarantees anything. Look at Al Gore. He inherits the longest run of economic prosperity on every count - jobs, growth, stock market - America has known, but may today become the most shocking loser in American history.

So America is replacing old paradigms. A sound economy is the basis not for endorsing present office-holders but flirting with their enemies. Instead of competence, the people dabble with dignity, respect, leadership and similar abstractions layered with moral coating. For Mr Blair, a Gore defeat will be worrying not because it signals, other than to exuberant rightist pattern-makers, the fall of the centre-left, but because it shows how unreliable the rewards can be for that old elusive goal, a solid economic record. Should Blair, also, be seeking an alternative appeal? Facing his own crisis, in the form of fuel protests, will he do so?

In this de-racinated environment, nobody can be sure how big the crisis will be. A number of epithets fit the electorate that has evolved from the tribal, committed body of half-a-century ago. How about cynical, disbelieving, fickle, grasping, materialistic, self-centred, loose, indifferent? Perhaps it can't be relied on to identify the higher good, as against instant advantage. More engaged and less moralistic than the US electorate, it may be regarded as no less frightening. There's a temptation to search as desperately as Al Gore and George W Bush for the tricksy embraces that will win it over.

This is not only unnecessary. It would also be dangerous. For one thing, Britain is at a different point in the electoral cycle, year four not year eight of a government the voters might feel free to get bored with, and casually throw out despite unprecedented economic prosperity. More important, it's by no means clear that in the end the British electorate want governments to be as irresolute as they are themselves. The old anchors have gone, but two new rules are cardinal in Blair's present situation.

First, the government can't credibly amend its commitment to long-term economic stability. It paid a heavy political price for declaring this ambition from the start, and running public spending on a tight rein in its first two years. That's why health and transport, and now environmental protection, still show painful evidence of under-spending, more than three years in. The justification for that would be destroyed by a panicky pre-election blow-out.

In his speech to the CBI yesterday, Gordon Brown rammed home the long-termist message. Many chancellors have spouted it before him. Nigel Lawson thought his tax-cutting 1988 budget laid the base for a long-term transformation of the economy; instead it contained the seed of the boom-and-bust that persisted into the 1990s. Mr Brown is making a believable virtue of the stability which is the goal he clings to. His prudent, sonorous, Scottish presence at the Treasury personifies the very reverse of fickleness. It's the essential precondition of survival for the governing party Labour has become. In place of left-right dialectic, he says, we offer a massive determination not to yield to short-term pressures. It's what - sometimes to our cost, and some times, as with pensions, by inhuman negligence we must correct - we are about.

Second, the government needs to be in charge of politics. The lures the other way are devious and spectacularly dishonest. Watching the next bout of fuel protest gather, one sees newspapers apparently more united against it than they were last time, and a Conservative leadership mouthing its refusal to support direct action. But the words have weaselly accompaniments. We sympathise with the hauliers' predicament, says the Mail, we must understand their pain. By implication, their case is serious. Likewise, Conservative PR hacks like Lord Bell note the body of opinion which, according to a Sunday poll, would support further haulier blockades. Affecting merely clinical interest, on Breakfast with Frost, he can barely conceal a foaming excitement at the prospect.

From a party viewpoint he may be right. The Tories look with keenest anticipation on the possible breakdown of Britain. But this only makes clearer the course the government must take. People expect it, above all else, to keep the country running. The lures must be resisted. So must the threats and the bogus ridicule. Of the many false arguments made in defence of the hauliers, the most corrupt is the claim that, if trouble now happens, ministers are to blame for taking measures to anticipate it. That such a travesty can be seriously touted in the same leader columns that two months ago were chiding ministers for their lack of readiness shows how political this dispute has become. If Blair wins this one, they're saying, he's got the election cold. Let us therefore do our best to see he doesn't.

The public, however, takes a more complex attitude. It long ago lost the habit of political allegiance. It can still tell pollsters, before the damage starts, that it supports direct action in favour of lower fuel duties. But in the end it wants governments to govern. In its wisdom, it knows that this is how things must be, and also, even more plainly, that the alternative government now on offer is a non-starter. It is ready to channel short-termism, lower petrol prices, into temporary protest, but long-termism - its preference for future government - into the resumption of support for Labour, as was shown very clearly in opinion polls taken soon after the September calamities were over.

The old anchors may have gone, but the demand for a government that does not drift from strategy and conviction has not. If anything, Labour ministers have been short of that quality. fields.bodyText: Once upon a time, politics was easy. Two rules governed almost every move. First, the choice could be defined as left versus right, and allegiances arranged themselves accordingly. In the 1951 British election, when 83% turned out to vote, 97% of them voted Labour or Conservative. Second, economic competence, as proved or disproved in the previous few years, had a correlation with the next election result. There seemed to be a direct trade-off between votes and jobs. Democracies rewarded leaders who supplied high growth, low inflation and reduced unemployment. Neither rule any longer holds. Allegiance has lost the glue of heavy doctrinal disagreement. Politicians no longer refer to themselves, or the other side, as left or right (though it was startling to read in Peter Mandelson's important Morrison lecture last week a straight-faced reference to "what Tony Blair calls One Nation socialism" - a phrase not recently heard, I think, from Mr Blair). Simultaneously, economic success no longer guarantees anything. Look at Al Gore. He inherits the longest run of economic prosperity on every count - jobs, growth, stock market - America has known, but may today become the most shocking loser in American history. So America is replacing old paradigms. A sound economy is the basis not for endorsing present office-holders but flirting with their enemies. It paid a heavy political price for declaring this ambition from the start, and running public spending on a tight rein in its first two years. fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: One of the quotations from Verdi's Otello in the piece presented under the byline of Placido Domingo (extracted from a new book about him), page 8, G2, November 3, was wrong. "Tu? Indietro! Fuggi! M'hai levato alla croce," should be "Tu? Indietro! Fuggi! M'hai legato alla croce." The translation ("Get away from me, you who have tied me to the cross") reflected the correct original. The mistake was ours and not Placido Domingo's.
fields.body:
One of the quotations from Verdi's Otello in the piece presented under the byline of Placido Domingo (extracted from a new book about him), page 8, G2, November 3, was wrong. "Tu? Indietro! Fuggi! M'hai levato alla croce," should be "Tu? Indietro! Fuggi! M'hai legato alla croce." The translation ("Get away from me, you who have tied me to the cross") reflected the correct original. The mistake was ours and not Placido Domingo's.

In the caption to the picture on page 21 (Reviews), November 4, the details were transposed. We should have said: Christine Rice as Musetta (left) and Sandra Ford as Mimi in Leoncavallo's La Bohème at the London Coliseum.

Several readers questioned whether the picture identified as a Sputnik, page, 7, G2, yesterday could possibly have been that. The answer is probably not. It had lain undisturbed in our files since 1957 and had written on it "Science fiction? Extra care." The original caption described it as "Sputnik 1 beginning its flight... cradled in a giant rocket plane."

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. Readers may contact the office of the readers' editor by telephoning 020-7239 9589 between 11am and 5pm Monday to Friday.

webTitle: Letters: US elections

fields.headline: America's knife-edge vote
fields.trailText: It was rather maddening to see repeated the false US Republican assertion that Ross Perot cost their party the White House in 1992 (Eyes left, October 25). He did nothing of the kind. Perot drew equally from the supporters of the elder George Bush and Bill Clinton.
fields.body:
It was rather maddening to see repeated the false US Republican assertion that Ross Perot cost their party the White House in 1992 (Eyes left, October 25). He did nothing of the kind. Perot drew equally from the supporters of the elder George Bush and Bill Clinton.

Furthermore, Perot was rightwing only by European standards; so too are virtually all American politicians except Ralph Nader. Perot stood to the left of the Republican party on such issues as tax, abortion, foreign policy, international trade and campaign finance reform. In Nader's case, however, almost none of his supporters see the junior Bush as their second choice. If Gore loses, Nader will have been a highly relevant factor in making Gore's leftwing support more tepid than it would otherwise have been.
Andrew Hirsch
Bainbridge Island, Washington state andrewhirsch@uswest.net

Jonathan Freedland (The winner will dictate, November 1) writes that the US supreme court protects abortion rights by a "knife's edge" and that if George Bush becomes president the US "would become a land where no pregnancy can be legally terminated". The supreme court had the opportunity in the 1992 Casey case to overturn Roe v Wade. The majority, which included pro-lifers, concluded that Roe v Wade was established legal precedent which makes it unlikely to be overturned. One of the dissenters in Casey has already been replaced by a pro-choice justice.

Even if Bush (who said he would not use abortion as a litmus test for judicial appointments) appointed, as Freedland suggests, conservative, anti-abortion judges, they have to be approved by a majority in a closely divided senate, which is unlikely.
Prof Colleen Graffy
Pepperdine University London colleen.graffy@pepperdine.edu

webTitle: Letters: Family-friendly employment

fields.headline: Story time
fields.trailText: The decline of the bedtime story (Leaders, November 3) is yet another illustration of how children - and their parents - are losing out as a result of the UK's "long-hours" culture. In 1995, the length of the working week, including travel time, for full-time employees was 53 hours for men and 48 for women. In both cases this is eight hours more than in 1982. Women working part-time have also increased hours.
fields.body:
The decline of the bedtime story (Leaders, November 3) is yet another illustration of how children - and their parents - are losing out as a result of the UK's "long-hours" culture. In 1995, the length of the working week, including travel time, for full-time employees was 53 hours for men and 48 for women. In both cases this is eight hours more than in 1982. Women working part-time have also increased hours.

This government's reluctance to sign up to the 48-hour maximum working time directive contrasts with other European countries which have accepted policies to reduce their working week (already shorter than ours), for example to 35 hours for all in France and 32 hours for parents in the Netherlands. If family-friendly employment policies are to be effective in the UK, the trend towards an ever longer working week must be reversed.
Prof Hilary Land
University of Bristol

webTitle: Letters: Let's make amends

fields.headline: Let's make amends
fields.trailText: To preserve a small group of British subjects in the Falkland Islands, we paid in human lives in a war. The restoration of the way of life of a small group of British subjects shamefully thrown out of their island home will, in comparison, cost little (Scandal of Diego Garcia, November 4).
fields.body:
To preserve a small group of British subjects in the Falkland Islands, we paid in human lives in a war. The restoration of the way of life of a small group of British subjects shamefully thrown out of their island home will, in comparison, cost little (Scandal of Diego Garcia, November 4). The government must now spend whatever it may cost to make amends. Our nation's shame is mitigated only by the fact that a British court has called us to account.
Paul Oestreicher
Coventry Cathedral

I note that Mark Lamarr and I are referred to as having voiced fierce opposition to the launch of London Live (Roundup, November 3). In fact I indicated publicly how much I was looking forward to working on the station before its launch in March. I'm happily presenting a successful morning show and I am looking forward to listening to Mark's Christmas Day show.
Robert Elms
BBC London Live 94.9FM

According to Professor Thirlwall (Economics, November 6) the concept of a natural rate of employment is "a theoretical construct with no empirical counterpart that can be identified". Is this what in non-academic circles is called "nonsense"?
Prof M Healy
Harpenden, Herts

Re Kinky Friedman (Letters, November 6), I and a couple of hundred non-PC Glaswegians were treated to the Kinkster performing They Don't Make Jews Like Jesus Any More at the Tron Theatre last week, among a clutch of other ditties, including Get Your Cakes in the Oven and Your Buns in the Bed, a paen to Texan manhood. Dubya, take note.
John McFarlane
University of Strathclyde

2030 eh (The end is nigh, perhaps, November 6)? Better start stocking up then.
R Parrish
Welwyn Garden City, Herts
