webTitle: Education: If you ask me...

fields.headline: If you ask me...
fields.standfirst: My son has missed a lot of school due to illness. He has returned to school for the occasional day, but finds it exhausting and difficult having been absent so often. How do I go about arranging for home tuition so he doesn't fall behind, but also ensure he keeps contact with school?
fields.trailText: My son has missed a lot of school due to illness. He has returned to school for the occasional day, but finds it exhausting and difficult having been absent so often. How do I go about arranging for home tuition so he doesn't fall behind, but also ensure he keeps contact with school?
fields.body:
Dr Carolyn Skilling, director, National Association for the Education of Sick Children

Firstly, go back to your son's school, even if you've talked to them already, and get them to make arrangements to send work home for him. The school may refer you to the local education authority's support services for sick children, who can provide home tuition. The local education authority is legally responsible for ensuring children out of school for any reason receive a "suitable education" (Education Act, 1996). Typically, they will assign one or more tutors for between three to six hours a week.

If you still feel your son's education is inadequate and fragmented, you might then look for an external supplier of home tuition. However, we wouldn't advise removing him from the school roll, as he would then lose his rights and entitlement. As parents, you would become solely responsible for his education. In this case, the school would be likely to inform the LEA's education welfare service and you would have to argue the case with them as to why he was being kept away from school.

If you do decide to look for alternative teaching arrangements, you should be able to hire home tutors yourself. A more recent innovation is electronic tuition by tutors connected via the internet. The service run by the National Association for the Education of Sick Children offers various forms of help. In some circumstances, the LEA will pay for such a service to discharge its legal obligations.

Legal requirements: Local education authorities must arrange for the provision of suitable education for children of compulsory school age (DfEE circular 11/99). "Suitable" education is defined as "efficient education suitable to the age, ability, aptitude and to any special educational needs the child may have."

LEAs decide what is suitable education out of school for a particular child - in consultation with parents and in line with their own policies and the efficient use of resources. Where a child is ill for up to a month, this will be the provision of work by your child's teachers, to help him or her keep up with what is being done in school.

For a longer illness, a tutor may provide home tuition up to key stage 3; at key stage 4, specialist tutors may be provided to fulfil GCSE course requirements. Again, this varies from LEA to LEA.

In all cases, parents should contact the school in the first instance, which should be able to put them in touch with the education welfare service in their area. Many LEAs also provide advice via a pupil support service, which can help both parents and the school. This is especially pertinent if the school has not had to deal with a long-term illness in the past and may not be aware of the full range of services available to you and your child.

 The National Association for the Education of Sick Children is a charity working to improve educational opportunity for all children whose education is disrupted by illness. Free-phone 0800 027 8523 or visit: www.sickchildren.org.uk

Susan Littlemore, from Parentline Plus

It's entirely natural to focus all your attention upon your child and the issues surrounding their well being - but you must acknowledge the stress that this puts you under too.

When a child is ill, especially for a long time, inevitably the whole family has to rearrange its home and working life. If possible, explain what has been happening to your employer, and how this is affecting you. She or he could prove to be of real support.

You're bound to feel anxious when your child goes back to school, even for the occasional day - this is a transition period for you and your child, with all the incumbent worries and concerns.

It's vital to talk about this - try to look beyond the immediate context of your child's illness to your own health. It may help to talk to your GP for a referral to a counsellor, or to contact your local family centre. There may be a support group that can help regarding a specific illness, or contact an advice line such as Parentline Plus.

Many parents feel anger and frustration, born out of tiredness, isolation and lack of support - especially when you're at home with a sick child. Often these emotions are reflected onto the child. By seeking time and attention for yourself, you will be more able to offer such support to your child.

 Parentline Plus can be contacted on freephone 0808 800 2222, or visit: www.parentlineplus.org.uk

webTitle: Furthermore: Donald Hiscock becomes a voyeur

fields.headline: A blurred and reluctant voyeur
fields.standfirst: Where's your glasses. Donald Hiscock gets double vision
fields.trailText: Where's your glasses. Donald Hiscock gets double vision.
fields.body:
I had a strange experience last night. I saw people in a different light. Or rather I didn't see people. I had gone back to college to retrieve my glasses, having put them down somewhere and then gone home without them. I don't know how I managed to do that, but that is not the point. The point is that I became a voyeur, if only a blurred and reluctant one.

I should have realised that things were not quite right when I gazed up at the college building that evening. Each room contained a group of active students and an animated teacher doing things with an overhead projector. It looked like learning was taking place. I rubbed my eyes. This was not the college that I knew.

I wandered through the building in search of my missing spectacles. I peered through the window of room 301, where only hours before I had been exploring a Hamlet soliloquy out loud to myself while my students slept. Now the tables had been pushed aside and an assortment of women in leotards were waving ribbons on sticks to a disco beat.

"Blokes like you need locking up," slurred a voice at my ear. I turned to face Travis, one of the caretakers. His trademark red bandanna, thick stubble and RayBans were for once a welcome sight.

"Oh hello. I need to get into the staff lounge," I said.

"No need to do that," smiled Travis. "You can get an even better view from inside the stationery cupboard. After the tea break they rolls down their socks and does scissor kicks."

"No, it's my glasses," I laughed politely.

"That's all right, I got binoculars I can lend you."

Travis disappeared as quickly as he had arrived. I decided to check out the cafeteria in case I had sent my glasses in on a tray to be washed up.

To my surprise I saw one of my own students, Roxanne, sitting at a table nursing a hot chocolate and reading a book. She must have noticed me groping along the sides of the salad bar. She called out to me, but by now I was literally seeing double. Fortunately I guessed right when I walked over to the left-hand version of Roxanne.

"You haven't lost your glasses again?" she said accusingly.

"What are you doing here?"

"Evening class in English Lit."

"But you do that full-time during the day," I said, "in my class."

"Do you have a problem with that?" rasped one of the Roxannes.

I made my excuses and left. In another classroom I caught sight of Kevin from Hospitality and Catering. Except there were three of him and one of those was circling the other two. Kevin appeared to be running an origami demonstration. Packed ranks of two-headed students were following his every fold and twist as a giant paper stork or tulip or Pokémon character emerged from his clever handiwork.

"That's boring," Travis whispered into my ear. "They got their socks down and they're doing cartwheels in 301," he gasped.

"I need the key Travis," I said.

"No problem," and he darted off down the corridor. "I've found your glasses. They're down in the stationery cupboard. Hurry up."

webTitle: So you want to learn... reflexology

fields.headline: So you want to learn...
fields.standfirst: Reflexology
fields.trailText: Reflexology.
fields.body:
Hullo.

I said hullo. Oh, er, hello.

Not a very encouraging start. How do you mean?

I want to sharpen my reflexes, but yours don't appear much cop. I beg your pardon.

You are a reflexologist? Yes.

Then you could help me? I think you misunderstand reflexology.

So what do you do? Reflexology is one of the most popular complementary therapies available.

You mean it's free? No. ComPLEmentary. It complements the patient in body, mind, emotions, vital force and spiritual energy which have been central to traditional treatments throughout history, but aren't taught in current medical training.

Now I'm not following you. Reflexologists work on the theory that every part of the body is connected by energy pathways, which end in reflex areas on the feet, the hands and the head. They work systematically on these reflex areas and, by applying controlled pressure, stimulate the body's own healing mechanisms.

How? Reflexologists treat patients' feet, and sometimes hands, feeling for areas of sensitivity, or imbalances between various organs as represented by specific areas of the feet.

What's this jag about feet? Our ancestors walked and ran barefoot over uneven ground so the nerve endings and reflex points on their feet were constantly being massaged and stimulated. Nowadays we spend much of our time sitting down, and walk on hard, flat surfaces, wearing thick-soled shoes. It is very easy for gravity to cause a build-up of waste products and a general stagnation in the feet.

So what? Every living body has the ability to heal itself. Following illness, stress, injury or disease, the body is in a state of "imbalance", with vital energy pathways blocked, preventing it from functioning properly. Reflexology can be used to restore and maintain the body's natural equilibrium and encourage healing.

Funky! How do you become one? The Association of Reflexologists [AoR] offers membership for people who have either trained on AoR-accredited courses or taken additional training to reach accredited standards. Other organisations accept practitioners who have trained with specific schools as members.

Any entry requirements? None set except a minimum age of 18.

What about training? Basic reflexology courses at further education and higher education colleges are part-time and usually last at least nine months, including at least 60 hours teacher contact time. Classes can be daytime, evening and at weekends, and include home study and practice. While credit can be given for attendance, these courses may not be comprehensive enough to become registered as a member of the British Register of Complementary Practitioners or other professional registers.

Telephone 0208 735 0632

webTitle: Islington's plans to remain an education authority

fields.headline: Adults only
fields.standfirst: John Crace looks at Islington's plans to remain an education authority
fields.trailText: John Crace looks at Islington's plans to remain an education authority.
fields.body:
The DfEE's recent decision to put back the closing date for each local authority to submit its new adult learning plan from November 3 to December 8 will almost certainly have been greeted with stifled yawns in town halls across the country. Not only was the delay widely anticipated, but some authorities may not have had the resources to do much more than jot down a few ideas.

Despite the government's enthusiasm for lifelong learning, local education authorities still focus on primary and secondary education, and adult learning gets tacked on as an afterthought.

But there are some honourable exceptions, among them Islington. Only a cynic could suggest that the north London borough's renewed interest in post-16 education could have any thing to do with the fact that its primary and secondary statutory education services were taken out of its hands this April after a highly critical Ofsted report, and placed in the tender grip of the private firm Cambridge Education Associates (CEA), but even the cynic has to acknowledge penitent rehabilitation and give credit where credit is due.

Leisha Fullick, Islington council's chief executive, downplays the borough's loss of its educational services by saying, "We still regard education as our service; ultimately we approve CEA's budgets and educational plans" and is understandably keener to stress how seriously it is taking adult education and how much it fits in with their regeneration plans.

"The DfEE guidelines said that the adult learning plan should reflect the needs of the population," she says, "and we gave a lot of thought to how best we could do this. Calling a public meeting would only attract the same three men and a dog who turn up to complain at every public meeting, so we set out to find an innovative and interesting way of getting to the local community."

The answer it came up with, almost inevitably given that Islington was the birthplace to the New Labour focus group, was a giant focus group aka the Citizen's Conference. Questionnaires were sent out to 12,000 residents, picked to represent all age and social class groupings, of whom roughly 10% replied. These were whittled down to 125 who were offered £50 to attend the day's workshops. A few just turned up for the cash, but most proved remarkably enthusiastic and committed.

"We've come up with a comprehensive plan to improve and integrate our adult learning programmes," says Chris Jude, Islington's head of lifelong learning. "These range from the creation of both permanent and mobile information and resource centres to heighten public awareness, to mock workplace training, flexible courses for the self-employed and single parents, mentoring schemes, teen cafés and plenty more besides."

There's no doubting Islington's determination, but the key question is whether the borough will get the funds it needs. Contrary to its reputation, Islington is one of the country's poorest boroughs. When Tony and Cherie moved out the average local salary plummeted, and many residents get by on as little as £5,000 a year.

"We're not sure what we will get," says Jude. "All we've been definitely promised from the DfEE is the same amount as last year." As that was only the princely sum of £500,000, Islington has had to do some creative accounting. In all, Jude has applied to over 10 different bodies, ranging from the UK Online Fund to the European Social Fund, to maximise the cash for Islington's initiatives.

And, of course, there's always the hope of extracting more from the Learning and Skills Council. Which is not too much of a long shot; Leisha Fullick is the only local authority chief on the Learning and Skills Council and so Islington's bid should, at least, get a fair hearing.

webTitle: Further education funding council's final AGM

fields.headline: Dust to dust
fields.standfirst: Nick Tester pays his last respects to the further education funding council
fields.trailText: Nick Tester pays his last respects to the further education funding council.
fields.body:
Tricky occasions, funerals. Sometimes emotions boil over and heated words fly. "Crap" was the most common verdict from college principals as they listened to the new man in their lives - John Harwood. The chief executive of the Learning and Skills Council delivered his first speech at the final AGM of the Further Education Funding Council.

Reheating David Blunkett's vision for the future of further education and insisting the funding council's financial regime would remain in place for another year did not spare John Harwood the message that he faces an extremely rough ride as he attempts to create the Learning and Skills Council and its 47 local varieties.

It was probably an unfair reaction, since the man has barely got his feet under the desk, has just 25 staff so far on board and is still waiting instructions from Blunkett as to how his massive £6bn budget might be disposed of. But then college bosses are clinically cynical. It's what they do best and, often, they're right to be so. They turned up in Birmingham in their best grey suits to bid farewell to the Further Education Funding Council, dressed appropriately for the funeral, as chief inspector Jim Donaldson described the event.

They most definitely were not impressed by Harwood's talk of "marriages between important sectors that have achieved an enormous amount." The groans were audible when he added "we need to cement this relationship."

Donaldson's final annual report was greeted with sustained applause, not least because its findings show over 90% of teaching sessions scrutinised to be at least satisfactory or better - and that over 40% of the 112 colleges visited had one or more areas of teaching deemed outstanding.

The big news of the day - Chris Woodhead's resignation - had not reached the conference. But Donaldson must now be in the frame for the Ofsted top job.

Only one in six college principals has managed to survive the course since the funding council was established in 1993.

Tessa Blackstone's announcement that college heads must henceforth have the principals' qualification drew deep gasps.

Sceptical college leaders should perhaps learn how to enjoy the honeymoon.

webTitle: Rostrum:

fields.headline: Goodbye, FEFC
fields.standfirst: David Melville  sings a sweet swan song as the final curtain falls on a seven year act
fields.trailText: David Melville sings a sweet swan song as the final curtain falls on a seven year act.
fields.body:
I felt a sense of real occasion when I spoke last Thursday at the final AGM and principals' conference of the Further Education Funding Council. I say a sense of occasion and not sadness, because I believe the future holds exciting challenges - and this can never be a reason to be despondent. However I could not resist indulging in a little nostalgia on such a poignant moment in the history of further education.

The changes since incorporation have been so dramatic that I was tempted to begin with "in a galaxy far, far, away"! But there was a very serious undertone to my comments to delegates. And this was about just how much has been achieved since incorporation, and that the new Learning and Skills Council will not be able to deliver without the support of the colleges.

It still seems strange to think that it is only seven short years since some 464 colleges were brought together to form the further education sector in England. The diversity of those colleges was staggering. Some major cities had only one college providing a full range of further, and some higher education. Some colleges were highly specialised, and small. The sixth-form colleges had, until then, been schools. There was not much, if anything, they all had in common.

Just seven years later, one of the great achievements is that the sector has been able to find that common ground. It is a "sector". It now has an important, and respected, voice in the national education debate. It is recognised as being at the heart of lifelong learning and the social inclusion agenda.

The response of colleges to the challenges of the past seven years has been amazing. When exhorted to "grow" - they grew, "reduce costs" - they reduced costs, "compete" - they competed, "collaborate' - they collaborated, "improve quality" - they improved quality. But colleges have not just responded to the ever-changing demands of government. They have developed many innovative approaches to the delivery of education and training. Colleges have played a leading part in the use of information technology in teaching and learning, and in the use of value-added assessment of performance.

Student numbers have grown dramatically since 1993-94, increasing by 33%. This means that 860,000 more lives are now changed by further education. This remarkable expansion has been carried out whilst unit costs have plummeted. Student retention rates have remained constant and their pass rates have made steady year-on-year improvements.

But the further education sector is not about finance and crude numbers. If these post-incorporation years are to be remembered for anything, it will be about the sector's response to two seminal reports - both of which stand alongside those other great reports such as Plowden and Robbins in that they have changed the face of education. They are of course the reports Inclusive Learning and Learning Works - better known as Tomlinson and Kennedy.

Colleges know all about widening participation, about the value of education and training, about expansion, about probity and the difference between public and private funds, about improving quality and about responding to their communities. The Learning and Skills Council cannot succeed without them. Its successes will indeed be their successes.

The semantic change from Further Education Funding Council to Learning and Skills Council is both symbolic and significant. Education and funding to learning and skills. In our concern about the inadequacies of our skills base, we will not succeed if we lose sight of the majority role of learning and education in colleges.

webTitle: Is the Workers' Educational Association relevant?

fields.headline: Extinct? No way
fields.standfirst: Now we're all entering the learning and skills age, is there still a role for the Workers' Educational Association, asks Simon Midgley
fields.trailText: Now we're all entering the learning and skills age, is there still a role for the Workers' Educational Association, asks Simon Midgley.
fields.body:
Robert Lochrie bristles slightly at the suggestion that the organisation he heads up is a dinosaur. But isn't it a pardonable image? How does the ideal of introducing the workers to the beauties of art, music and literature - all still among its most popular programmes - and teaching them for their own sake, square with whatever is meant by lifelong learning?

And what of the nobility of the task of opening the minds of manual labourers to the glories of philosophy and the metaphysical rewards for their teachers of this cross-class intercourse? One of the WEA's earliest and most distinguished tutors, the historian R H Tawney, said that: "The friendly smiting of weavers, potters, miners and engineers have taught me much about the problems of political and economic science which cannot be learned from books."

Two out of the three words in the title are mildewed, to say the least. Workers is hardly New Labour, and we've all got to learn to call education "learning and skills". But the WEA's general secretary is not having the Jurassic tag: "It would be a funny old dinosaur that is not only growing each year, but consistently over-achieves the targets given to it by the Further Education Funding Council and is more successful than ever in attracting funds from the National Lotteries Board, the European Union and the Department for International Development."

Haunted by its illustrious past, however, the WEA, a voluntary movement and charitable organisation, continues to wrestle with the question of precisely what role it should play in today's lifelong learning society. In this age of quantification and targets, can its courses simply be regarded as intrinsically valuable or should they have measurable outcomes?

Founded by Albert Mansbridge in 1903, the Association was created as an alliance between labour (working men) and learning (the universities). Its ideological roots are shared with a clutch of 19th-century initiatives, such as the mechanics institutes, the co-operative movement and popular public lectures on science, designed to slake the working classes' thirst for knowledge from which they felt excluded by the class system.

At that time there were more than 800 local WEA branches. Richard Crossman was a vice-president for three years, Rab Butler for 12 and Hugh Gaitskell for 10.

Today the WEA is divided into four organisations - two associations in Wales, one in Northern Ireland and one covering both England and Scotland. Mr Lochrie, general secretary of the English and Scottish WEA which has some 600 local branches, says there is still a very real job to be done.

"A very, very significant proportion of the population does not engage in lifelong learning in a structured way," he said. "Our very particular job is to bring those people in, in partnership with the unions." He adds that the association has moved some way from providing learning for its own sake towards evaluating the benefits of its courses. A learning outcomes strategy now helps to measure the extent to which educational goals are being met.

The WEA's work consists of three main strands. A general education programme is delivered through local branches and tutors. This involves a wide variety of provision ranging from classes in dowsing in Cornwall and west Devon, Egyptology in Blackburn, creative writing in Bury, philosophy in Cheshire to ICT courses in the east Midlands.

The second major area of work is community learning aimed at specific groups of people with particular needs. This can involve working with the blind and others with special needs, helping to deliver return-to-learning programmes, basic skills programmes and English courses for speakers of other languages.

In the London district a community-based creative writing project is targeted at the homeless, refugees and asylum seekers. In Yorkshire the WEA is helping economically beleaguered hill farmers find more efficient ways of running their businesses, often using computers.

The WEA's final strand of work is its workplace learning programme where students are recruited in the workplace, via the trade unions. Such programmes are flourishing especially in Cheshire, Merseyside, west Lancashire and Scotland. The WEA works alongside unions such as Unison, the General, Municipal, and Boilermakers and others to provide programmes in communication skills, IT and literacy and numeracy initiatives.

As a proportion of its total work the WEA's liberal education programme is falling, while work-based and community-based provision is growing. In 1998/9 it ran more than 9,000 courses. These are typically part-time and comprise 10 or 12 weekly classes, lasting two or three hours. The largest programme areas are in art, crafts, music, history, archaeology, philosophy, religion, personal development, literature, languages and communications. There are 5,000 part-time tutors in England and Scotland.

Funded by the Further Education Funding Council as if it were a further education college, the WEA receives £12m a year for its vocational and non-vocational work. A Further Education Funding Council inspection report, based on an inspection conducted in March last year, praised most of its teaching for being of good quality and some of it for being outstanding.

However, it added that provision for students with learning difficulties and/or disabilities was poor. There were also criticisms of the WEA's arrangements for assessing students' learning and of its financial planning and management. Mr Lochrie said: "What we now do is target individuals and groups in a much more systematic way than ever before.

"Our student numbers are growing, but not within the traditional structures of the association, ie the local branches, or in general liberal education. Most of the work that is bringing in new students is outside the traditional programme - in the workplace and in communities." The WEA, he added, takes a very broad view of what lifelong learning is and of the many pathways that people can travel to get back into education and work.

"We ought to be bringing into lifelong learning those people who have not participated, who are educationally disadvantaged and who left school at the earliest possible age," he said.

The report says that the WEA's knowledgeable and committed voluntary members are one of its major strengths. It also praises the WEA's "clear mission, values and strategic objectives" leading to "successful widening of participation and significant contributions to lifelong learning." Ah, perhaps not quite such a dinosaur after all.

webTitle: Food parcels scheme for students

fields.headline: Loaves and loo rolls
fields.standfirst: Average students spend 22% of their food budget on drink and socialising. Jerome Monahan on how one retailer is helping parents feed them from a distance
fields.trailText: Average students spend 22% of their food budget on drink and socialising. Jerome Monahan on how one retailer is helping parents feed them from a distance.
fields.body:
POWs, refugees and front line troops awaiting parachute drops come to mind when you hear talk of food parcels? Well, think again. Beleaguered students have now joined the ranks of those deserving emergency food aid.

Late October is when the realities of living away from home start to break through the euphoria of fresherdom. With wide-eyed shock, students across the land, outside the safety net of catered accommodation, are coming to the chilling realisation that cupboards and fridges do not spontaneously fill themselves.

So, it is with impeccably good timing that food retailer Iceland has launched the Save Our Students (SOS) Survival Pack - a scheme enabling parents to shop at a distance for their provision-challenged offspring.

The idea belongs to Ben Dutton, a 21-year-old student of Spanish and public relations at Leeds Metropolitan University. It was while on secondment with Iceland that he dreamed up the idea. He suggested the company should adapt their homeshopping facility to create a standard set of student supplies. These could then be ordered and paid for from a parent's address and delivered to their son's and daughter's digs. Ben's colleagues were so taken with the notion that they gave him a budget and suggested he did some research.

A thousand students at four universities - Loughborough, Leeds, Bristol and Brighton - were quizzed about their shopping and eating habits and what emerged would chill any parent's heart. "Seven in 10 were receiving contributions from home towards their food, but 45% of the students we questioned were skipping meals," said Ben. "This figure climbed to 78% when it came to breakfast."

The survey revealed that many students were going hungry and resorting to bizarre food combinations as their supplies dwindled. Among the most unappetising concoctions were Weetabix with peanut butter and sugar sandwiches. Even more worrying was the amount students claimed they diverted from their grocery allowance for drink - 22 per cent of a weekly average outlay of £29.82.

Ben feels these curious priorities make total sense in the context of university life: "A major part of being at uni, especially at the start, is about getting out and meeting people. Something has got to give and that something is often healthy food. The Iceland scheme is not promoting laziness."

His view is supported by recipient of an SOS parcel, Liverpool student Gemma Davies: "Students have to spend a lot of their money socialising. Anyone making food their priority and staying in all the time to eat it would quickly fall apart - it can be very lonely going away to study."

The Iceland SOS initiative resolves these problems by bringing one of two standard supplies - meat or vegetarian - right to the door. "For £40, parents can send two weeks' worth of groceries," explains Ben. "And all the student needs to do is be there during a pre-arranged two-hour slot to receive the goodies."

The food parcels do not contain much that requires refrigerator space. And as well as various staples, there is room for chocolate biscuits and loo rolls. The venture - presumably designed to persuade students that Iceland is a hip, happening company and to educate everyone that their range extends beyond frozen cheesecake - is being well received.

"It's a wonderful idea," said consultant nutritionist Azmina Govindji. "The worse thing is that students are missing meals - above all else they should be eating regularly. My one concern is that these set grocery lists might contain an unnecessary amount of salt."

Beth Blackie, Gemma's mother, was full of praise: "It's a great relief - you send them off with a full box of food, but you cannot be visiting them regularly to rummage in their cupboards."

Unsurprisingly, the SOS idea gets its highest approval rating among students. "It's needed; people here are always skimping on food - there is so much else going on," says Durham law student Stephen Beattie.

"It can be nightmarish, particularly in the first year when you are having to juggle so many new demands all at the same time."

Toni Dicks, a student union representative at Northampton University, said: "This is brilliant - I hate supermarkets."

Of course, getting a food pack is one thing, actually cooking it is another. Simple meal suggestions are included with each delivery, but the scheme is up against a lot when it comes to students' culinary blindspots. "Many arrive at university with little or no experience of feeding themselves," says Leicester senior student welfare officer Clare Taylor.

Her view is reflected in the tales of woe most students can report about disastrous attempts to prepare food. Durham English Student Emma Taylor tells of a flatmate resorting to a mallet in an effort to detach portions of mince from a large frozen economy block: "The whole house was shaking. He never did manage to chip a piece off and the whole thing went in the bin."

There is also no guarantee that students will spend the money saved on fruit and vegetables - still a rarity, according to the most recent Health Education Monitoring Survey, in the diets of over 50% of young men and 40% of young women.

Such carping aside, there is no doubt getting a food parcel is a source of many pleasures to students: "I spent four hours tantalising the girls I live with - unpacking and re-packing my box," said Gemma. "And since it came, I have never been so popular."

But, meanwhile, things are tight for Ben Dutton. He is back at college and his grant has been delayed. "My food supplies have really run short this week, but my mum and dad are on holiday."

A public service broadcast is needed: "Will the parents of Ben Dutton currently travelling in America please arrange an urgent delivery of a food parcel - your son is seriously contemplating a sugar sandwich."

 For full details of the Save Our Student Scheme contact the order line on 0870 242 2242.

webTitle: New era for life sciences

fields.headline: Dawn of a new era
fields.standfirst: Commercial potential has helped boost grants for life sciences, says Lee Elliot Major
fields.trailText: Commercial potential has helped boost grants for life sciences, says Lee Elliot Major.
fields.body:
Genetically modified foods, untrustworthy biotech companies and the spectre of designer babies may have tarnished its social image, but life sciences is now one of the fastest-growing university disciplines.

As closures and rationalisation plans dog departments in the physical sciences, biosciences are experiencing unprecedented growth, according to the main government funding agency for the subject.

"The explosion of knowledge and opportunities in the biosciences has brought a significant shift in university employment, with a 20% growth in life science departments over the past five years, contrasting with declining numbers in physical sciences," the Biotechnology and Biological Sciences Research Council reports.

The main concern for the council's senior officials is to meet the increasing demands for research funds from universities' flourishing life sciences communities. There are fears that competition for research grants will be so intense that success rates for applications will plummet.

Research fields are in a constant state of flux, as developments open up uncharted frontiers while activity in already extensively mapped areas fades. The nineteenth century is known, for example, as the golden era of chemistry. Physics, meanwhile, prospered during the first half of the twentieth century. Biology has been in the ascendant for the last 50 years - since Crick and Watson discovered the structure of DNA.

The current expansion of life sciences in universities, though, signals the emergence of a hybrid breed of multidisciplinary researchers, defying these broad scientific classifications. While the research focuses on living organisms, it depends on a blend of expertise from physical, chemical and computing sciences.

This is the era of the "post-genomic scientists" - researchers trying to make sense of the mountains of data being created by the human genome project. For many, the ultimate goal is to use this rich source of information to improve medical treatment beyond our wildest dreams.

But it is money driving the growth of academic disciplines. In an attempt to exploit the academic and commercial opportunities presented by the decoding of the human genome, the government has overseen an unprecedented shift in research funding priorities over the last three years. Increases in the science budget have focused largely on post-genomic science: structural biology; bioinformatics; and functional genomics.

The main beneficiaries among government research agencies have been the BBSRC and the Medical Research Council. Although even the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council now has its own life sciences programme. For its part, the BBSRC is funding six new functional genomics centres, dealing with key organisms for which the genomic sequences are known, and six complementary structural biology centres, to provide molecular information on the function of genes.

But perhaps the most important development has been the financial impact on universities of the Wellcome Trust, the world's largest biomedical research charity. From PhD stipends to grants for large Wellcome research units, the money injected by the charity during the last decade has been a key element in the growth of biomedicine in the UK. The Trust now channels about £400m a year into universities.

The government is also keen that this new breed of academics becomes more entrepreneurial and works closely with the UK's biotechnology and pharmaceutical industries.

If all this attention were not enough, following the last spending review the government, convinced that the Glaxo Wellcomes of the future will emerge from these strong academic-industry links, is this month expected to announce another funding boost for the life sciences.

webTitle: Transforming life for agency teachers

fields.headline: Sex equality appeal
fields.standfirst: Peter Kingston  reports on a case which could transform life for agency teachers
fields.trailText: Peter Kingston reports on a case which could transform life for agency teachers.
fields.body:
The government is exploring ways it can stop agencies denying employment rights to staff on their books.

But the Department for Education and Employment is today opposing a high-court claim by an agency lecturer for equal pay and pension rights.

Malcolm Wicks, the lifelong learning minister, has told the lecturers' union, Natfhe, he is "very disturbed" about how some agencies treat staff.

If necessary, he says, the government can use powers in last year's Employment Relations Act to make sure agencies fulfil individuals' rights.

Natfhe and the Equal Opportunities Commission are jointly backing a claim by Debra Allonby in the court of appeal against Accrington and Rossendale college, the agency, Education Lecturing Services, and the DfEE for the same pay and pension rights as full-time male lecturers at the college doing comparable work.

The union's lawyers hope that legal decisions that have been taken since Allonby's unsuccessful battle through the employment tribunal system will persuade the appeal court to refer her case to the European Court of Justice.

Union hopes were boosted during the summer by ministerial hints that government would not tolerate inequitable treatment of staff.

"We believe that workers deserve fair treatment regardless of whether they are recruited direct or work through an intermediary such as an employment agency," Malcolm Wicks wrote in a letter to the union.

"With regard to employment rights generally for those falling outside the protections that normally apply, you may be interested to learn that Section 23 of the Employment Relations Act 1999 contains a provision which would allow us, by order, to confer rights on individuals not currently covered."

The status of agency workers and how it will use this Section 23 power are currently being considered by the Department of Trade and Industry, a DfEE spokesman confirmed.

Wicks adds: "I have been very disturbed by the treatment of staff by some employment agencies and I have asked my officials to work closely with the DTI to ensure that all further education lecturers receive their appropriate employment rights."

Natfhe's lawyers will argue in court today that Allonby deserves the employment rights of male colleagues directly employed by the college and performing a comparable job.

In 1996, Allonby was a part-time information technology lecturer at Accrington and Rossendale college. To make cash savings, the college engaged an agency, Education Lecturing Services (ELS) to provide its part-time hourly paid staff.

Allonby was re-employed via ELS to work at her college for what Natfhe says was less pay and no entitlement to sick pay or similar benefits.

An employment appeals tribunal two years ago confirmed that she had been unfairly dismissed. But she was not entitled to equal pay because there was no one she could compare herself to. Similarly she was barred from access to the teachers' pension scheme because, the tribunal ruled, she couldn't compare herself with lecturers employed in colleges who have entry rights.

Accrington and Rossendale principal Mike Austin said: "We're not surprised at the appeal because Natfhe feels very strongly about it, but on both previous occasions tribunals found on our behalf."

A DfEE spokesman said: "It's right that the court of appeal considers Mrs Allonby's case and the very important issues which it raises."

In 1996, Allonby was a part-time information technology lecturer at Accrington and Rossendale college. To make cash savings, the college engaged an agency, Education Lecturing Services (ELS) to provide its part-time hourly paid staff. Allonby was re-employed via ELS to work at her college for what Natfhe says was less pay and no entitlement to sick pay or similar benefits. An employment appeals tribunal two years ago confirmed that she had been unfairly dismissed. But she was not entitled to equal pay because there was no one she could compare herself to. Similarly she was barred from access to the teachers' pension scheme because, the tribunal ruled, she couldn't compare herself with lecturers employed in colleges who have entry rights. Accrington and Rossendale principal Mike Austin said: "We're not surprised at the appeal because Natfhe feels very strongly about it, but on both previous occasions tribunals found on our behalf." A DfEE spokesman said: "It's right that the court of appeal considers Mrs Allonby's case and the very important issues which it raises."

webTitle: New ways to fund universities

fields.headline: Only study what you've paid for
fields.standfirst: One way of increasing funds would be to charge for courses according to their market value, says Sir Colin Campbell
fields.trailText: One way of increasing funds would be to charge for courses according to their market value, says Sir Colin Campbell.
fields.body:
Hardly anyone disagrees that there is an urgent need to change the way UK universities are funded. How could they when faced with the facts?

Public funding per student has fallen by 50% since 1980. Universities have responded by increasing productivity - we not only teach more students, but have also increased our market share of international students and raised the status of the UK science base. Nonetheless, the adverse effects of two decades of declining public funding are plain:

 Academic salaries are low, compared with non-academic jobs and with salaries of academic staff overseas. Recruitment and retention of high quality staff is difficult and getting harder; even if they are attracted into academia, many of the most talented are easily tempted overseas.

 Student: staff ratios have increased and average class sizes have doubled.

 Notwithstanding the recent funding pulses via the Joint Infrastructure Fund, there has been a serious lack of capital investment over the last 20 years, especially when compared to international competitors. In 1995, the UK spent 0.7% of GDP on higher education. The OECD average was 1.5%. The US invested 2%. To increase UK expenditure to the OECD average would require additional public funding of £5 bn a year. Neither government nor taxpayer are likely to make this a priority. After all, £5bn a year could buy around 200,000 more teachers or 240,000 more nurses.

No change in the status quo will also mean no funds for all-important new initiatives, such as e-learning and biotechnology developments. We will lag behind our international counterparts in these innovative and exciting areas. And if the reputation of UK higher education that attracts 200,000 international students to the UK each year is compromised we will quickly lose ground.

The present system already falls short on other counts:

 Although student numbers have more than doubled, universities are almost as socially exclusive today as they were 20 years ago. Just 10% of 18-year-olds from unskilled and partly skilled backgrounds enter higher education. For 18-year-olds from senior managerial and professional backgrounds, this figure is 80%.

 The current system is incredibly inefficient. Government control over use of public funds grows ever more intrusive. This is both expensive and slows down the speed at which the system can respond to new initiatives (e-learning and biotechnology again). So a new system must not only increase funding available to universities from non-government sources, but should also reduce social exclusion and wasteful regulation and enable higher education to be more market sensitive and compete internationally.

What is the answer? Several options are debated in the report, Funding Universities to Meet National and International Challenges, by Professor David Greenaway and Dr Michelle Haynes (www.nottingham.ac.uk/economics/funding).

But the only realistic option is to ask beneficiaries of higher education to pay more to provide it, although public money must remain a central part of the funding. Any decent state will invest in its youth. And the benefits to graduates themselves are huge. They are more likely to be employed than non-graduates, and they will earn more - on average £400,000 more than non-graduates over their working life.

Enabling different universities to charge different fees for different courses, according to market demand and cost, would draw extra funding into the system. Even if the government set an upper limit on fees, the extra funding would be substantial. With, say, a fee cap of £4,000, more than £3bn extra would be generated each year. And the Greenaway/Haynes report suggests all universities, not just the old ones, would benefit.

If students were able to contribute more by drawing on future earnings through risk-free loans to be repaid only when they could afford to, it would ensure extra income at no public cost. That is, providing the finance up front would also ensure no one was denied access because of cost. Another benefit of additional income is that universities could then start building up scholarship funds to broaden access further.

Of course, these proposals need further development to ensure we increase funding and broaden access. But we cannot sit on our hands indefinitely. The competition is getting stronger all the time.

 Sir Colin Campbell is vice-chancellor of Nottingham University.

webTitle: Pupils are clamouring to join a Sussex school's support scheme for first years

fields.headline: We're here to help you
fields.standfirst: Pupils are clamouring to join a Sussex school's support scheme for first years
fields.trailText: Pupils are clamouring to join a Sussex school's support scheme for first years.
fields.body:
Alex Osborne suspects people don't really understand his role. Alex Crouch agrees people don't appreciate how much work is involved - there are duty rotas to organise, for a start. Jo Cornes explains that it can be difficult to tell your peers they're not doing their job properly, while Ellie Murphy points out the skills needed to motivate others.

Alex, Jo, Alex and Ellie are year 10 pupils at Ringmer Community college in Sussex and manage 36 students in their year group as part of the senior partner scheme. They ensure the scheme is running smoothly and achieving its aim of helping year 7s settle in. This is done by visiting year 7 forms and being available to talk about their problems or worries.

All year 9 pupils can apply to be come a senior partner, but acceptance is not automatic. Indeed, the scheme has become so successful that more pupils now apply than there are places available. As Julie Warren, assistant principal explains: "They have to complete an application form, telling us why they would like to become a senior partner. Parents sign the form and myself and the head of year interview applicants and appoint." There is debriefing for those who have been unsuccessful.

Warren stresses that the senior partners are not simply the "star pupils". She says: "We're looking for reliability, empathy, sensitivity and self-confidence. Not every pupil can approach a year 7 and initiate a conversation to see if everything is okay."

Senior partners attend training with the college counsellor, covering lis tening and negotiating skills, guidance on when to pass matters on and issues surrounding confidentiality. The four partner managers found this invaluable preparation.

Ringmer has 48 feeder schools, and senior partners help all new pupils, particularly those who arrive not knowing anyone. Katherine Rattle says: "I was the only one to come here from my old school, and so everyone was a stranger." It is testament to the scheme's success that Katherine, Alex Wilson, Rikki Newman and Jessica Woolard all feel the senior partners are first and foremost friends. As Alex Crouch says: "It's the main part of the job."

The fears and worries that Rikki, Alex, Jessica and Katherine express about starting at secondary school are familiar ones: "Getting lost, not being able to do my homework, missing the school bus. "It's better to go to the senior partners than teachers", Katherine asserts, "because they know how it really feels."

The school's year 10s were the first group to have their own senior partners. Then there were only four partners, and all agree that the scheme is better now. On a personal level, the year 10s probably gain more from the experience than the year 7s, thinks Alex Osborne.

Ellie says: "I thought it would be a useful thing to do, especially as we went through the process ourselves. I can see now just how helpful it is." Jo sees other benefits too: "I spoke to parents at the Open Evening, and they were glad to know that we're here."

More girls than boys have applied in the past, but this is changing, partly due to last year's partner managers being awarded the Diana, Princess of Wales Memorial Award for Young People.

Principal, Stephen Johnson, gives the scheme a high profile too, recognising that the project's success relies upon the pupils themselves acknowledging its worth - if only as a chance to get your name in the paper!

For Warren, one of the scheme's most rewarding aspects is that it encourages year 7s to want to be senior partners themselves. Katherine, for one, wants "to help little people. Well, they'll seem really little by then, won't they?"

webTitle: Asian women and university

fields.headline: Stuff of dreams
fields.standfirst: Asian women can still face an uphill battle getting to university. It's nothing to do with grades and everything to do with sex, they tell Abu Taher
fields.trailText: Asian women can still face an uphill battle getting to university. It's nothing to do with grades and everything to do with sex, they tell Abu Taher.
fields.body:
Zhanara Begum
Second-year student at Cambridge University studying English literature

Zhanara is the model of a successful student. Bright, from a working-class background in the West Midlands, she passed her A-levels with flying colours and got a place at Cambridge.

Educated in a state school in Walsall, West Midlands, a Cambridge education is a dream come true for Zhanara.

"Cambridge is absolutely great. It has broadened my horizons both intellectually and socially," she says. "I've been able to learn things I wouldn't otherwise have been able to. I am having a great time."

A hard-working 19-year-old, she is a prominent member of her department - both academically and in extra-curricular activities.

An ardent fan of Shakespeare, she has already travelled around Europe with a Cambridge student theatre group performing the role of Paulina in The Winter's Tale.

But life has not always been so good. Getting to Cambridge was an arduous struggle for Zhanara which had nothing to do with her academic ability nor the much-hyped elitism of Oxbridge. Like many female students of Asian background, she was almost prevented from going to university by her family, who were afraid that she might be "led astray".

"My family were afraid that I may stray from Islam. I would be going out with guys and be drinking etc, etc. This is why they discouraged me from coming to university," she says.

Zhanara's parents were adamant about her not going to university, even though it was vital if she was to fulfil her ambitions of becoming a diplomat for organisations like the EU or Nato. Both strict Muslims, they were happy for her to complete her A-levels and then stay at home until they found a suitable husband.

But there was a huge difference in the treatment of Zhanara's three brothers compared to herself and her three sisters. Her elder brothers were allowed to go to university and all are pursuing successful careers.

Although it is a case of double standards, she says her parents' fears were understandable as in Asian households the reputation of a family rests on a daughter's "decency".

With a passion for literature from early childhood, Zhanara struggled to persuade her parents to let her read English at Cambridge. In the end, her elder sisters stepped in to persuade her parents to let her go. She believes she was lucky - her sisters' persuasion and the prestige of Cambridge helped convince her parents to comply.

"Also, my parents trust me. I am quite religious, and they know I won't get up to anything un-Islamic."

She believes it is this religious conviction that won her parents' consent more than anything else. They trusted her strong faith which they believed would keep her away from the "immoral" excesses of university life.

At university she prays five times a day. All her friends at Newnham College are aware of her religious commitment and respect her for it. She even went to the May ball wearing her hijab (veil).

Although Zhanara managed to continue into higher education, her three elder sisters, like countless other Asian girls, did not. Despite achieving better A-level results than Zhanara (two As and a B), they were discouraged from going further.

In fact, it was the elder sisters' bitterness at not going to university that was the chief catalyst in ensuring that Zhanara succeeded.

Although Zhanara's parents give her full support now, they say their anxieties are something that every Asian, or at least Muslim, parent feels. Her mother Sufia, a housewife, says: "We are Muslims and want to live like Muslims. I don't want my daughters to move away from the traditional lifestyle.

"At university, students are exposed to alcohol, drugs and sex all the time. We didn't want our daughter ruined by such a lifestyle." Her worst fear is that of "free love relationships".

In fact, she still hopes her daughter will settle down to an arranged marriage straight after her studies. She is not so keen on her pursuing a career after university. "We don't expect our daughter to feed us. She should get married first, and then she can do whatever she likes."

Herpreet Kaur
Second-year student at Brunel University studying multi-media

Herpreet, 19, from Ilford, Essex, has to make the tortuous journey from the edge of east London to Brunel University on the other side of the capital every day. Like many Asian female students, she is forced by her family to live at home and commute to campus.

"It's frustrating. It takes me at least an hour to get to campus, but there's no other way," she says.

Although her parents wanted her to go to university, they insisted it must be near home. Brunel wasn't her first choice, but she had to compromise. Her parents, who own a small retail business, were even willing to buy her a car so she could commute more easily.

Her parents' fears are similar to Zhanara's. They just want their daughter to have an education, and not get involved in the university lifestyle. "They want me at home so they can keep tabs on me. They don't like the idea of me drinking and mingling with boys," she says.

Herpreet says she loves her parents too much to upset them. "They genuinely care for my education, and they think that being at home I'll study better," she says.

Herpreet's parents are especially cautious because they have seen too many cases among their friends and relatives where the daughters have gone to university and started smoking, drinking and going out with boys.

But the over-protectiveness does not always work, as often "what Asian girls tend to do is lead a double-life. They behave very restrained at home, but act totally wild at uni," Herpreet says.

"I know a lot of Asian girls who go to uni just to have a good time, because they know these are the only few free years they'll ever get. After that they'll have to get married."

Although restricting girls from going to university is very common in the Asian community, to date there have been no investigations in this area.

Bodies like the NUS and UCAS are unaware that the issue exists, and have no staff or resources to deal with it. One surprised NUS spokeswoman said: "I didn't realise this was a problem."

Indeed, most organisations believe the contrary - that more and more Asian girls are entering higher education. And UCAS statistics prove it.

"The number of UK female students from Bangladeshi, Indian and Pakistani backgrounds applying to university has been steadily increasing over the past five years, generally at a rate faster than the total female population of higher education students," says Anthony MaClaran, deputy chief executive of UCAS.

But the percentage of Asian females applying to university is lower than that of males. For instance, last year only 947 female students with a Bangladeshi background entered university, compared to 1,102 males from the same background.

Figures for Pakistani and Indian students show similar discrepancies, which contradict the national trend in the gender balance of university applicants, where more females are applying than males.

Dr Zaki Badawi, principal of the Muslim College of Britain in London, says this is bad news for the Asian community. "Educated women are a valuable asset to society. They are essential for the family as well as the rest of society."

He acknowledges that Asian parents do stop their daughters from going to university. He says it is harmful, as it prolongs the oppression of women.

"There's prejudice against women learning in the Asian community. It is a form of male domination," he says.

"Often the fears of daughters going astray or becoming corrupted by all sorts of influences is an excuse to hide that prejudice," he adds.

Dr Badawi, who has taught Islamic studies around the world, admits that Asian parents are right in fearing the "moral decadence" on campuses, but says they must trust their daughters.

"All societies have decadence. But it is up to the individual to stay away from it."

webTitle: Does class size matter?

fields.headline: Shrink to fit
fields.standfirst: When the government began its drive to cut class sizes, all the research indicated that size didn't matter.  Phil Revell reports on the latest findings
fields.trailText: When the government began its drive to cut class sizes, all the research indicated that size didn't matter. Phil Revell reports on the latest findings.
fields.body:
One and a half cheers for the government, which announced last week that its election pledge on class sizes will be met ahead of schedule. In 1997 Labour committed itself to reducing infant class sizes to a maximum of 30 by 2002. Since then, said Education Secretary David Blunkett, class sizes have indeed been shrinking: "The number of children in classes above that level fell from a peak of 485,000 in January 1998, through 177,000 in January 2000, to stand at 30,000 at the beginning of September."

Responding to critics who claim that the problem has merely shifted further up the school, he announced a £73m drive to cut class sizes for 8- to 11-year-olds.

"This is a priority for parents," said Doug McAvoy, general secretary of the National Union of Teachers. "They know that high class sizes mean less individual attention for their children." McAvoy's opinion is confirmed by studies of the factors influencing parents who choose a private education for their children.

"It is one of the top three factors in the decision," said a spokesman at the Independent Schools Information Service, which carried out the research. In prep schools class sizes are around 15 or 16, half the government's target figure.

The issue of class size is so obvious to most parents and teachers that it is amazing that there should ever have been any debate. But academic research into class size has been confused and contradictory.

"Every teacher I've ever spoken to in the whole world would argue that a smaller class allows them to do a better job," says Dr Peter Blatchford at London's Institute of Education. "But the research evidence was so puzzling as to be bizarre. Studies seemed to show that children in larger classes were doing better."

Research into class size in the 50s and 60s did indeed appear to indicate that large classes were best, and an Ofsted report in 1998 argued that class size was not a factor in educational attainment. Chris Woodhead endeared himself to the profession again by arguing that it was the "quality of the teaching" that was critical.

In America, the Star project in Tennessee found that children in small classes did better in reading and maths, but the research made no attempt to identify just why it was that small classes made a difference. Various states have introduced class size reduction initiatives, at huge expense, but there are academics and policy makers who think that this is money wasted.

Not Peter Blatchford. He is directing the Class Size Research Project looking at the experience of over 10,000 very young children in schools across the UK. Blatchford dismisses the Ofsted claim and argues that earlier studies were based on poorly designed research.

The first clear results from the project will be published next year. "The message we are getting is very clear," he says. "Children in smaller classes are making more progress in literacy and maths."

It's particularly important for the weakest attainers (bottom 25%). "They are the children who made the most progress in smaller classes."

But the researchers also found differences in the classroom interaction. "Children in smaller classes initiate more, and there's less time off task. Children in larger classes are more distracted and less engaged."

Teachers at Holyhead Primary School in the West Midlands know what Blatchford means. The school serves a challenging area of Sandwell, near Birmingham, and a failed Ofsted inspection resulted in a very small intake of children three years ago. Year 3 at the school still has just 16 children.

"You can see the difference," says headteacher Hilary Bills. "The teacher who has the small class has a fantastic year."

"There's a huge difference," says Year 3's teacher Simmone Edge. "I heard the entire class read yesterday, I couldn't have done that with a class of 36."

Her colleague Paul Smith has one of the larger groups. "There's no room to move around in the class," he says. "With so many children it's very difficult to have a quiet classroom. You haven't got the time during the day to go around the class on an individual basis - so they don't get the attention. If they are struggling I don't always see that as quickly as I would in a smaller class."

And the differences aren't just academic. "Teachers of very young children have an emotional involvement in seeing children develop," says Blatchford. "The information we're getting is almost a cry from the heart. Teachers are saying: 'It's very difficult to do the job that I want to do when I've got 30-plus children'."

Paul Smith is familiar with that sense of frustration. He entered the profession because he wanted to make a difference to children's lives, but in a large class he doesn't feel he is achieving what he could - and the workload is eroding his commitment to his chosen career.

"For my first two years in the job I was perfectly happy," he says. "But during these last two, with the larger classes, I'd have to be honest and say that there have been times when I've asked myself 'Do I want to do this?' You have no real life in term-time, you spend most of your time trying to get ahead of the work."

A recent report by Teacherline, the independent counselling helpline for teachers, reported that nearly half the country's teachers were suffering from stress, with overwork one of the most common complaints.

"You're sitting there until eleven o'clock at night marking maths books," says Hilary Bills. "You get to the number 25 and you still have 10 more to go - it's a killer."

And the problem isn't confined to teachers. Interviews by a team from a leading psychotherapy institute found "worryingly high" levels of stress in children. More than a quarter of those questioned said they were often or always stressed. Children said many problems were caused by school.

"We were surprised by the extent of the problem, particularly by the amount of stress reported by very young people," said Professor Stephen Palmer, from City University, London, who led the study.

Stress for children in school can arise from bullying, poor performance, poor relationships with the teacher - all the things which teachers claim are more easily dealt with in smaller classes.

"One of the boys in our small class is on the autistic spectrum," says Hilary Bills. "We've maintained him in mainstream, which is what his mother wants, because he's had the extra attention of a small class. In a larger group he would have been in special school by now."

In a large class the child who loses out the most is often the quiet, seemingly average child, whose progress is apparently no cause for concern. "It's very easy to overlook the quiet child," says Simmone Edge. "High flyers get attention, you're very aware of children with special needs and, of course, loud noisy boys - but it's the quiet ones who lose out in a large class."

Blatchford's research clearly supports the government's decision to begin the reduction of class sizes with the youngest children. He is less sure about the benefits of smaller classes for older pupils. "The literature suggests that the biggest effects are with the youngest children," he says. But Tony Cooper would disagree.

Cooper won a teachers' Oscar last month. He's head of Aldercar school near Nottingham where he has achieved phenomenal results. The past five years have seen a 231% increase in higher grades at GCSE. One of the first things Cooper did on becoming head was to reduce class sizes.

"There are many reasons why I thought it would work," he says. "The individual attention that children get in the classroom, relationships between the teacher and 18 to 25 pupils, as opposed to 28 to 37. They get to know each other and they work together much better."

But keeping classes down to 18-25 in a secondary school is expensive. Aldercar's buildings look tired and shabby. "We could have made our buildings more attractive," Cooper says. "But for £20,000, which might have painted one exterior block of my school, I get another teacher."

And Cooper is another voice arguing that class size has an effect beyond Sats scores and GCSE results. He strongly believes that smaller classes produce better relationships and less stress for his teachers.

"People do have stressful times, but in five years I've had just one member of staff off with long-term stress."

His gut feelings are supported by a study into class size by the National Foundation for Educational Research which argued that the morale, motivation and self-esteem of teachers was affected by class size and that larger classes combined with classroom overcrowding had negative effects on children's behaviour.

In short, class size is indeed the issue for schools. Real government action to reduce numbers to well below 30 would impact on a whole series of headline-inducing concerns, from teacher stress through to bullying and childhood mental health - something parents have known instinctively all along.

"If you went to a supermarket which checkout would you go to?" asks Hilary Bills. "The short queue or the long wait for a harassed checkout operator? It's exactly the same with a school."

webTitle: Comment: Ros Coward on the fuel protests

fields.headline: The feel bad factor
fields.standfirst:
The public's intimate relationship with their car as a 'second skin' is what drives their irrational fuel protests

Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: The public's intimate relationship with their car as a 'second skin' is what drives their irrational fuel protests
fields.body:
The fuel protests are a ragbag of different interests. Their cause - "cheaper fuel" - is actively unpopular with people concerned about the environment. This is not the stuff of popular revolution. It has only become so because it has tapped into something potent; the feel bad factor.

If the government is relying on polls to gauge public support, it will be very confused. They don't add up. MORI has 58% supporting protest action, while the RSPB found 51% believing petrol should be taxed for environmental reasons and 46% wanting taxation to limit greenhouse gas emissions. Away from number crunching though, the feel bad factor is unmissable. Everyone is fed up about something, whether it's stealth taxes, the risk of bankruptcy, commuter chaos, extreme weather or fears about contamination of food. Early commentary on New Labour now seems laughable. Then the worry was the government hadn't quite "captured that elusive feel good factor". No, indeed.

The feel bad factor is only partly their fault. The rail crisis derives from privatisation, a decade of under-investment and short cuts in safety procedures. The Tories were also responsible for the BSE cover-up, which has heaped up feelings of hopelessness. Panic about how long BSE has been in the food chain has recently been compounded by concern about lamb - the meat substituted by most families. More evidence of bacterial infection in chickens and banned GM maize in convenience food has further unsettled confidence.

Labour hasn't helped. They whipped up false hope with promises that "things could only get better". They adopted many damaging and hated policies around education, and public transport, like the plans for privatising the Underground. Their first two years involved much harrying of the "undeserving poor" and no visible spending to renew the crumbling infrastructure. Consequently, Tory mismanagement came home to roost before Labour had done anything visible to make a difference.

Only the feel bad factor explains puzzles about the fuel protests. Why should the public, already hugely inconvenienced by rail chaos and consequent traffic congestion, now extensively alarmed about global warming and flooding, support a movement which, if it achieved its aims, would make all this worse? Why else should the public support hauliers, who are often themselves the focus of complaints - when their lorries clog up the cities and pour fumes over children or when their heavy use of local roads necessitates building unpopular by-passes?

I would despair if I thought this support was because the majority believe cheap petrol is a basic human right and are either indifferent to or ignorant about its disastrous environmental impact. But it is obviously more complex. The majority say they would use public transport if it was reliable and cheap. London voted for Ken Livingstone, who explicitly calls for congestion charges and reducing car dependency. Many people say they would support higher fuel tax if the money were ring-fenced for public transport. And no parent is in any doubt that safe streets for children are more important than cheaper fuel.

Yet, the fuel protest has articulated wider and deeper grievances: about stealth taxes driving up living costs without any public pay-offs; about unfair advantages for European hauliers and farmers; about British uncompetitiveness with the high pound; and general hostility to a government which seems pre-occupied with abstract "human" rights and indifferent to the difficulties of ordinary citizens. Other targets might have focused some of this discontent: supermarket chains have undermined British farming by over-reliance on imports and have driven up the cost of living with expensive foods. But only fuel protests symbolise all the elements of current dissatisfaction.

This is because for many the car represents an aspect of themselves, an extension of the body, something reinforced by modern car designs. These emphasise convenience and comfort, allowing car users to seal themselves off from outside discomforts. Even traffic jams seem preferable to the powerlessness caused by disrupted, uncomfortable train journeys. The car feels like an outer skin, a place where you make your own choices about when to travel and which route to take. Absurdly for something which causes so much damage to its surroundings, the car symbolise comfort, convenience and freedom for the self.

Because of this link between self and car, fuel protestors give voice to numerous different ways in which people currently feel assaulted - feeling less well-off, inconvenienced, unprotected and harried, without any pay-offs like cleaner air. Making everything easier for the car driver would only be a short-term fix. It wouldn't deal with the root causes of other grievances and in the long run would cause a deterioration in quality of life. The signs are promising that Gordon Brown won't back down over fuel tax. But he must attend to the deeper separate grievances embedded in the fuel protest. Only then will the public be willing to shed their second skin - the car.

webTitle: The best stripper scene

fields.headline: The best stripper scene
fields.standfirst: Nutty professor II: the klumps
fields.trailText: Nutty professor II: the klumps
fields.body:
Buddy Love (Eddie Murphy), the demonic alter-ego of Professor Sherman Klump, has broken into the Klump family home to steal Sherman's bright red elixir of youth. Before he can proceed, however, he's cornered by the lascivious Grandma Klump (Murphy), who believes she has stumbled upon a male stripper booked for a family party.

Licking her lips, she approaches him.

"You know, you look just like Ken Norton in that movie Mandingo."

Buddy backs into the wall.

"Oh, really?"

"Yeah. But this is the closest I'm ever going to get to Ken Norton."

She flutters her eyelashes at him.

"Er... thank you. Thank you so much."

She advances still closer.

"I wondered if you'd give me a little private dance?"

She begins to dance as suggestively as her body allows.

"OK, you want a private dance?" asks a terrified Buddy. "OK, I can do that. But first, I'm so thirsty. So thirsty! I got a craving for some red fruit punch."

Grandma stops dancing for a moment.

"Red fruit punch? I don't seen none in the house. But there was some out in the refrigerator in the garage..."

"In the garage? Well, after I quench my thirst, I'm gonna give you a dance."

He starts gyrating.

"You like that?"

Grandma's eyes widen.

"Oh yeah. Just like Soul Train. Oh, Good Lord."

Buddy heads for the door.

"I'll be right back."

See also: Exotica, Mean Streets, Pecker, Three Colours Blue

Don't see also: Striptease

Pointless trivia: Eddie Murphy received $20 million to star in Nutty Professor II.
