webTitle: Pop: Doves

fields.headline: Doves send fans into the rafters
fields.standfirst:
Doves
The Ritz, Manchester
***
fields.trailText:
Doves
The Ritz, Manchester
***
fields.body:
They were clinging to the eaves of the old ballroom to see local heroes, Doves, play their way through their Mercury nominated debut album, Lost Souls. In a previous incarnation, Doves were Sub-sub, bouncing along on the indie-dance cross-over, now they've attached themselves to a far more sturdy, and Mancunian, family tree.

Their bass-heavy sound, garnished with fiddly riffs, and heavy on the delay-pedal, is at times suggestive of The Chameleons, another band of ordinary blokes who wrote powerful music, while the latent melancholy of their song-writing puts you in mind of New Order.

To counteract their slightly static delivery, the band was accompanied by a video backdrop and a light show worthy of bonfire night, while a drum machine and keyboards were used to funk things up.

The wallow and wail of tracks like Seasong are their strongest point. A lolloping bass underpinned a haunting riff as singer-guitarist, Jimi Goodwin, took it in turns with guitarist, Jez Williams, to sing lead vocals.

Each song resembled a soundscape gathering in intensity and sometimes Williams' insidious guitar offered the only discernible detail. Occasionally, even the voices were lost in the drift. As some of the lesser-known tracks tended to the indistinct, the sprightly harmonies of Catch the Sun came as welcome relief to the patient crowd who finally got the chance to jump around.

New single, The Man Who Told Everything, avoided all the clamour in a simple, uncluttered rendition, with Williams' guitar again adding a nice looping riff, while another Doves classic, The Cedar Room, boasted a bass-line to find the pulse in your temples and a chorus that demanded a sing-along. Yes, it's anthemic stuff, music for big lads to hug to, and Doves do take earnestness to new heights. But they don't lack invention.

The best track of the night, Here it Comes, saw Goodwin swap places with drummer Andy Williams, who took the lead vocals, while Goodwin sang the chorus over a cascading Hammond.

Overall, though, this was a display of solidarity rather than showbiz and it made for a solid, if uninspiring, performance.

Leeds Metro, tonight; The Arches, Glasgow, tomorrow; Newcastle university, Thursday; Sheffield university, Friday; Brighton Centre, Sunday; Shepherds Bush Empire, London, 13 &14 November.

In a previous incarnation, Doves were Sub-sub, bouncing along on the indie-dance cross-over, now they've attached themselves to a far more sturdy, and Mancunian, family tree. Their bass-heavy sound, garnished with fiddly riffs, and heavy on the delay-pedal, is at times suggestive of The Chameleons, another band of ordinary blokes who wrote powerful music, while the latent melancholy of their song-writing puts you in mind of New Order. To counteract their slightly static delivery, the band was accompanied by a video backdrop and a light show worthy of bonfire night, while a drum machine and keyboards were used to funk things up. The wallow and wail of tracks like Seasong are their strongest point. A lolloping bass underpinned a haunting riff as singer-guitarist, Jimi Goodwin, took it in turns with guitarist, Jez Williams, to sing lead vocals. Each song resembled a soundscape gathering in intensity and sometimes Williams' insidious guitar offered the only discernible detail. Occasionally, even the voices were lost in the drift. As some of the lesser-known tracks tended to the indistinct, the sprightly harmonies of Catch the Sun came as welcome relief to the patient crowd who finally got the chance to jump around. New single, The Man Who Told Everything, avoided all the clamour in a simple, uncluttered rendition, with Williams' guitar again adding a nice looping riff, while another Doves classic, The Cedar Room, boasted a bass-line to find the pulse in your temples and a chorus that demanded a sing-along. Yes, it's anthemic stuff, music for big lads to hug to, and Doves do take earnestness to new heights. But they don't lack invention. The best track of the night, Here it Comes, saw Goodwin swap places with drummer Andy Williams, who took the lead vocals, while Goodwin sang the chorus over a cascading Hammond. Overall, though, this was a display of solidarity rather than showbiz and it made for a solid, if uninspiring, performance. webTitle: Atom and Lucasfilms join forces to produce Star Wars showcase

fields.headline: Atom and Lucasfilms join forces to produce Star Wars showcase
fields.trailText: In an attempt to stem the flow of unofficial Star Wars sites, bogus trailers and leaks, Lucasfilm has teamed up with Atom to launch an official website for fans to showcase their Star Wars short films
fields.body:
Online film-maker AtomFilms is joining forces with Lucasfilm to produce a website to encourage Star Wars fans to create their own versions of the sci-fi classic.

The website, to be known as the Star Wars Fan Film Network, will give fans and amateur film-makers the chance to submit their own parodies and documentaries of the hugely popular films with the aid of a library of audio clips taken from the franchise, including those of Darth Vader breathing, the lightsabre wave and Rebel blaster fire.

Participants will also get the opportunity to showcase their work on the site. As an added incentive, films that a team of judges from Lucasfilm choose to be shown will receive royalty payments.

Mich Chau, executive vice-president of Lucasfilm, believes that Star Wars fans will jump at the chance to produce their own shorts. "Lucas Online is interested in supporting amateur film-makers and engaging fans to share their passion for Star Wars. By teaming up with AtomFilms we hope to create an easy-to-find, entertaining site for Star Wars fans to share their creativity and have fun," he said.

Scott Roesch, director of web entertainment for AtomFilms, added: "Star Wars is a cultural phenomenon unlike any other in film history we are thrilled to be leveraging our online entertainment expertise to create the first official short film outlet for the loyal Star Wars fans."

In addition to being able to submit their own short films, fans will be able to interact with the film-makers and animators behind the Star Wars films and get the latest news from the set of Episode 2.

A host of unofficial sites have sprung up since the release of Episode 1 last year and producer George Lucas has been appalled by the number of leaks (see our earlier story) from the set of Episode 2, due for release in 2002. This new site could be a way for Lucasfilm to tempt fans away from such sites.

The collaborative site will launch later this year. Information about submissions is available now.

webTitle: Can I go back to my old career after a break?

fields.headline: Can I go back to my old career after a break?
fields.trailText: I came to the UK from India in 1993. I used to work for an Indian space research organisation but to cover my living expenses I took a machine operator's job at a factory in Leicester.
fields.body:
The problem

I came to the UK from India in 1993. I had diploma in electronics and radio engineering and experience working for a highly reputable body called Indian space research organisation. I worked in system engineering and integration and earth station equipment testing department.

But to cover my living expenses I took a machine operator's job at a hosiery factory in Leicester. I am doing the same job seven years later.

I am bored and frustrated. I want to go back to the technical job but I am seven years out of that and my knowledge needs to be refreshed. I am 32. I am married and have two kids.

I am confused and remain upset. I can not see my future ahead. Is there any way I can have job satisfaction. I am hard working and can work long hours.

The solution

Everyone deserves job satisfaction, although some people are able to accept poor job satisfaction in return for satisfaction in other areas of their lives. For example, some mothers work in unskilled factory jobs because it enables them to pick their kids up from school and care for them - which is more important to them than job satisfaction.

In your case, you have traded a highly satisfying job for a new life in a different country. My guess is that you have put up with the trade-off for this long, but have now reached the point where your life in the UK does not compensate for your boredom at work. In which case, I encourage you not to put up with it any longer and to take every step to gain more stimulating work. Here are some of my suggestions to help you:

 Contact your local university or college and see if they run courses in electronics or radio engineering. Perhaps you can do a part-time (evening) degree, HND or diploma course to update your skills.

 Contact your local university careers service and ask them what publications you would need (local papers, specialist publications, etc.) to get in order to seek out jobs in this field. Ask for any other advice. You may have to pay for this as you are not a graduate in this country.

 Apply for jobs. You might have to accept lower pay to start with, and start at the bottom, but it should be worth it in the long run. You are still young enough to work your way up.

 Contact employers that you have seen advertise vacancies in your chosen field or even if you just know they employ people in this field. Ask their advice - many people are only too happy to spare a few minutes to help others get a foot in the door.

You might have to take a drop in income, or spend money in training, but the investment should reap dividends in a few years by increasing the quality of your life.

 Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes to Work (Purple House) and Managing Your Boss in a Week (Hodder & Stoughton).

webTitle: Classical review: BBCSO/ Belohlavek

fields.headline: BBCSO/ Belohlavek
fields.standfirst:
Barbican Hall, London
****
fields.trailText:
Barbican Hall, London
****
fields.body:
Jiri Belohlavek's outstanding credentials as a Janacek interpreter were demonstrated at Glyndebourne earlier this year, when he conducted a revival of Jenufa that for its passion, lyricism and sheer dramatic coherence will never be forgotten by anyone fortunate enough to witness it.

For the BBC Symphony Orchestra's concert at the Barbican, this underrated Czech conductor tackled two of the same composer's less well-known orchestral works, one of them operatically derived - the concert suite from his final opera From the House of the Dead - the other the early symphonic poem, The Fiddler's Child.

Every element matters in Janacek's orchestral writing - a single string trill, or a brief woodwind motif can carry as much significance as a grand rhetorical gesture - and Belohlavek understands that perfectly. The Fiddler's Child is wedded to a detailed programme, in which a solo violin impersonates the fiddler, whose ghost returns to claim his child, who is portrayed by an oboe.

The BBC Symphony Orchestra responded as keenly as ever to a conductor who has clear ideas on what he wants and the technique to deliver. In the three extracts from The House of the Dead, Belohlavek managed to conjure up the work's immense compassion and transfiguring optimism through the orchestral writing alone. It was never going to be the same experience as seeing the whole opera in a theatre, but it was a good substitute.

Between this pair of works, there was an almost self-contained mini-concert of Liszt - a curious coupling for the Janacek, for it is hard to think of two more dissimilar composers. The Chilean Alfredo Perl was the soloist in the first of Liszt's piano concertos, a thoughtful, highly musical account, which played down the barnstorming aspects of the solo writing and concentrated instead on the poetic dialogues between the keyboard and the orchestra.

Perl then played the first of the Mephisto Waltzes, conjuring up the piece's diablerie without resorting to overt theatricality; and Belohlavek and the orchestra added another piece of late Liszt, in the form of The Black Gondola, John Adams' orchestration, gleaming and sensuous, of the 1882 piano original.

webTitle: Price cuts boost sales

fields.headline: Price cuts boost sales
fields.standfirst:
Money Unlimited
Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Private buyers piled back into the new car market last month as manufacturers lowered prices.
fields.body:
Private buyers piled back into the new car market last month as manufacturers lowered prices.

Private registrations rose 14.1%. The number of new cars bought in October 2000 totalled 153,541, a 2.6% rise on the October 1999 figure, the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders said yesterday.

The society added that research carried out at last month's Birmingham motor show indicated that nearly half of visitors intended to buy a new car over the next 12 months.

"As well as producing new, improved models, manufacturers are reducing list prices and provid ing longer warranties and better servicing packages," said SMMT chief executive Christopher Macgowan.

However, Rover sold only 5,613 cars compared to 7,678 in October 1999, its market share dipping from 5.13% to 3.66%.

webTitle: Classical review: LSO/Tilson Thomas

fields.headline: Mahler's least-played symphony illuminated
fields.standfirst:
LSO/Tilson Thomas
Barbican Hall, London
****
fields.trailText:
LSO/Tilson Thomas
Barbican Hall, London
****
fields.body:
Mahler's Seventh is generally regarded as the joker in the pack, as far as his symphonies are concerned. "Enigmatic" is how it is commonly described, although perhaps this reflects a failure to find an adequate language with which to describe it.

Few would doubt the quality and impact of its individual movements, but many have claimed that the raucous flurry of its outer sections sits awkwardly with the darker musings of its centre. Not Schoenberg, however, who considered it "perfect".

More recently, the Seventh - the least played of Mahler's symphonies and a work which has defeated many of his most celebrated interpreters - has been championed by conductors such as Riccardo Chailly and Michael Tilson Thomas. Tilson Thomas's recent recording of the work with the LSO has been much admired and finally we have the chance to hear him conduct it live.

What he reveals is a work far from incoherent, though out on a limb from the rest of Mahler's output as far as its subject is concerned.

We think of Mahler primarily as the symphonic explorer of the psyche, yet the Seventh replaces introversion with observation. What we hear is the clamour of external reality passing by in a relentless processional. Throughout, the themes seem to pile up on each other in jangling profusion, like myriad sensations jumbled together. The trudging, anticipatory dissonances of the first movement open onto a landscape at once imposing and sensual, as Mahler pushes for an almost Straussian erotic frenzy. The two nocturnes are filled with a garish surrealism, while the central scherzo is a frantic waltz on the edge of an abyss. The finale conjures up imperial Vienna, raucous and clangorous, with triumph.

Much of this is revelatory, though its impact is occasionally purchased at a price. Tilson Thomas takes it all at such an unremittingly high voltage, that you wish he would simmer down in places. In marked contrast to Simon Rattle's recent, warm-sounding, performance of the Ninth with the LSO, Tilson Thomas opts for a more brittle, kaleidoscopic orchestral palette, demanding playing of bravura extravagance from the orchestra, who only rise intermittently to the challenge.

The end result was thrilling, if raw round the edges in places, while some of the taxing instrumental solos were handled with less than the necessary delicacy.

webTitle: Visual arts review:  Tony Oursler / The Influence Machine

fields.headline: Tony Oursler / The Influence Machine
fields.standfirst:
Soho Square, London
****
fields.trailText:
Soho Square, London
****
fields.body:
The dead are coming through. We've been trying to connect with the other side for centuries and finally we've made it. It wasn't the crystals, oiuja boards and hexes that did it, but good old technology. The ghosts are definitely in the machine: in the morse code signals tapped out on the telegraph wires, in the bubbling static on the old valve radio; in that disappearing dot when you switch off the TV.

The spirit world has made it into cyberspace, they're in the smoke and in the video; they're in London's Soho Square. An Artangel project, The Influence Machine by American artist Tony Oursler, is a series of video projections, a technological haunting in the park. Projected faces loom in artificial smoke. A head spins amid the dripping leaves. A man beats his head against a treetrunk. So what's new, you say, in Soho Square?

I'd like to say it's spooky, but this is art. Oursler's talking heads, intoning their vaguely existential Beckettian monologues, work well outdoors, weather permitting. The subject suits him, too: death, in Oursler's usually gallery-bound art, is but another form of loneliness, another occasion for aggressive mutterings. Soho Square is apt: John Logie Baird's first demonstrations of television were made just down Frith Street (the real Frith Street ghost, on the other hand, is a phantom blackbird, who has been flitting through walls for hundreds of years).

Baird used ventriloquist dummies for his out-of-body experiments on the cathode ray tube, his modern equivalent of the crystal ball. The ghosts here are mediums for yet other voices, whose intonings and plaints haunt the Soho night. Maybe there are too many voices, too many spirits. The cumbersome equipment, the smoke machines and small army of technicians somehow dulls the effect.

That the voices are American is no surprise; Soho, after all, is colonised by the US movie industry. The Influence Machine is more about the clairvoyance of modern communications, the disembodied unreal lives we lead - less in our imaginations than on the phone, keyboard-tapping rather than table-rapping. Oursler's work was recently shown in New York's Madison Square. Americans need ghost stories to shore up their fragile sense of continuity in the new world. Europeans, on the other hand, already have too much to haunt us. The best thing is to come across Oursler's spirits by chance, late at night and drunk, while looking for a phantom cab.

Until November 12.

webTitle: Classical review: Philharmonia/Sawallisch

fields.headline: Philharmonia/Sawallisch
fields.standfirst:
Royal Festival Hall, London
***
fields.trailText:
Royal Festival Hall, London
***
fields.body:
It may have been part of the Philharmonia's Mendelssohn series, but there was no doubt where the focus lay in Wolfgang Sawallisch's concert - and it was not on Mendelssohn's Scottish Symphony, in the second half of the programme.

Before the interval, Krystian Zimerman performed that most evocative of virtuoso showpieces, Rachmaninov's Second Piano Concerto. On paper, this was a match made in heaven, with Zimerman's extroversion enhanced by Sawallisch's classicism, with the luxurious support of the Philharmonia.

Yet in practice, the relationship between soloist and conductor, while built on contrast, was rather a dissonant clash of musical approaches. Where Zimerman strove to create the expressive ebb and flow that characterises his solo performances, he found himself contained by the strict boundaries of speed and articulation set by Sawallisch.

Although the sensuous second theme of the first movement was allowed an expansive tempo, there was little of the poetic momentum the music demands. Similarly, Sawallisch's refusal to complement the spontaneity of his soloist compromised the emotional charge of the slow movement.

Zimerman's exposed dialogues with the woodwind soloists of the orchestra were not helped by the oppressive brightness of his piano, or the unforgiving acoustics of the Royal Festival Hall. But as the cold energy of the finale demonstrated, this was an account defined by musical difference rather than creative synergy - even if the brilliance of the coda at last gave a glimpse of unity between soloist and orchestra.

Sawallisch and the Philharmonia were on much firmer interpretative ground in Mendelssohn's Scottish Symphony. Sawallisch turned the fantasy of Mendelssohn's novel structure into a single sweep of classical integrity. Yet there was real variety here, too: from the first movement's slow-burning melancholy to the unbridled round-dance of the second. Sawallisch's tour de force came in his purposeful slow movement and the lean power of his finale. The major-key coda - which can sound like one of Mendelssohn's most ill-judged inspirations - was, at Sawallisch's fleet-footed speed, the only logical conclusion to the symphony.

Samuel Barber's ebullient School for Scandal Overture, which opened the concert, was projected with the same combination of clarity and finesse.

Sawallisch's tour de force came in his purposeful slow movement and the lean power of his finale. The major-key coda - which can sound like one of Mendelssohn's most ill-judged inspirations - was, at Sawallisch's fleet-footed speed, the only logical conclusion to the symphony. Samuel Barber's ebullient School for Scandal Overture, which opened the concert, was projected with the same combination of clarity and finesse.
